THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Errin Lamont Hutton, 
          Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee 
  County

  Judge

Unpublished Opinion 
  No. 2004-UP-286
  Submitted February 23, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  May 3, 2004

APPEAL DISMISSED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender 
          Robert M. Pachak, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
          Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, all of Columbia; and 
          Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER 
  CURIAM:Â  Hutton was convicted of two counts of armed robbery, two counts 
  of ABHAN, four counts of kidnapping, armed robbery, and burglary in the first 
  degree.Â  He received ten-year sentences on the two ABHAN charges, and on each 
  of the remaining charges he was sentenced to life imprisonment without parole.Â  
  Huttonâ€™s appellate counsel has petitioned to be relieved as counsel, stating 
  he has reviewed the record and has concluded Huttonâ€™s appeal is without merit.Â  
  The sole issue briefed by counsel argues Huttonâ€™s trial should have been severed 
  from that of a codefendant.Â  In a separate pro se brief, Hutton raises 
  twenty issues addressing jurisdictional or due process issues.
After 
  review of the record pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) 
  and State v. Williams,Â  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss 
  this appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to be relieved. 
  [1] 
APPEAL DISMISSED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concur.



 
   
    [1]  Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE 
  STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        E. Hathaway Construction, 
          Inc., Respondent, 
        
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        David Eli, a/k/a David Eliyahu, 
          Four Seasons, Rebecca Shirley, David L. Shirley and the Shirley Family 
          Limited Partnership, Defendants
        Of Whom David Eli, a/k/a 
          David Eliyahu, Four Seasons is the, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion 
  No. 2004-UP-289
  Heard April 7, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  May 4, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, 
  REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        John M Leiter, of Myrtle 
          Beach, for Appellant.
        Norwood David DuRant, of 
          Surfside Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER 
  CURIAM:Â  E. Hathaway Construction, Inc. brought this action against David 
  Eli, a/k/a David Eliyahu, Rebecca Shirley, David L. Shirley, and the Shirley 
  Family Limited Partnership to foreclose on a mechanicâ€™s lien and for breach 
  of contract seeking to recover money owed for the construction of a building 
  on land Eli leased from the Shirleys.Â  The Master-In-Equity awarded Hathaway 
  a judgment on its breach of contract claim, determined the total debt on the 
  mechanicâ€™s lien, including a set-off in favor of Eli as a result of a leak, 
  and ordered the foreclosure of the lien.Â  The master also awarded Hathaway attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.Â  
FACTS 

In March 
  of 2000, Hathaway and Eli entered into a verbal contract for the construction 
  of a building on land leased from the Shirleys.Â  The building was to be used 
  by Eli for selling beach merchandise.Â  The parties agreed Eli was to pay cost 
  plus fifteen percent.Â  
The original 
  plan for the building called for the installation of a glass panel front to 
  the building.Â  After construction began, Eli requested a change to the shape 
  of the front of the building by adding more glass and an angled front.Â  Hathaway 
  used a Kawneer prefabricated system for the front of the building.Â  
Eli made 
  a portion of the payments required under the verbal contract.Â  However, he eventually 
  stopped making payments and Hathaway ceased work on the building.Â  On August 
  31, 2000, Hathaway received a certificate of occupancy for the building, and 
  no further work was completed on the building.Â  
Hathaway filed an Affidavit of Mechanicâ€™s 
  Lien against the real property and the â€œowners of the fee simple estate.â€Â  The 
  notice of mechanicâ€™s lien made no mention of the leasehold interest.Â  On November 
  9, 2000, Hathaway filed the current action, seeking to foreclose on the mechanics 
  lien and also seeking damages for breach of contract.Â  The Shirleys answered 
  and cross-claimed against Eli for indemnification. Â In his answer, Eli asserted 
  he was entitled to a setoff for the leaking glass front.Â  He also counterclaimed 
  for damages suffered by the construction deficiencies.Â  
The Master granted 
  Eli a $20,000 set-off for Eli â€œto repair the roof that has a leak.â€ Â He held 
  Hathaway was entitled to a judgment of $243,705.24 and ordered foreclosure of 
  the leasehold interest.Â  
Eli filed a motion for reconsideration.Â  
  In it he alleged the court erred in concluding Hathaway had a valid mechanicâ€™s 
  lien against the leasehold interest where the lien failed to mention the leasehold 
  and only mentioned the fee simple interest.Â  Eli also alleged the court erred: 
  1) in enforcing the foreclosure against Eliâ€™s wife because she was never made 
  a party to the action; 2) in awarding penalties and interest to Hathaway based 
  upon subcontractors not being paid; 3) in awarding prejudgment interest; 4) 
  in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees under the contract; 5) in awarding one half of the 
  accountantâ€™s fee; 6) in determining the amount of the setoff to which Eli was 
  entitled; and (7) in including certain sums in the total debt secured by the 
  mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  
The Master filed 
  an Amended Final Order in which he reaffirmed his previous order, but changed 
  some of the amounts.Â  He held the total debt secured by the mechanicâ€™s lien 
  was $201,752.69, which included $183,626.41 as the contract balance, prejudgment 
  interest, attorneyâ€™s fees, court fees and the setoff in favor of Eli in the 
  amount of $20,000.00.Â  The master also held Hathaway was entitled to a judgment 
  in the amount of $239,128.59, which included the above total debt plus half 
  of the accountantâ€™s fee equaling $6,352.50 and penalties and interest charged 
  by subcontractors equaling $31,023.40.Â  Although the attorneyâ€™s fees are included 
  in the calculation of the mechanicâ€™s lien, the order states the master awarded 
  the attorneyâ€™s fees â€œunder the terms of the contract.â€Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW 

The foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien 
  is an action at law.Â  T.W. Morton Builders, Inc. v. von Buedingen, 316 
  S.C. 388, 397, 450 S.E.2d 87, 92 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  An action for breach of contract 
  seeking money damages is also an action at law.Â  Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 
  309 S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 (1992).Â  In an action at law, tried without 
  a jury, the masterâ€™s findings of fact will not be disturbed on appeal unless 
  found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the Masterâ€™s findings.Â  
  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 
  773, 775 (1976).

  LAW/ANALYSIS
  I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Validity 
    of the Foreclosure 

Eli argues the Master erred in foreclosing 
  on the leasehold interest pursuant to the mechanicâ€™s lien because the mechanicâ€™s 
  lien did not mention the leasehold interest.Â  Additionally, he asserts the mechanicâ€™s 
  lien only referenced the owners of the fee simple interest, the Shirleys, and 
  not the owners of the leasehold interest, which was foreclosed.Â  We find Eli 
  failed to preserve this issue.
The mechanicâ€™s lien statute requires 
  the lien to include â€œa description of the property intended to be covered by 
  the lien sufficiently accurate for identification, with the name of the owner 
  of the property . . .â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 (Supp. 2003).Â  The lien in this 
  case did list the owner of the property, but failed to list the owner of the 
  leasehold interest.Â  However, in the complaint, under the cause of action to 
  foreclose on mechanicâ€™s lien, Hathaway noted the Shirleys had leased the property 
  to Eli and requested a judgment against the â€œDefendantsâ€ which include Eli.Â  
  Additionally, the complaint indicated that any deficiency judgment, if necessary, 
  should be against the â€œDefendantsâ€ including Eli.Â  During an earlier arbitration 
  hearing, counsel for Hathaway stated that the action was â€œunder the mechanicâ€™s 
  lien statute as a mechanicâ€™s lien foreclosure of a leasehold interest.â€Â  There 
  is no indication in the record that Eli objected to the statement.Â  Finally, 
  at the beginning of trial, the court and counsel had discussions regarding the 
  fact Hathaway was proceeding to foreclose the leasehold interest.Â  Eli made 
  no objection at that time.Â  Later in the trial, Eliâ€™s counsel stipulated that 
  â€œthe mechanicâ€™s lien was filed timely and in compliance with the statute, and 
  the summons and complaint were filed timely and in compliance with the statute.â€Â  
  Again, Eli raised no objection to the court proceeding as a foreclosure against 
  the leasehold interest.
We find Eli should have raised the 
  objection to the form of the mechanicâ€™s lien at the earliest opportunity and 
  not during a motion to alter or amend the judgment after the case had been tried.Â  
  See Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 S.E.2d 436, 437 
  (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œA party cannot for the first time raise an issue by way of 
  a Rule 59(e) motion which could have been raised at trial.â€).Â  As such, we find 
  Eli waived his right to contest the form of the mechanicâ€™s lien.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Foreclosure 
  on Dalya Eliyahuâ€™s Leasehold Interest
Eli contends 
  the master erred in foreclosing the leasehold interest because Mrs. Eliyahu 
  was never made a party to the action.Â  We disagree.
The purpose 
  of a notice of pendency of an action is to inform a purchaser or encumbrancer 
  that a particular piece of real property is subject to litigation.Â  Pond 
  Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 16, 567 S.E.2d 881, 889 (Ct. 
  App. 2002).Â  The lis pendens statute provides:
 
  
    From the time of filing only, 
      the pendency of the action shall be constructive notice to a purchaser or 
      encumbrancer of the property affected thereby, and every person whose 
      conveyance or encumbrance is subsequently executed or subsequently recorded 
      shall be deemed a subsequent purchaser or encumbrancer and shall be bound 
      by all proceedings taken after the filing of such notice to the same extent 
      as if he were made a party to the action.Â  For the purposes of this 
      section, an action shall be deemed to be pending from the time of filing 
      such notice.
  

S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 15-11-20 (1976) (emphasis added).
Thus, 
  when a notice of pendency is filed, a purchaser or encumbrancer is charged with 
  constructive notice of litigation if his conveyance or encumbrance is subsequently 
  executed or recorded.Â  MI Co., Ltd. v. McLean, 325 S.C. 616, 626, 482 
  S.E.2d 597, 602 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œA properly filed lis pendens binds subsequent 
  purchasers or encumbrancers to all proceedings evolving from the litigation.â€Â  
  South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank v. Cook, 291 S.C. 530, 532, 354 S.E.2d 562, 
  562 (1987).
The mechanicâ€™s 
  lien in this case was filed on October 24, 2000.Â  The lis pendens was filed 
  November 9, 2000.Â  At the time, there was nothing filed with the Horry County 
  Register of Deeds to indicate that Mrs. Eliyahu was a party to the lease.Â  Eli 
  and Mrs. Eliyahu subsequently filed a Memorandum of Lease with the RMC office 
  on December 29, 2000.Â  As Mrs. EliyahuÂ  failed to file the Memorandum of Lease 
  until after the filing of the lis pendens, she is bound by the proceedings taken 
  after the filing of such notice to the same extent as if she had been made a 
  party to the action.Â  Accordingly, we find the master did not err in foreclosing 
  Mrs. Eliyahuâ€™s leasehold interest in the property.Â  
III.Â Â Â  Setoff
Eli contends the master erred in 
  awarding only a $20,000.00 setoff against the amount Hathaway was entitled to 
  collect.Â  He contends the master failed to make specific findings of fact to 
  support the amount.Â  We agree and believe the issue should be remanded to the 
  master for a determination of the amount of the setoff and for specific findings 
  of fact in support of the amount.
In the Amended Final Order the master 
  awarded a $20,000.00 setoff in favor of Eli.Â  The master stated:
 
  
    The Court finds that the Defendant, 
      David Eli, answered and further counter claims and sets off for approximately 
      [$300,000.00] against the Plaintiff.Â  This Court finds after considering 
      all of the evidence presented by David Eli, that most of the evidence is 
      not credible.Â  However, the Court does find for the Defendant, David Eli, 
      and will allow the Defendant, David Eli, the set off in the amount of [$20,000.00] 
      to repair the roof that has a leak.Â  
  

We agree that a setoff is appropriate 
  given the fact that even Hathaway acknowledges the construction is not complete 
  and a leak has occurred in the building.Â  However, the Master made no finding 
  of fact stating how he reached a figure of $20,000.00 for the setoff.Â  We are 
  unable to derive the basis for the figure from the record on appeal.Â  As such, 
  we remand to the master for specific finding regarding the basis for the amount 
  of the setoff to which Eli is entitled.Â  See Timothy C. Doughtie Adver., 
  Inc. v. Nelsen Steel & Wire Co., Inc., 284 S.C. 27, 30, 324 S.E.2d 329, 
  331 (Ct. App. 1984) (case remanded where trial court failed to set forth specific 
  findings of fact and Court of Appeals was unable to determine whether the order 
  was controlled by an error of law).Â  
IV.Â Â Â  Accountantâ€™s 
  Fee
Eli argues the master erred in requiring 
  him to pay one half of the accountantâ€™s fee.Â  We disagree. 
The master found the parties entered 
  into an agreement that each party would pay for one half of the fee for Marshall 
  Wells, a CPA brought in to examine Hathawayâ€™s records.Â  During trial, Lynn Slocum, 
  an employee of Hathaway, testified she was involved in meetings in which Eli 
  requested that an independent CPA audit the account.Â  She also stated that Eli 
  agreed to pay one half of the fee for the audit.Â  Mr. Wells testified that Floyd 
  Hathaway, the owner of Hathaway, told him that his fee would be split between 
  Hathaway and Eli.Â  Finally, Lisa Liebowitz, an employee of Eli, testified that 
  Eli and Floyd Hathaway had a meeting to discuss the account.Â  She testified, 
  â€œDavid called me, say[ing], â€˜Would you â€“ you know, are you willing to work with 
  someone we hire together, with [Hathaway] . . .â€™â€Â  
Based 
  upon our limited standard of review, we find there was evidence in the record 
  to support the masterâ€™s finding that Eli agreed to hire Wells and to pay one 
  half of his fee for the audit of the account at Hathaway.
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Subcontractorâ€™s Penalties 
  and Interest
Eli contends the master erred in 
  awarding Hathaway the penalties and interest resulting from Hathawayâ€™s failure 
  to pay subcontractors.Â  We disagree and find the penalties and interest resulted 
  from Eliâ€™s failure to pay according to the contract and are therefore a cost 
  incurred by Hathaway.
At trial, Slocum testified that Hathaway 
  incurred approximately $32,000.00 in fees, interest, penalties, and costs as 
  a result of Eliâ€™s failure to pay when requested.Â  The record includes many notices 
  of interest charges or late fees by Hathawayâ€™s subcontractors.Â  
The master determined the penalties 
  and interest were the direct result of the breach by Eli.Â  As such, he awarded 
  $31,023.40 to Hathaway under the breach of contract claim.Â  â€œDamages recoverable 
  for breach of contract either must flow as a natural consequence of the breach 
  or must have been reasonably within the partiesâ€™ contemplation at the time of 
  the contract.â€Â  Manning v. City of Columbia, 297 S.C. 451, 455, 377 S.E.2d 
  335, 337 (1989).Â  We find there was testimony and evidence to support the masterâ€™s 
  decision that the penalties and interest were the direct result of the breach 
  by Eli, and therefore, are recoverable under the breach of contract cause of 
  action.
VI.Â Â Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Finally, Eli contends the master 
  erred in awarding Hathaway attorneyâ€™s fees under the contract.Â  He claims there 
  was no evidence the contract allowed for the collection of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  Hathaway contends it should be able to recover attorneyâ€™s fees under the mechanicâ€™s 
  lien statute and the award should be affirmed.Â  We believe the issue should 
  be remanded for a determination by the master as to the amount of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees due under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.
It is well established in South Carolina 
  that â€œ[a]ttorneyâ€™s fees are not recoverable unless authorized by contract or 
  statute.â€Â  Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 307, 486 S.E.2d 750, 759 (1997).Â  
  In this case, there is no evidence in the record indicating attorneyâ€™s fees 
  were contemplated by the contract.Â  Therefore, the master erred in awarding 
  attorneyâ€™s fees to Hathaway under the contract.
The mechanicâ€™s lien statute, however, 
  specifically authorizes the collection of attorneyâ€™s fees by the prevailing 
  party.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (Supp. 2003).Â  While the master stated during 
  the hearing on Eliâ€™s motion to alter or amend that he was awarding the fees 
  under the statute, his final order stated the fees were pursuant to the contract.Â  
  The master did not examine Hathawayâ€™s right to attorneyâ€™s fees under the statute, 
  and therefore, we remand for consideration of the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees 
  to which Hathaway is entitled under section 29-5-10(a).
CONCLUSION
We find Eli waived 
  his right to complain of the form of the mechanicâ€™s lien by not objecting at 
  the earliest possible opportunity.Â  Additionally, we find Mrs. Eliyahu is bound 
  by the proceedings as the Memorandum of Lease was filed subsequent to the filing 
  of the lis pendens.Â  We find the master correctly included in the judgment amount 
  one half of the fee for the accountant and the penalties and interest charged 
  by Hathawayâ€™s shareholders. Â Accordingly, the decisions by the master on these 
  issues are affirmed.Â  We find the master failed to make specific findings of 
  fact regarding the amount of the setoff to which Eli is entitled.Â  Additionally, 
  the master erred in awarding the attorneyâ€™s fees under the contract and not 
  under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.Â  As such, these two issues are reversed and 
  remanded to the master for further consideration.Â  Therefore, the order of the 
  master is 
AFFIRMED 
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Quasay Yusas Thomas, 
          Appellant. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Union County
  Â Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion 
  No. 2004-UP-300
  Submitted February 20, 2004 
  â€“ Filed May 5, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender 
          Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant. 
        Deputy Director for Legal 
          Services Teresa A. Knox; Legal Counsel Tommy Evans, Jr.; and Legal Counsel 
          J. Benjamin Aplin, S.C. Dept. of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services, 
          all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Quasay Yusas 
  Thomas appeals the revocation of his probation.Â  We affirm.
Thomas pled guilty on April 25, 2002 
  to contributing to the delinquency of a minor.Â  He had been indicted for criminal 
  sexual conduct with a minor, second degree.Â  The plea court sentenced him to 
  a three-year term of imprisonment, but suspended the sentence upon his service 
  of six months imprisonment or the payment of a three-hundred-dollar fine and 
  the service of two-years probation. 
Twelve months later, following the 
  issuance of a probation citation charging Thomas with violating the terms of 
  his probation, the sentencing court conducted a hearing on May 15, 2003 and 
  revoked his probation in full.Â  The probation citation cited Thomas, inter 
  alia, with failing to report in December, January, and February to his 
  probation officer as instructed, testing positive for marijuana on March 25, 
  2003 for the third time, and failing to pay a court-ordered fine and a supervision 
  fee, all in violation of the conditions of his probation.Â  With particular reference 
  to his using marijuana, Thomas stated in response to a question from the sentencing 
  court as to whether he could pass a drug test, â€œWell, sir, I havenâ€™t smoked 
  any marijuana in a month.â€Â  Among the standard conditions of Thomasâ€™ probation, 
  which the sentencing court found he violated, was the condition that requires 
  a probationer to â€œrefrain from the violations of any state or federal penal 
  laws.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-430(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  
We decide this case without oral 
  argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR, and affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), 
  SCACR, because the challenge leveled by Thomas at the revocation of his probation 
  is manifestly without merit. See State v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 
  647, 511 S.E.2d 94, 96 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding the decision to revoke probation 
  is committed to the discretion of the sentencing court and the review of the 
  court of appeals is limited to correcting errors of law unless the lack of a 
  legal or factual basis indicated the sentencing judge acted arbitrarily or capriciously); 
  Barlet v. State, 288 S.C. 481, 483, 343 S.E.2d 620, 622 (1986) (â€œProbation 
  may not be revoked solely on the ground the probationer failed to pay 
  fines or to make restitution.â€); 24 C.J.S. Criminal Law Â§1561, at 154 
  (1989) (â€œA violation of the terms, or even one of the terms, of probation is 
  sufficient ground for revocationâ€ and â€œ[a] judge may revoke probation when reasonably 
  satisfied that a state . . . law has been violated, and conviction is not essentialâ€); 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(c) (2002) (making possession of marijuana a criminal 
  offense in South Carolina).Â  
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
GOOLSBY, Â HOWARD, AND KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM: James Gerald Williams 
  appeals from a family court order terminating his parental rights to his minor 
  daughter, Taylor Kristen Cann.Â  The family court terminated Williamsâ€™s parental 
  rights (1) pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(1), based on its finding that

  months and that Williams failed to support the minor child; and (3) based on

Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
LaM Distribution, LLC and Fidelity & Deposit Company of Maryland,       
Defendants.

        LaM Distribution, LLC,       
        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Vaughn Coltrane & Associates, Inc., KCV Construction Services, Inc.; 
        Albert V. Coltrane, P.E.,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Calhoun County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-309
Submitted April 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  7, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Henry W. Brown and John W. Davidson, 
  both of Columbia, for Appellant.
R. Davis Howser, George V. Hanna, IV and Andrew E. Haselden, 
  all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this dispute relating to 
  the construction of a freezer facility, Appellant LaM Distribution (LaM) contends 
  the trial court erred in concluding Respondent Vaughn Coltrane & Associates 
  (VCA) had not breached its contract with LaM and in discounting the award of 
  damages to LaM for fees not paid to VCA.Â  We reverse. 
  [1] 
FACTS
On March 30, 1998, LaM secured a building permit 
  for a $6,500,000.00 refrigerated warehouse facility to be constructed in Calhoun 
  County, South Carolina.Â  Employing temperatures as low as -25 degrees Fahrenheit, 
  the facility freezes and stores food products and other perishables.Â  To design 
  and manage construction of the facility, LaM contracted for the services of 
  VCA, a consulting engineering firm specializing in food industry services.Â  
  The agreement between the parties contained the following clause:

3.Â  VCA will be responsible for exercising the degree of skill 
  and care required by customarily accepted, good professional engineering practices 
  and procedures.

Construction of the facility took longer than planned.Â  
  When the project was approximately sixty-five percent complete, LaM discovered 
  various design and construction problems.Â  A dispute then arose regarding lack 
  of payment of some of the construction management fees owed to VCA.Â  As a result 
  of the dispute, VCA left the job prior to the completion of construction, thereby 
  leaving unfulfilled its contractual obligations.Â  All told, LaM paid VCA $284,498.21 
  for the work, but did not pay approximately $89,000.00 in fees charged during 
  the last portion of the construction management phase of the project.
After construction was complete and the facility 
  went into operation, LaM discovered additional problems with the design and 
  construction of the facility.Â  To assess the condition of the facility, LaM 
  engaged the services of Facilities Design, Inc., an engineering company with 
  experience in the design of cold storage facilities and construction management.Â  
  Over the course of its investigation, Facilities Design found nineteen defects 
  in the facilityâ€™s design and construction.Â  These deficiencies included various 
  instances of inadequate insulation, improper wiring, insufficient emergency 
  lighting, lack of proper drainage, and various code violations.
VCA eventually filed suit against LaM to collect 
  the unpaid fees, alleging causes of action for breach of contract, quantum meruit, 
  and foreclosure of mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  LaM answered and counterclaimed, alleging 
  causes of action for breach of contract, negligence, fraudulent misrepresentation, 
  constructive fraud, negligent misrepresentation, breach of implied warranty, 
  and breach of express warranty.
By order dated May 30, 2001, the trial court granted 
  LaMâ€™s motion for summary judgment on all causes of action alleged against it 
  by VCA.Â  In so ruling, the court noted VCA was not properly licensed to practice 
  engineering in South Carolina because it lacked a Certificate of Authorization 
  as required by statute.Â  Because VCA had not complied with the statutory mandate, 
  the court held â€œVCA is prohibited from enforcing this contract and collecting 
  its fees.â€Â  VCA did not appeal the order.
With only LaMâ€™s counterclaims remaining, the parties 
  tried the matter without a jury in February 2002.Â  The trial court ruled in 
  favor of LaM on only its negligence cause of action, finding VCA liable for 
  eight of the alleged nineteen design and construction defects.Â  Of the eight 
  defects found, however, the court awarded LaM compensation for only six and 
  also reduced damages to account for VCAâ€™s unpaid fees, thereby arriving at a 
  total award of $34,140.00.Â  LaM now appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for breach of contract is an action at 
  law.Â  Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 483, 486 S.E.2d 771, 773 (Ct. 
  App. 1997).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, 
  the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found 
  to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes 
  Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 
  (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Contract
LaM asserts the trial court erred in failing 
  to find VCA had breached its contract with LaM.Â  We agree.
In concluding VCA had not breached its 
  contract by discontinuing work on the project, the trial court stated, â€œthe 
  evidence further discloses that LaM failed to pay VCA and/or KCV for the work 
  it performed under the contract, thereby giving VCA and KCV the legal right 
  to pull off of the job based on this non-payment of agreed to fees.â€Â  The court 
  also indicated other actions by LaM that contributed to affording VCA the legal 
  right to discontinue its performance under the contract.Â  In essence, the court 
  ruled LaMâ€™s non-payment and other actions amounted to a material breach of the 
  contract, thereby relieving VCA of its obligation to perform.Â  
While the trial court is correct that the legal 
  consequences of one partyâ€™s material breach is to relieve the other contracting 
  party of its performance obligation, that rule has no application in the present 
  case.Â  As previously noted, VCA failed to appeal the court order of May 30, 
  2001, dismissing its breach of contract claim against LaM.Â  As an unappealed 
  order, all the findings of fact and legal conclusions contained thereinâ€”including 
  the ruling that LaM did not breach the contractâ€”are now the indisputable law 
  of the case.Â  See Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 
  338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (unappealed ruling is law of the 
  case).Â  Because the prior order established as a matter of law that LaM did 
  not breach the contract, VCA cannot take a second bite at the apple by defending 
  itself on the grounds that LaM materially breached the contract.
Because VCA offered no other defense or excuse 
  for its nonperformance, and the incontrovertible evidence before the court established 
  that VCA did not fulfill its contractual obligation, LaMâ€™s breach of contract 
  cause of action must succeed as a matter of law.Â  The trial courtâ€™s failure 
  to rule accordingly amounts to an error of law.Â  
Moreover, the trial courtâ€™s decision on this matter 
  must be reversed because its conclusion that VCA acted negligently in performance 
  of its duties cannot be squared with the implied conclusion that VCA did not 
  breach its contractual obligation to exercise â€œthe degree of skill and care 
  required by customarily accepted, good professional engineering practices and 
  procedures.â€ 
Offset
LaM next asserts the trial court erred 
  in reducing LaMâ€™s damages to account for VCAâ€™s unpaid fees.Â  We agree.
Although the trial court found VCA liable 
  on LaMâ€™s negligence cause of action, the court also found LaM was comparatively 
  negligent:
I find that the Plaintiff has proven both negligent design 
  and/or negligent construction management as to certain of the nineteen items 
  litigated in this trial as set forth in the discussion, which follows.Â  I further 
  find that the Plaintiff was comparatively negligent as to certain of the nineteen 
  items litigated at trial.
The trial court concluded LaMâ€™s comparative negligence 
  extended to six of the items.Â  The court reduced LaMâ€™s award for one item by 
  twenty percent and reduced the award for the remaining five by fifty percent.Â  
  For each incident of comparative negligence, the court stated the reason for 
  reducing the damages award was because LaM failed to pay VCAâ€™s full fee and 
  that some of the defects would have been avoided had VCA remained on the job. 

While comparative negligence provides 
  a sound basis for reducing tort damages, the concept has no application outside 
  tort law.Â  Indeed, under contract theory, comparative negligence provides no 
  basis for reducing a damages award.Â  See Smoak v. Carpenter Enters., 
  Inc., 319 S.C. 222, 224, 460 S.E.2d 381, 383 (1995) (â€œFurther, a charge 
  on contributory negligence, a tort concept, would have been inappropriate and 
  confusing in the breach of contract and breach of warranty actions.â€).Â  Given 
  our conclusion above that LaM is entitled to recover on its breach of contract 
  claim, LaM is entitled to recover in full for each item.
 REVERSED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

After a review of the

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Teresa Swindler, Anthony Sheppard, and Carolyn Sheppard, DOB:Â  2-4-92Â  
        A minor under the age of 18,        Defendants,
of whom Teresa Swindler and Anthony Sheppard are the       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Lisa A. Kinon, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-313
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  13, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
William Issac Diggs, of Myrtle 
  Beach, for Appellant, Teresa Swindler; John L. Martini, Jr., of North Myrtle 
  Beach, for Appellant, Anthony Sheppard.
Ernest Joseph Jarrett, of Kingstree; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The South Carolina Department 
  of Social Services (DSS) sought to terminate the parental rights of Teresa Swindler 
  and Anthony Sheppard to their minor child.Â  The family court terminated the 
  parental rights of both parents.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Swindler and Sheppard married and had one child 
  together.Â  At the time of the childâ€™s birth, Swindler and Sheppard were already 
  separated.Â  They divorced in 1994 and Swindler received custody of the minor 
  child.Â  
On March 2, 1998, DSS received a complaint Swindler 
  left the minor child with strangers and could not be located.Â  Subsequently, 
  DSS and Swindler entered into a safety plan, with Swindler retaining custody.Â  
  DSS received a second call in May 1998 indicating, again, that Swindler could 
  not be located.Â  Beth Katzenberger, with whom Swindler had been living, informed 
  DSS she had cared for the child for approximately two weeks without contact 
  by Swindler. 
DSS contacted Swindlerâ€™s mother, who indicated 
  Swindler had been staying at the motherâ€™s home, without the child. At that time, 
  Swindler had gone to Columbia with a boyfriend.Â  However, Swindlerâ€™s mother 
  did not know of Swindlerâ€™s exact whereabouts. Since Swindler could not be located, 
  the child was taken into emergency protective custody on May 19, 1998.Â  
After a merits hearing, the court entered a finding 
  that Swindler physically neglected the child and granted custody of the child 
  to Sheppard, with supervised visits to Swindler.Â  Both parents were ordered 
  to attend individual and family counseling.Â  Additionally, both were required 
  to attend and complete parenting skills classes.Â  
Sheppard failed to actively participate in the 
  counseling sessions and had minimal participation in the treatment plan.Â  In 
  fact, he was not cooperative with DSSâ€™s permanency plan. Further, the child 
  began acting out sexually in school and her behavior was continuing to deteriorate.Â  
  Â Â Based upon these facts, DSS took custody of the child in November 1999, 
  and the minor child has remained in DSS custody since that time.Â  Because of 
  her â€œaggressive and sexually reactive behavior and agitated behavior,â€ the minor 
  child was placed in a therapeutic foster home.
While the child was in foster care, DSS completed 
  a home study of Swindlerâ€™s home and the study came back negative because she 
  had married Anthony Swindler, a registered sex offender.Â  Swindler maintained 
  visitation until her pregnancy and transportation problems caused her to stop.Â  

Swindler was referred to Dr. Melissa Muse for 
  continued counseling and supervised visitation.Â  Dr. Muse expressed concern 
  that Swindler would be unable to prevent the child from inappropriately touching 
  Swindlerâ€™s other children. Â Additionally, Dr. Muse was concerned that Swindler 
  showed little ability to set and enforce boundaries for the child.Â  
 DSS brought this action seeking to terminate 
  the parental rights of both Swindler and Sheppard.Â  DSS claimed Sheppardâ€™s parental 
  rights should be terminated under S.C. Code Ann Â§Â§ 20-7-1572(2), (4), (6), and 
  (8) (Supp. 2002).Â  DSS sought to terminate Swindlerâ€™s parental rights under 
  sections 20-7-1572(2), (4), and (8).Â  
The court determined Sheppardâ€™s parental 
  rights should be terminated under all sections alleged by DSS.Â  Specifically, 
  the court found he: 1) had failed to provide support for a period of more than 
  six months; 2) had a diagnosable condition unlikely to change which made him 
  unlikely to provide acceptable care; 3) failed to properly complete the treatment 
  plan and remedy the conditions leading to the removal of the child; and 4) the 
  child had been in foster care for fifteen of the previous twenty-two months.Â  

In regards to terminating Swindlerâ€™s parental 
  rights, the family court found:Â  1) she willfully failed to provide support 
  for in excess of six months, as she had not made a single payment or offer of 
  support in over nine months; and 2) the child has been in DSS custody for more 
  than fifteen out of the last twenty-two months.Â  
Finally, the family court concluded this 
  was a case where the interests of the parents and child were in conflict.Â  The 
  court determined the child had been in DSS custody for twenty-eight months and 
  that the best interest of the child was to terminate Sheppard and Swindlerâ€™s 
  parental rights.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2002), 
  mandates that the TPR statutes â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure 
  prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control 
  of their parents by terminating the parent-child relationship.â€Â  â€œThe interests 
  of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578.Â  â€œGrounds for termination of parental rights must 
  be proven by clear and convincing evidence.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. 
  Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608-09, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003) (citing 
  Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 102 S. Ct. 1388, 71 L. Ed. 2d 599 (1982)).
â€œUpon review, the appellate court may make its own finding 
  from the record as to whether clear and convincing evidence supports the termination.â€Â  
  Headden, 354 S.C. at 609, 582 S.E.2d at 423.Â  The reviewing court, however, 
  is not required â€œto ignore the fact that the family court, who saw and heard 
  the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign 
  comparative weight to their testimony.â€Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 
  281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Termination of Teresa Swindlerâ€™s Parental Rights
Swindler contends the court erred in terminating 
  her parental rights pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-1572(4) and (8) (Supp. 
  2002).Â  We find there was clear and convincing evidence to support the courtâ€™s 
  decision to terminate parental rights.
Pursuant to section 20-7-1572: 

The family court may order the termination of parental rights 
  upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination 
  is in the best interest of the child:
. . . .
(8) The child has been in foster care under the responsibility 
  of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months . . . .Â Â  

Swindler maintains the trial court erred 
  in terminating her parental rights pursuant to section 20-7-1572(8), because 
  the child was removed for unlawful reasons.Â  We disagree and find this section 
  supports the courtâ€™s decision to terminate Swindlerâ€™s parental rights to her 
  daughter.
Swindlerâ€™s main contentions are two-fold.Â  
  First, she asserts the statute requires that she be responsible for the removal 
  of the child and subsequent need for custody by DSS, and that she contribute 
  to the continuance of the removal.Â  Second, she maintains that section 20-7-1572(8) 
  requires a showing that DSS undertook reasonable efforts to return the child 
  but was unsuccessful due to the parentâ€™s actions or inactions. 
â€œAll rules of statutory construction are subservient 
  to the one that legislative intent must prevail if it can be reasonably discovered 
  in the language used, and that language must be construed in the light of the 
  intended purpose of the statute.â€ Ray Bell Constr. Co. v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville 
  County, 331 S.C. 19, 26, 501 S.E.2d 725, 729 (1998).Â  The stated purpose 
  of the TPR statute â€œis to establish procedures for the reasonable and compassionate 
  termination of parental rights where children are abused, neglected, or abandoned 
  in order to protect the health and welfare of such children and make them eligible 
  for adoption. . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1560 (1976).Â  Furthermore, TPR statutes 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures 
  for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by 
  terminating the parent child relationship.â€Â  Joiner ex. rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 
  342 S.C. 102, 108, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000) (quoting S.C. Code Ann.Â§ 20-7-1578).
A clear reading of the statute juxtaposed 
  with its stated purpose demonstrates the legislature intended a child in the 
  care of DSS for more than fifteen out of twenty-two months to be freed from 
  the custody and control of their parents when it is in the childâ€™s best interest.Â  
  The legislature did not express any further requirement to be proven.Â  
The child in this case had been in the 
  care of DSS from November 3, 1999, until the date of the hearings in March 2002, 
  or a total of twenty-eight consecutive months.Â  The family court found that 
  subsection 8 was enacted to address the situation presented by Swindlerâ€™s termination. 
  The court opined that the legislature made provisions for termination when a 
  child was in care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.Â  The court 
  held the Department met its burden and showed that the minor child remained 
  in foster care because of Swindlerâ€™s failure or inability to provide a home 
  that was the subject of a positive home study. 
Swindler failed to provide a safe home and demonstrate 
  the necessary ability to care for the child in order to have her returned prior 
  to the twenty-eight months she spent in foster care.Â  We find that termination 
  under section 20-7-1572(8) was proper.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Best Interest of Child
We find the family court properly terminated 
  Swindlerâ€™s parental rights under Â§ 20-7-1572(8) and find that termination of 
  Swindlerâ€™s rights is in the minor childâ€™s best interests. [1] Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family court's 
  termination. See Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 580, 578 S.E.2d 
  733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003); See also S.C. Code Â§ 20-7-1572 
  (â€œThe family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding 
  of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination is in 
  the best interest of the child.â€). 
There is ample evidence in the record 
  to support the conclusion that termination of Swindlerâ€™s parental rights is 
  in the childâ€™s best interest.Â  First, the reason for the childâ€™s removal from 
  her home was leaving the child with other people for extended periods of time 
  while she was out of town.Â  Swindlerâ€™s mother indicated that Swindler would 
  leave the child with her while she went to Columbia. 
Additionally, Dr. Muse testified that 
  Swindler was ill equipped to care for the special needs of the child.Â  Additionally, 
  Dr. Muse indicated that Swindler would be unable to prevent the child from possible 
  perpetration of sexual acts against the two younger children.Â  Finally, Dr. 
  Muse indicated that Swindlerâ€™s mother put forth the most effort in counseling 
  and therapy sessions.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court correctly found 
  termination of Swindlerâ€™s parental rights was in the best interest of the minor 
  child. 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Termination of Anthony Sheppardâ€™s Parental Rights
The family court terminated Sheppardâ€™s parental 
  rights on four grounds. [2] Â  Upon reviewing the record, Sheppardâ€™s statement, 
  and the family courtâ€™s determination in its entirety, we find no error in the 
  courtâ€™s decision.Â  The child was in foster care under the responsibility of 
  the state continuously from November 1999 until March 2002.Â  Accordingly, the 
  family courtâ€™s decision to terminate Sheppardâ€™s parental rights is affirmed.
CONCLUSION
We find the court did not err in terminating 
  Swindler and Sheppardâ€™s parental rights under section 20-7-1572(8) and the termination 
  was in the best interest of the minor child.Â Â Â  Accordingly, the decision of 
  the family court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  This issue was not appealed.Â  
    While an unappealed ruling is normally the law of the case, see ML-Lee 
    Acquisition Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 241, 489 
    S.E.2d 470, 472 (1997), because the ruling involves the best interest of a 
    child, this court may raise the issue ex mero motu.Â  
    Ex parte Roper, 254 S.C. 558, 563, 176 S.E.2d 175, 177 (1970); see 
    also Galloway v. Galloway, 249 S.C. 157, 160, 153 S.E.2d 326, 327 
    (1967) (â€œThe duty to protect the rights of minors has precedence over procedural 
    rules otherwise limiting the scope of review and matters affecting the rights 
    of minors can be considered by this court ex mero motu.â€). 
    Â Â 

 
   
    [2]  Pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 
    (1987), Sheppardâ€™s counsel attached to the record of the family court proceedings 
    an affidavit stating his belief that the appeal lacks merit.Â  Sheppard filed 
    a response to counselâ€™s affidavit, indicating that he has done all he could 
    to bring the child back home and that DSS has used his child to get money 
    with no intention of returning the minor child.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Michael McFarland, Sr. and John Doe, and Child:Â  Sarah McFarland (05/05/1995) 
        Child:Â  Michael McFarland, Jr., (12/04/1996),       
Defendants,
of whom Michael McFarland, Sr. is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Wesley L. Brown, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-316
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed May 13, 2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael Dean Hamrick, of Gaffney, for Appellant.
Meredith Brooks Moss, of Gaffney, for Respondents.  
Usha Jefferies Bridges, of Gaffney, for Guardian Ad
Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Michael McFarland appeals a family courtâ€™s order terminating 
  his parental rights. We affirm.
 FACTS
Michael (Appellant) and Christine McFarland are 
  the biological parents of Michael McFarland, Jr.Â  The other member of the family 
  is Sara McFarland. [1]  While 
  the family was living in Cherokee County, the children, then age 3 and 4, were 
  found â€œwalking down a busy highway,â€ unsupervised and improperly clothed. This 
  occurred in March of 2000. The children had wandered away from their home while 
  Mrs. McFarland was sleeping and Appellant was at work. When confronted by the 
  authorities, both Appellant and Mrs. McFarland admitted drug use. The family 
  court ordered the childrenâ€™s removal from the home because of a lack of supervision 
  and because of the drug use. However, the family court granted supervised visitations 
  to Mrs. McFarland and Appellant at the discretion of the DSS. The family court 
  also adopted a treatment plan and ordered the McFarlands to pay child support 
  in the amount of $32.00 per week. 
On April 17, 2000, Appellant was arrested on burglary 
  charges. [2]  He tested positive for marijuana and cocaine 
  on that day as well. While Appellant was in prison, the family court held a 
  first Permanency Hearing in May 2001, which meeting the McFarlands attended. 
  The family court decided to extend the plan of reunification by six months. 
  In December of the same year, another hearing was held, where Appellant formally 
  requested visitation with the children. The family court denied the request 
  and ordered a plan of termination of parental rights. 
By an order dated March 7, 2003, the family court 
  terminated Appellantâ€™s parental rights regarding both children. 
  [3]  It found that:

(a) the children have lived outside of the home 
  of the parent for a period of six (6) months and the parent has failed to visit 
  pursuant to S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3); (b) the children have lived outside 
  of the home of the parent for a period of six (6) months and the parent has 
  willfully failed to support pursuant to S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4); and (c) 
  the children have been in foster care under the responsibility of the State 
  for fifteen (15) of the last twenty-two (22) months pursuant to S.C.Code Ann. 
  Â§ 20-7-1572(8).

The family court ruled that the lack of support 
  was willful, since Appellant was gainfully employed when the children were removed. 
  [4]  The family court also noted that Appellant had committed three serious 
  felonies shortly after the children left, â€œvoluntarily pursu[ing] course of 
  lawlessness [leading to] his imprisonment and inability to pay child support.â€ 
  The family court ruled that the termination was in the best interest of the 
  children. 
ISSUES

  
    Did the family court err in terminating Appellantâ€™s parental rights
    for failure to support his children while he was 
  in prison?
    
  
    Did the family court err in terminating Appellantâ€™s parental rights
    for failure to visit his children while he was 
  in prison?

LAW/ANALYSIS
â€œThe termination of parental rights is 
  governed by statute.â€ Depâ€™t. of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 322, 
  335, 543 S.E.2d 580, 582 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1772 (Supp. 
  2000)). Under Â§ 20-7-1572, one of three conditions must be met: the child must 
  have lived outside the home of the parent for at least six months; the court 
  must determine that the parent has willfully failed to support the child; or 
  the parent has willfully failed to visit the child. Id. An order terminating 
  parental rights must be supported by clear and convincing evidence. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 413 S.E.2d 835 (1992). 
  An appellate court is free to make its own findings as to the existence of facts, 
  but is not required to ignore the findings from the trial court.Â  Dorchester 
  County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 477 S.E.2d 476 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â  Where the trial courtâ€™s findings are adequately supported, an appellate 
  court should give proper deference to those findings since the trial court was 
  able to personally observe the parties and weigh their credibility.Â  South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 547 S.E.2d 506 
  (Ct. App. 2001). 
The family court terminated Appellantâ€™s parental 
  rights on three statutory grounds and because it found that termination was 
  in the best interest of the children. On appeal, Appellant addresses only two 
  of those grounds. However, â€œ[a] family court may order the termination of parental 
  rights upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding 
  that termination is in the best interest of the child . . . .â€ Â§ 20-7-1572 (emphasis 
  added). Additionally, â€œ[an] appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or 
  judgment upon any ground(s) in the Record on Appeal.â€ Â Rule 220 (c), SCACR. 
  Therefore, we affirm the family court using only statutory ground since we agree 
  that the termination of Appellantâ€™s parental rights serves the best interest 
  of the children.
The facts before us clearly satisfy the requirement 
  under Â§ 20-7-1572(8) that the children live outside the parentâ€™s home for fifteen 
  of the twenty-two months preceding an order for termination. Here, the children 
  were removed from the home on April 9, 2000 and have lived in the continuous 
  care of DSS. The family court held the termination hearing in October 2002 and 
  did not issue the termination order until March 2003. Therefore, the children 
  had lived outside the home for at least thirty- six months, more than twice 
  the required time. 
As for the best interest of the children, the family 
  court found that Appellant had a â€œhistory of domestic violence, drug use and 
  neglect, lack of compliance with the treatment plan.â€ The record indicates that 
  the authorities had already removed the children from the McFarland home on 
  a prior occasion in 1998. Additionally, the family court noted that one of the 
  children suffered from an illness that required expensive medication that Appellant 
  would probably have difficulty providing. The family court also placed much 
  emphasis on the strong bond between the children, a bond that would be at risk 
  if the children were separated and placed in different homes. That scenario, 
  according to DSS, was more likely to happen without the termination of Appellantâ€™s 
  parental rights. Given all of that evidence, plus Appellantâ€™s long-term incarceration, 
  we agree with the family court that the termination of Appellantâ€™s parental 
  rights serves the best interest of the children.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the family courtâ€™s ruling is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

 
   
    [1]  Mrs. McFarland is Saraâ€™s biological mother, but Saraâ€™s biological 
    father is unknown. Mrs. McFarland has waived her parental rights to both children. 
  

 
   
    [2] Appellant was convicted on burglary charges in June 2000, and sentenced 
    to twenty years in prison. He has been incarcerated since his arrest. 

 
   
    [3] By the same order, the court also terminated the rights of Mrs. McFarland 
    and of John Doe, the biological father of Sara McFarland.Â  

 
   
    [4] Appellant subsequently quit his job but offers no justification for 
    that decision.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Bruce S. Morris,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Larry R. Patterson Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-318
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  13, 2004Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Legal Counsel J. Benjamin Aplin, South Carolina Department 
  of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Bruce S. Morris appeals, contending 
  the sentencing court relied on invalid considerations in revoking his probation 
  for breach of the conditions of probation.Â  We affirm.1
BACKGROUND
Following Morrisâ€™ pleas on February 28, 2002, to 
  two separate indictments for financial identity fraud, the Honorable Gary E. 
  Clary sentenced Morris to two concurrent ten-year terms of imprisonment, suspended 
  the sentences, and placed him on probation for five years.Â  Several months later, 
  in October 2002, Morris appeared before the Honorable John Few, charged with 
  violating the terms of his probation.Â  Judge Few found him in violation of several 
  conditions and special conditions, but continued Morrisâ€™ probation as long as 
  he either maintained full-time employment or was a full-time college student.Â Â  

On May 30, 2003, Morris appeared before the Honorable 
  Larry R. Patterson, again charged with violating the conditions of his probation.Â  
  More specifically, the probation citations charged him with (1) failing to report 
  as instructed; (2) failing to pay supervision fees arrearage; (3) failing to 
  pay court-ordered costs and assessments arrearage; (4) failing to pay restitution 
  arrearage; and (5) failing to follow the advice and instruction of the supervising 
  agent.Â  Judge Patterson revoked Morrisâ€™ probation and reinstated the original 
  ten-year sentences.Â  He later denied Morrisâ€™ motion to reconsider the revocation.
FACTS
At the revocation hearing, the probation 
  officer listed the conditions of Morrisâ€™ probation that he allegedly violated.Â  
  Among other things, he reported that Morris had paid â€œnine hundred dollars on 
  restitution to date, leaving him with [an] arrearage of $465.00, and a balance 
  of $6,680.97.â€Â  Afterward, Jack Millwood, the victim of one of Morrisâ€™ financial 
  identity fraud transactions for which Morris was convicted, addressed Judge 
  Patterson and expressed dissatisfaction with the criminal justice system and 
  the manner in which it had handled the case.Â  The victim in the other case, 
  Joseph A. Nyitray, did not attend the hearing.Â  
For his part, Morrisâ€™ attorney related Morris had 
  a full-time job and had recently paid $1,500 in college tuition.Â  
At the end of the hearing, Judge Patterson 
  said, â€œ[Morris] should of [sic] paid this man his money that he stole 
  from him rather than paying the college tuition.Â  Iâ€™m revoking it in full.â€Â  
  Morris thereafter moved Judge Patterson to reconsider his action, claiming â€œsignificant 
  factual and legal mattersâ€ either not considered or not fully considered by 
  him warranted the revocation order being vacated or modified.
 A subsequent hearing on the motion to 
  reconsider left the revocation intact.Â  Judge Patterson said he had based the 
  order of revocation on Morrisâ€™ failure to report and his choice to pay college 
  tuition rather than satisfy his restitution obligation.2Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
The decision to revoke probation is addressed 
  to the sound discretion of the sentencing judge.Â  State v. Hamilton, 
  333 S.C. 642, 511 S.E.2d 94 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
We cannot say, based on the record before 
  us, that the sentencing judge abused his discretion in this instance.Â  Morrisâ€™ 
  basic complaint on appeal is that he â€œowed nothing to . . . Millwood at the 
  time of his revocation hearing.â€ Nothing in the record, however, supports this 
  assertion other than defense counselâ€™s own statement, which he made in argument 
  at the sentence reconsideration hearing, that â€œthe court may have based its 
  decision, in whole or in part, on a mistaken belief that [Millwood] . . . was, 
  in fact, the victim who was aggrieved by the alleged failure to pay restitution 
  as ordered.â€Â  Certainly, no evidence supports it.Â  Cf. McManus v. 
  Bank of Greenwood, 171 S.C. 84, 171 S.E. 473 (1933) (stating a court cannot 
  consider statements of fact appearing only in argument of counsel).
Moreover, the sentencing judgeâ€™s statement that 
  â€œ[Morris] should have paid this man his money that he stole from him rather 
  than paying the college tuitionâ€ did not identify Millwood as the victim aggrieved 
  by Morrisâ€™ failure to pay restitution and could just as well have referred to 
  Nyitray.Â  As we read the sentencing judgeâ€™s remarks, he simply expressed concern 
  that Morris chose to pay his college tuition rather than pay toward the amount 
  he owed in restitution, a sum that totaled $6,680.97 on the date of the probation 
  revocation hearing and of which sum he owed $465.00 in arrears. 
We do not reach the issue of whether the 
  sentencing judgeâ€™s finding that Morris had failed to report as instructed, a 
  finding Morris does not challenge on appeal, alone would support the sentencing 
  judgeâ€™s decision to revoke Morrisâ€™ probation.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

 
  1Â  
    Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

 
  2 The sentencing judge stated at the hearing on the 
    motion to reconsider, â€œI . . . found [a] failure to pay his restitution . 
    . .Â  and he failed to report.â€

Ron C. Bennett, of Marion, pro se, for Appellant.
Robert E. Lee and Amy Wise, of Forence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Ron C. Bennett appeals, contending 
  the trial court improperly granted summary judgment to the respondents the State 
  of South Carolina, the County of Marion, and Magistrate Lunette Cox.Â  We affirm 
  pursuant to Rules 215 and 220(2), SCACR, and S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-8-250 (Supp. 
  2003), along with the following authorities:Â  Taylor v. Medenica, 331 
  S.C. 575, 582, 503 S.E.2d 458, 462 (1998) (noting an issue which is raised but 
  not argued in brief is deemed abandoned and will not be considered on appeal); 
  Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 298, 519 S.E.2d 583, 600 (Ct. 
  App. 1999) (holding conclusory arguments may be treated as abandoned); Englert, 
  Inc. v. Netherlands Ins. Co., 315 S.C. 300, 304, 433 S.E.2d 871, 873 (Ct.

  on appeal); Moody v. McLellan, 295 S.C. 157, 162, 367 S.E.2d 449, 452 
  (Ct. App. 1988) (stating an alternative ruling of the trial court in granting 
  summary judgment that was not excepted to constitutes a basis for affirming 
  the trial court and is not reviewable on appeal).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
AFFIRMED.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Robert G. Barbary,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-320
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed May 14, 2004 


APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Tara S. Taggart, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert G. Barbary (Appellant) 
  was convicted of two counts of criminal domestic violence of a high and aggravated 
  nature (CDVHAN).Â  He was sentenced to concurrent terms of ten years in prison.Â  

On appeal, counsel for Appellant has filed a final 
  brief along with a petition to be relieved as counsel.Â  Appellant has not filed 
  a pro se response.Â  After a thorough review of the record pursuant 
  to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967) and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s 
  petition to be relieved.Â  Â Â Â Â  
APPEAL DISMISSED. [1] 
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.Â  

 
   
    [1] Â  This case is decided without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.
