THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Cheryl Moyer Dillman,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Mitchell Foy Dillman, personal representative for the Estate of Kenneth 
        Lew Dillman,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Alvin D. Johnson, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-322
Heard March 11, 2004 â€“ Filed May 14, 
  2004

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
Â AND REMANDED


  
    
      
John S. Nichols, of Columbia and William Randall Phipps, of 
  Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.Â  
Patrick James Thomas Kelley, of Bluffton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â In this domestic action, Mitchell 
  Foy Dillman (Estate), as personal representative of the Estate of Kenneth Lew 
  Dillman (Husband) [1] , alleges 
  numerous errors in the family courtâ€™s order on equitable distribution, the alimony 
  award, and attorneyâ€™s fee award in favor of Cheryl Moyer Dillman (Wife).Â  We 
  affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife were married in Switzerland on 
  October 8, 1989, and were remarried three days later in the United States.Â  
  Prior to their marriage, they purchased a lot on Hilton Head Island.Â  The deed 
  conveyed a two-thirds interest to Wife and the remaining one-third to Husband.Â  
  They later built a house on this lot and Wife paid $364,000 of the $443,000 
  total cost of the land and construction.Â  In February 1993, Wife conveyed one-sixth 
  of her interest to Husband, thereby vesting each with an undivided one-half 
  interest in the property.Â  
In December 1991, Wife loaned Husband money taken 
  from her life insurance policies and funds from her investment account.Â  Husband 
  used the funds to satisfy outstanding mortgages on two quad lots in an apartment 
  complex he owned in Hinesville, Georgia (Hinesville Apartments). [2] Â  Wife received notes and mortgages 
  on the two lots as security for the loan. Â Both parties agreed Husband had significantly 
  paid down the notes at the time of trial but disagreed as to the remaining balance 
  due.Â  
Early in 1994, Husband borrowed a substantial sum 
  from a bank, which he secured by a mortgage encumbering the coupleâ€™s Hilton 
  Head Island home.Â  He used approximately two-thirds of the proceeds of the loan 
  to satisfy mortgages on five more quad lots at his Hinesville Apartments, and 
  deposited the remaining amount into his personal securities account.Â  By the 
  time of the final hearing in family court, Husband had repaid the entire amount 
  due on this loan.Â  
In September 1995, Wife loaned Husband $30,000 from 
  her Merrill Lynch checking account.Â  Husband combined these loan proceeds with 
  personal funds to purchase a lot in Sun City, Hilton Head, in March 1996.Â  Both 
  parties testified Husband repaid at least $15,730 of the loan just prior to 
  purchasing the property.Â  
In June 1999, Wife became suspicious that Husband was 
  having an extramarital affair after discovering notes written to him by a woman 
  the couple had met while vacationing in France.Â  Husband had taken a trip without 
  Wife at the time and place discussed in the notes.Â  Upon his return, Wife discovered 
  a used prophylactic in the garbage.Â  Husband denied he and the woman traveled 
  together and claimed he shared his hotel room with a gentleman he met on the 
  tennis courts.Â  Wife testified Husbandâ€™s extramarital affair was the cause of 
  the breakup of their marriage, but Husband claimed the marriage had broken down 
  prior to his involvement with the other woman.Â  
In September 1999, Wife brought this action for divorce, 
  seeking equitable distribution of marital property, separate maintenance and 
  support, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Both parties requested their antenuptial agreement 
  be recognized for purposes of equitable distribution. 
  [3] Â  However, after reviewing the agreement, the family court ruled the 
  agreement was void, a ruling neither party appealed.Â  The court bifurcated the 
  trial, granting Wife a divorce, and reserving all other issues for a later hearing.Â  
  At that hearing, the court divided the marital assets, awarded Wife alimony 
  of $1,000 per month, issued a mutual restraining order, and required Husband 
  to pay $20,000 of Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The order permitted a termination 
  of alimony only in the event of Wifeâ€™s death or remarriage, not providing for 
  the eventuality of Husbandâ€™s death.
SCOPE 
  OF REVIEW
When reviewing 
  an appeal from the family court, we have the authority to find facts in accordance 
  with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  We are not, however, 
  required to disregard the findings of the judge, who saw and heard the witnesses 
  and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative 
  weight to their testimony.Â  Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 109-110, 557 
  S.E.2d 693, 699-700 (Ct. App. 2001) (internal citations omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Equitable 
  Distribution Issues
A.Â  Failure to Consider Statutory Factors
The estate asserts several errors 
  regarding the family courtâ€™s findings and rulings on equitable distribution, 
  among them contending the court failed to weigh the various factors contained 
  in the statute [4]  by failing 
  to consider the existence of an antenuptial agreement and essentially ignoring 
  the manner in which the parties conducted their financial affairs during the 
  marriage.Â  We disagree.Â  
The statute lists the factors the family 
  court must consider when making an equitable distribution award and vests the 
  court with the discretion to determine the weight to be assigned each factor.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003).Â  Contrary to the estateâ€™s allegations, 
  we find the court adequately considered the relevant factors and addressed them 
  sufficiently in the final order so that this court is able to conclude it was 
  fully cognizant of them.Â  See Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 
  100, 545 S.E.2d 531, 537 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 
  492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 859 (Ct. App. 1996)).Â  As an appellate function, this 
  court looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment, and if the result 
  is equitable, taken as a whole, that this court might have weighed specific 
  factors differently than the family court is irrelevant.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 
  349 S.C. 85, 97, 561 S.E.2d 610, 616 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
As to the antenuptial agreement, while it may provide 
  evidence of the intention of the parties initially, it is not controlling because 
  the prior order of the family court declared it void and there has been no appeal 
  of that ruling.Â  Greenville County v. Kenwood Enters., Inc., 353 S.C. 
  157, 173, 577 S.E.2d 428, 436 (2003) (holding any unappealed portion of the 
  trial courtâ€™s judgment is the law of the case and must therefore be affirmed).Â  

B.Â  Marital Fault
The estate further complains the court erred 
  by concluding Husbandâ€™s involvement with another woman contributed to the breakup 
  of the marriage and in considering such when making its award.Â  We disagree.Â  

The estate does not challenge the courtâ€™s 
  conclusion that Husband was involved with another woman, but rather argues the 
  marriage was irretrievably broken prior to any involvement.Â  The evidence, however, 
  amply demonstrates Husband was corresponding with and secretly meeting the other 
  woman prior to the partiesâ€™ divorce, and Wife testified that Husbandâ€™s infidelity 
  contributed to the breakup of the marriage.Â  The family court found that Husbandâ€™s 
  explanations for his behavior lacked credibility.Â  Accordingly, the court appropriately 
  considered Husbandâ€™s fault in its final order.Â  S.C. Code Â§ 20-7-472(2).Â  

C.Â  Marital Home
The estate complains the court erred by awarding Husband 
  only a 20 percent interest in the marital home, arguing the court devalued his 
  sweat equity and in-kind contributions made pursuant to a 5-year plan he alleges 
  existed.Â  We disagree.
The court found Wife directly contributed 
  a significantly greater portion of the cost of the house and land, Husbandâ€™s 
  direct contribution was minimal, and the partiesâ€™ indirect contributions were 
  essentially equal.Â  The estate asserts the court failed to properly weigh Husbandâ€™s 
  efforts as general contractor during construction and, later, his responsibilities 
  of running the household.Â  Husband relied heavily on a so-called 5-year plan 
  contained in a document which Wife denied ever agreeing to.Â  We discern no abuse 
  of discretion in the courtâ€™s decision concerning the marital home.Â  Ball 
  v. Ball, 314 S.C. 445, 448, 445 S.E.2d 449, 451 (1994) (the family court 
  has wide discretion in determining the contributions made by each spouse to 
  the marital estate).Â  
The estate also complains about various other 
  provisions of the court order relating to the marital home, including the value 
  placed on it by the court allowing a 7 percent reduction in its valuation in 
  the event Wife chose to buy Husbandâ€™s interest, in requiring a public auction 
  in the event the parties could not agree to sell the house on the open market, 
  and in making Wife responsible for any mortgage payment when there was none.Â  
  The appraisal the court accepted was the one prepared closest to the date of 
  the filing of the pleadings, and because a private sale would involve a real 
  estate commission, it was not erroneous for the court to authorize a reduction 
  in the appraisal by a reasonable real estate commission if Wife chose to buy 
  Husbandâ€™s interest.Â  The courtâ€™s order on these points was well within its discretion.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-476 (Supp. 2003) (â€œThe court in making an equitable apportionment 
  may order the public or private sale of all or any portion of marital property 
  upon terms it determines.â€).Â  
D.Â  Treatment of Other Assets
The estate asserts the family court erred 
  in identifying two units at Cotton Hope Plantation, a lot in Sun City, and Husbandâ€™s 
  Merrill Lynch and AmeriTrade accounts as marital assets.Â  We disagree.Â  
The estate initially argues Husband provided 
  almost all the funds for the purchase of the units in Cotton Hope Plantation 
  and the lot in Sun City.Â  However, these were assets acquired during the course 
  of the marriage and are therefore considered to be marital property which, by 
  definition, includes â€œall real and personal property which has been acquired 
  by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing 
  or commencement of marital litigation.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2003).Â  
  No question of transmutation exists with regard to these assets because they 
  were not owned by Husband prior to the marriage.Â  Additionally, there is considerable 
  credible evidence these assets were acquired with substantial funds of both 
  parties which were commingled.Â  Also, the AmeriTrade account was opened during 
  the course of the marriage and was funded by the Merrill Lynch account which, 
  as discussed below, was transmuted into marital property.Â  Consequently, it 
  is also a marital asset subject to apportionment by the family court.
Husband did open the Merrill Lynch account 
  prior to the marriage.Â  However, there was evidence that during the course of 
  the marriage Husband made several principal contributions from the partiesâ€™ 
  joint funds.Â  There was also testimony that Husband deposited monies from the 
  building account maintained by the parties for the marital residence into the 
  Merrill Lynch account.Â  Husband offered no record of deposits and disbursements 
  for this account.Â  We therefore conclude there was evidence of significant commingling 
  of marital funds unto this account and, as a result, the account was transmuted 
  into a marital asset subject to apportionment.Â  See Hussey v. Hussey, 
  280 S.C. 418, 423, 312 S.E.2d 267, 270 (Ct. App. 1984) (holding nonmarital property 
  can become transmuted into marital property when it becomes so commingled as 
  to be untraceable).Â  
II.Â  Transmutation 
  of Hinesville Apartments
The estate argues the family court erred 
  by holding the totality of Husbandâ€™s Hinesville Apartments had been transmuted 
  into marital property and by granting Wife a 30 percent equity interest therein.Â  
  We agree.
Husband acquired the Hinesville Apartments prior to 
  the marriage.Â  In December 1991, Wife borrowed $158,000 against her life insurance 
  policies and loaned the proceeds plus a check drawn on her Merrill Lynch account 
  for $7,750 to Husband.Â  Husband used the $165,750 to satisfy outstanding mortgages 
  only on quad lots 7 and 9.Â  Husband executed two $82,875 promissory notes with 
  mortgages on those two quads in favor of Wife as security for the loan.Â  Each 
  note had a variable rate calculated to be one percent above the rate paid by 
  Wife.Â  Husband claimed he paid down the notes to a balance of $81,587 as of 
  March 1, 2001 and was current with his payments.Â  At trial, Wife agreed Husband 
  was current with his payments at the time, but testified he had previously been 
  behind and late charges accrued increasing the total outstanding balance on 
  the notes to $97,485.26 as of December 6, 2002.Â  
Husband also executed a note for $203,000 secured 
  by the partiesâ€™ Hilton Head Island home and used $176,457.94 of the loan proceeds 
  to satisfy mortgages on quad lots 3, 4, 5, 6 and 8.Â  He deposited the remaining 
  amount into his Merrill Lynch securities account.Â  Husband repaid the entire 
  amount due under the note as of the date of the final hearing.Â  
Nonmarital property may be transmuted only if it 
  is utilized in support of the marriage, becomes so commingled as to be untraceable, 
  or is utilized in such a manner as to evidence intent to make it marital.Â  Wyatt 
  v. Wyatt, 293 S.C. 495, 497, 361 S.E.2d 777, 779 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  None 
  of these requirements exist with regard to Husbandâ€™s Hinesville properties.Â  
  Husband held the properties solely in his own name, and the income was paid 
  exclusively to him.Â  The funds utilized by Husband to pay the existing mortgages 
  were acquired in arms-length transactions evidenced by notes and secured by 
  mortgages.Â  The loan secured by a mortgage on the marital residence had been 
  fully repaid at the time of the final hearing.Â  Wifeâ€™s own testimony was to 
  the effect that she would not have loaned Husband the money to satisfy the existing 
  mortgage had she not received security for her loan.Â  The evidence is that Husband 
  made regular payments pursuant to the terms of the note.Â  There is no evidence 
  either party intended at the time of that transaction to transmute the apartments 
  into marital property.Â  We therefore reverse the portions of the family courtâ€™s 
  order holding the apartments have been transmuted and equitably dividing them.Â  
  We also reverse the portion of the order requiring sale of the properties and 
  forgiveness of the balance of the debt to Wife secured by the properties.Â  The 
  estate remains liable for the outstanding balance due on the note.Â  Because 
  the parties disagree as to the remaining balance, this issue is remanded to 
  the family court to determine the exact amount due.
III.Â  Alimony
The estate complains of numerous errors in 
  the family courtâ€™s order on the subject of alimony.Â  Most significantly, it 
  asserts the court erred by failing to order alimony payments to cease at Husbandâ€™s 
  death.Â  We agree this omission was error.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-3-130 (B)(1) (Supp. 2003) requires that periodic alimony terminate 
  â€œon the remarriage of the supported spouse or upon the death of either spouse.â€Â  
  As Husband has died, Wife is not entitled to any further alimony.
IV.Â  
  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
The estate 
  contends the family court erred by ordering Husband to contribute $20,000 towards 
  Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
The estate 
  argues that we should reverse the family courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees to 
  Wife if we conclude Husband is successful in his appeal.Â  The court will reverse 
  the award of attorneyâ€™s fees where the substantive results achieved by a partyâ€™s 
  counsel are reversed on appeal.Â  See, e.g., E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 
  307 S.C. 471, 477, 415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).Â  In this case, we affirm a majority 
  of the family courtâ€™s order and reverse only as to the transmutation and apportionment 
  of the Hinesville Apartments and require the termination of alimony in accordance 
  with statutory authority.Â  The remainder of the order accrues to the benefit 
  of Wife.Â  Accordingly, we find the award of fees to her was proper.
CONCLUSION
We reverse those portions of the family courtâ€™s order transmuting 
  and apportioning Husbandâ€™s Hinesville apartments, require his estate to satisfy 
  the remaining balance due on the notes on quads 7 and 9, and remand for the 
  court to determine the correct amount.Â  We also find Wife is no longer entitled 
  to alimony.Â  We affirm the family courtâ€™s order as to the remaining issues.
 AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND 
  REMANDED.Â  
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., 
  concur.



 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Husband died during the pendency of this appeal.Â  His son, 
    Mitchell Foy Dillman, was named personal representative of his estate.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Prior to the marriage, Husband acquired 7 individual quads 
    (freestanding rental units each containing four apartments) and five townhouses 
    (all located on a single lot) in Hinesville, Georgia.Â  The quads are identified 
    as lots 3 through 9, and the townhouses are identified collectively as lot 
    10.Â  

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Because both parties already had considerable assets they 
    entered into an agreement approximately one month before the marriage stating 
    their intentions that their respective children, rather than one another, 
    should receive their premarital holdings.Â  

 
   
    [4]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003).Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL
VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Sue B. Brigman,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Johnny M. Brigman, Laverne Brigman, Ray
Brigman, Percy W. Brigman, Flora 
        Ann Johnson, Katherine Cassidy, Roberta Holmerod, Janice Sakala and Jodie
Bethea,        Respondents.
Sue B. Brigman, Special Administrator of the Estate of
W.A. Brigman, 
        Jr.,        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Johnny M. Brigman,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
C. Anthony Harris, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-323
Submitted March 19, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  14, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles J. Hupfer, Jr., 
  John R. Chase and Benjamin T. Zeigler, all of Florence, for Appellant.
Florence Ann Johnson, of 
  Lexington;Â  Janice Sakala, of Beaverton, Oregon;Â  Jodie Bethea and Roberta Holmerud, 
  both of Bonita, California;Â  Katherine Casside, Laverne Brigman, Ray Brigman 
  and Percy W. Brigman, all of Latta, and Ralph L. Kelly, of Bennetsville, for 
  Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Sue Brigman appeals the ruling 
  of a special referee denying probate of the will of W.A. Brigman, her husband. 
  We affirm.
 
  FACTS
W. A. Brigman, Jr. (Testator) and Sue 
  B. Brigman (Appellant) were married in 1973. They lived on a farm in Marlboro 
  County, where Testator was a life-long farmer. The land and the farm had been 
  in the Brigman family for as many as 150 years. Testator executed a will in 
  1994, leaving Appellant a life estate (or until she remarried) in the farm and 
  the remainder to his nephew Johnny Brigman (Respondent) in fee simple. Testator 
  died on April 26, 1999. (R.30). 
Following Testatorâ€™s death, a will dated April 23, 1999 
  was offered for probate. That will left the farm and all of the farming equipment 
  to Appellant in fee simple. Respondent challenged the validity of the 1999 will. 
  The case was referred to a special referee in June 2001 and a hearing was held 
  on July 13 of that year.Â  
At the hearing, Kelly Childers, 
  [1]  the Brigmansâ€™ minister, and Nannie Williams, a health care worker, 
  testified for Appellant. They were the subscribing witnesses for the 1999 will. 
  According to them, Testator was alert and could speak on April 23, the date 
  of the willâ€™s execution. The two wills were allegedly read to Testator numerous 
  times and he was asked repeatedly if he understood and wanted the changes being 
  made. Each time, Testator said yes or nodded his head in agreement. Reverend 
  Childers testified Appellantâ€™s â€œhand was up against the back of [Testatorâ€™s] 
  hand to aid and give assistanceâ€ when the will was executed. Childers and Williams 
  testified that along with Appellant, Appellantâ€™s daughter and grand-daughter 
  were also in the home on that evening. [2]  Appellant, her daughter, and 
  her grand-daughter did not testify at the hearing. 
Laverne Brigman, Respondentâ€™s brother, also testified. 
  He claimed that he heard Testator say that Testator was â€œgoing to make some 
  changesâ€ on April 6, while Testator was in the hospital. Laverne Brigman also 
  testified that Testator was upset with Respondent because Respondent had brought 
  some â€œfarm papersâ€ to the hospital for Testator to sign. [3] 
Respondent testified on his own behalf. He claimed 
  that he visited Testator daily, except for April 10, when Appellant refused 
  him entry into the house. Respondent also said that he saw Testator on April 
  23, â€œlate in the after-noon.â€ Testator was by then â€œjust breathing . . . [h]is 
  eyes were set, he did not speak, he did not move, he did not talk, he did not 
  know [Respondent].â€ Respondent maintained that Testator had been in that condition 
  since April 11 until his death on April 26. Respondentâ€™s son Johnny Brigman 
  also took the witness stand. He corroborated his fatherâ€™s testimony that Appellant 
  had barred the two of them from visiting Testator on April 10. 
Another family member testified that Testator â€œwas 
  in mighty bad shapeâ€ in the days preceding his death. Testator â€œreally didnâ€™t 
  seem to be aware of what was going onâ€ and asked about a relative who had been 
  dead â€œa pretty good while.â€ There was also testimony from Annie Anderson. She 
  was a neighbor, a long-term friend of Testatorâ€™s family, and a retired registered 
  nurse. When she visited Testator in the after-noon of April 23, â€œ[his] eyes 
  were . . . glazed overâ€ and â€œ[h]e had no expression.â€ 
By an order of October 15, 2003, the special referee 
  found that â€œW. A. Brigman, Jr. was subjected to undue influence or duress to 
  execute the document offered for Probate as the Will of W. A. Brigman, Jr. dated 
  April 23, 1999.â€ He also found that Testator lacked any testamentary intent 
  and testamentary capacity. He denied probate. 
ISSUES

  
    Did the special referee err in finding that Testator
    was under undue influence or duress?
    
  
    Did the special referee err in finding that Testator
    lacked testamentary intent?
    
  
    Did the special referee err in finding that Testator
    lacked testamentary capacity?Â 

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe standard of review applicable to cases 
  originating in the probate court is controlled by whether the underlying cause 
  of action is at law or in equity.â€ In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 568, 544 
  S.E.2d 854, 856 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  An action to determine the validity of a will 
  is one at law. In re Estate of Weeks, 329 S.C. 251, 262, 495 S.E.2d 454, 
  460 (Ct. App. 1997). â€œâ€™If the proceeding in the probate court is in the nature 
  of an action at law, the [appellate] court may not disturb the probate courtâ€™s 
  findings of fact unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence 
  to support them.â€™â€ Macaulay v. Wachovia Bank of South Carolina, 
  N.A., 569 S.E.2d 371 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing Howard 
  v. Mutz, 315 S.C. 356, 361, 434 S.E.2d 254, 257 (1993)). â€œContestants of 
  a will have the burden of establishing undue influence, fraud, duress, mistake, 
  revocation, or lack of testamentary intent or capacity.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-407 
  (Supp. 1996). The contestant must do so by clear and convincing evidence. Russell 
  v. Wachovia Bank, N.A., 353 S.C. 208, 217, 578 S.E.2d 329, 333 (2003).
ANALYSIS
Appellant argues that the special referee erred when 
  he found that Testator executed the 1999 will under undue influence or duress. 
  We disagree.
â€œFor a will to be invalidated for undue influence, the influence 
  must be the kind of mental coercion which destroys the free agency of the creator 
  and constrains him to do things which are against his free will, and that he 
  would not have done if he had been left to his own judgment and volition.â€ Id. 
  â€œThe evidence must show that the free will of the testator was taken over by 
  someone acting on testator's behalf.â€ Id. In general, there should be 
  â€œevidence either of threats, force, and/or restricted visitation, or of an existing 
  fiduciary relationship.â€ Id.  
Here, Testator had been in very poor health since April 7, 
  when he suffered a second or third stroke. He was also recuperating from a heart 
  attack and was suffering from kidney failure. Testator â€œwas going down hill 
  fast.â€ The record does not indicate that Testator ever requested a change in 
  the 1994 will at all. It was Appellant who spearheaded the execution of the 
  1999 will, â€œaidingâ€ Testator to sign the will, choosing the subscribing witnesses, 
  telling them when to come.Â Â  Reverend Childers, who testified for Appellant, 
  admitted that, on the night in question, Testator â€œcould not sign and [Appellant] 
  took his hand and guided it to place his signature on the will.â€ When asked 
  whether Testator had indicated he wanted or needed assistance, Reverend Childers 
  answered â€œhe didnâ€™t ask her to [help him sign], if thatâ€™s what youâ€™re asking 
  me.â€ Compare S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-2-502 (1976) (â€œ[E]very will, shall be 
  in writing signed by the testator or in the testator's name by some other person 
  in the testator's presence and by his direction, and shall be signed 
  by at least two persons each of whom witnessed either the signing or the testator's 
  acknowledgment of the signature or of the will.â€) (emphasis added). 
The special referee also noted that the persons surrounding 
  Testator that night, namely Appellant, Reverend Childers, Appellantâ€™s daughter 
  and grand-daughter, and the health care worker, testified to reading the 1999 
  will three or four times to him. They did this at a time when Testator was â€œfull 
  of poison,â€ not having yet received his nightly dialysis treatment. While there 
  is no evidence of threats, witnesses testified that Appellant precluded them 
  from visiting Testator on at least one occasion. Moreover, Appellant was heard 
  saying â€œI changed his will.â€
Clearly, there was some evidence to indicate that Testator 
  had been coerced. Therefore, we cannot say that the special referee erred as 
  a matter of law in finding that Testator was under duress or undue influence.
Appellant also argues that the special referee erred in finding 
  that Testator had no testamentary intent or capacity. Again, we disagree.
In general, a testator has the capacity to make a will if 
  he knows (1) his estate, (2) the objects of his affection, and (3) to whom he 
  wishes to bequeath his property. In re Weeks, 329 S.C. at 263, 495 S.E.2d 
  at 461. And a testator who signs a will is presumed to understand its nature 
  and content. Henkel v. Winn, 346 S.C. 14, 18, 550 S.E.2d 577, 579 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).Â  As said earlier, it up to the party challenging the will to show 
  the contrary. Â§ 62-3-407.
At the hearing, there was testimony that Testator, starting 
  around April 11, did not respond to or recognize family members, that he was 
  unaware of his surroundings, that his eyes were â€œsetâ€ and â€œglazed.â€ On the specific 
  day that the 1999 will was executed, Testator had at least two visitors, Respondent 
  and Annie Anderson. They both testified that when they saw Testator in the after-noon, 
  he was non-responsive, â€œgone.â€ The subscribing witnesses offered a different 
  account. They testified that Testator was alert when the will was signed late 
  at night on April 23, that Appellant was told about the changes and approved 
  them. The special referee again found, however, that the will was signed when 
  Testator was in need of his dialysis treatment. We cannot say that the conclusion 
  was legal error. 
The special referee saw and considered all of the testimony. 
  He noted, as do we, that neither Appellant nor her daughter testified. Both 
  had played key roles in the signing of the 1999 will. The special referee also 
  noted that the farm had been in Testatorâ€™s family for numerous generations and 
  that Testator had been preoccupied with its long-term care. Respondent had spent 
  much time on the farm, both as a boy and as an adult; he had been like a â€œsonâ€ 
  to Testator. Testator had already told Respondent that the farm â€œwas coming 
  to [him].â€ Additionally, the special referee took into account Testatorâ€™s reputation. 
  Testator had always been â€œsteady and stable,â€ not one to â€œact on a whim . . 
  . when he wasnâ€™t in full control of his faculties.â€ 
The special referee could have discounted the testimony offered 
  by Respondent and Annie Anderson that Testator was already â€œgoneâ€ in the after-noon 
  of April 23, 1999. In the alternative, he could have found that Testator regained 
  alertness that evening â€“ just long enough to change his will and leave the family 
  farm to Appellant. He did neither. Instead, having seen and evaluated all of 
  the witnesses, the special referee discounted the testimony of Appellantâ€™s witnesses 
  and set aside the 1999 will. [4]  As the record provides some evidence for his 
  findings, we cannot say that he erred. Therefore, we affirm his ruling.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the decision of the special 
  referee is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ, concur.

 
   [1]  Childers married Appellant less than one month 
    before the probate hearing. 

 
   [2]  Appellant had children from a previous marriage, 
    but none with Testator.

 
   
    [3]  Testator apparently signed a power of attorney over to Respondent 
    on April 6, but it was rescinded the next day. Another power of attorney was 
    signed on April 10 in favor of Appellant and of Gary Crawford. Gary Crawford 
    was a friend of Appellantâ€™s daughter. Appellant used that power of attorney 
    to withdraw funds from Testatorâ€™s banking accounts that same day. 

 
   [4]  See Sauers v. Poulin Bros. Homes, 
    Inc., 328 S.C. 601, 605, 493 S.E.2d 503, 505 (Ct. App. 1997) 
    (holding that a finder of fact is free to disregard a witnessâ€™s testimony, 
    even if uncontradicted) (citation omitted).

PER CURIAM: Robert Cantrell appeals, arguing 
  the trial court erred by holding him in contempt of court for failing to take 
  a drug test within 10 days as required by court order.Â  We affirm.1 
LAW/ANALYSIS
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the 
  following authorities:Â  I. As to the contempt order: see Wilson v. 
  Walker, 340 S.C. 531, 537, 532 S.E.2d 19, 21-22 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting 
  that in an appeal from an order of the family court, this court has jurisdiction 
  to find facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence; however, 
  this court is not required to disregard the trial judgeâ€™s findings who saw and 
  heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility); 
  State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 
  1994) (â€œA determination of contempt ordinarily resides in the sound discretion 
  of the trial judge.â€).Â  II. As to the willfulness of Cantrellâ€™s actions: see 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1350 (Supp. 2003) (â€œAn adult who willfully violates, neglects, 
  or refuses to obey or perform a lawful order of the court . . . may be proceeded 
  against for contempt of court.â€); Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. at 129, 447 S.E.2d 
  at 217 (citing Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Social Servs. v. Padgett, 
  296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988)) (â€œA willful act is defined as 
  one â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something 
  the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law 
  requires to be done; that is to say with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard 
  the law.â€™ â€)Â  
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, HOWARD, and BEATTY, JJ., concur. 

 
  1

    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

  all of Columbia; and Solicitor William Townes Jones, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, 
  Craig L. Atchison, was charged with and convicted of first-degree burglary, 
  larceny, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  
  On appeal, Atchison asserts reversible error in the admission of evidence of 
  more than two previous burglary convictions to prove an element of first degree 
  burglary, as well as the failure of the trial judge to redact prior indictments 
  which were admitted to show the previous burglary convictions and included crimes 
  other than the burglaries.Â  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and 
  the following authorities:Â  State v. Keenon, 356 S.C. 457, 459, 590 S.E.2d 
  34, 36 (2003) (although the trial court committed clear error in admitting evidence 
  of all six of defandantâ€™s prior burglary/housebreaking convictions without first 
  weighing the prejudicial effect against the probative value, given the overwhelming 
  evidence of defandantâ€™s guilt the admission of more than two prior convictions 
  was harmless error); State v. Kilgore, 325 S.C. 188, 192, 480 S.E.2d 
  736, 738 (1997) (where evidence of guilt was overwhelming without any reference 
  to defendantâ€™s guilty plea to misprision of a felony, any error in admission 
  of guilty plea was harmless); State v. Parker, 315 S.C. 230, 235, 433 
  S.E.2d 831, 833 (1993) (the erroneous admission of prior bad acts evidence is 
  not reversible error where the evidence of guilt is overwhelming without any 
  reference to the evidence of the prior bad act); State v. Mitchell, 286 
  S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985) (error is harmless when it could not 
  reasonably have affected the result of the trial).
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of Andrew L. Williams,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Thomas W. Cooper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-330
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 17, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Andrew Johnson, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Deputy Attorney General Treva Ashworth, Assistant 
  Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe and Assistant Attorney General R. Westmoreland 
  Clarkson, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  On January 14, 2003, 
  a Richland County jury found the State had proven beyond a reasonable doubt 
  that Andrew L. Williams was a sexually violent predator as that term is defined 
  in the Sexually Violent Predator Act (the â€œActâ€). [1] Â  Williams appeals, arguing the 
  trial court erred in not finding the case barred by res judicata.Â  We affirm.Â Â Â  

FACTS
Williams has a history of committing sexually 
  violent offenses.Â  For instance, in 1995, the State filed a petition against 
  him for criminal sexual conduct with a minor. 
  [2] Â  Following a hearing, the court found Williams guilty on a lesser charge 
  of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature and sentenced him to 
  an indeterminate period in the South Carolina Department of Juvenile Justice.
While Williams was incarcerated at the 
  Department of Juvenile Justice, the State charged him with three acts of criminal 
  sexual conduct in the first degree. 
  [3] Â  Williams pled guilty to one count of criminal sexual conduct in the 
  first degree in exchange for the State dismissing the remaining charges.Â  Again, 
  the court committed Williams to the Department of Juvenile Justice for an indeterminate 
  period not to exceed his twenty-first birthday.Â  Williams remained at the Department 
  of Juvenile Justice until he reached the age of seventeen, at which time, he 
  was transferred to the Department of Corrections.
Williams attended sex offender treatment 
  during the time he was incarcerated at the Department of Corrections.Â  However, 
  the Department terminated him from the program for behavior problems, including 
  touching and striking a female employee.Â  Williams also committed other behavioral 
  offenses such as when he was given a sexual misconduct charge for masturbating 
  in front of a female officer.Â  
Despite these problems, Williams was paroled in 
  July 2000.Â  Two of the conditions of his parole were that he attend sex offender 
  treatment and stay away from drugs.Â  On September 6, 2000, the State filed a 
  petition pursuant to the Act to have Williams confined to a â€œsecure facility 
  for long term control, care, and treatment.â€Â  In an order dated September 28, 
  2000, Judge James R. Barber found there was probable cause to believe Williams 
  met the criteria of a sexually violent predator and ordered his detention pending 
  a probable cause hearing.
On April 9, 2001, following the probable cause 
  hearing pursuant to section 44-48-80 of the Act, Judge Alison R. Lee found the 
  State had â€œfailed to demonstrate that probable cause exist[ed] to find that 
  [Williams] is a sexually violent predator.â€Â  Subsequent to Judge Leeâ€™s probable 
  cause determination, Williams attended a parole hearing for failing to attend 
  the required sex offender treatment.Â  In August 2001, at a subsequent parole 
  hearing, Williams tested positive for marijuana and still had not completed 
  sex offender treatment.Â  Finally, in November 2001, Williamsâ€™ parole was revoked 
  for failing to comply with his parole conditions.
On May 24, 2002, relying in part on events 
  occurring after Judge Leeâ€™s probable cause determination, the State filed its 
  second petition to have Williams confined in a secure facility.Â  One of the 
  bases for this petition was Williamsâ€™ failure to attend the sex offender aftercare 
  treatment.Â  In an order dated June 14, 2002, and again on July 10, 2002, Judge 
  G. Thomas Cooper, Jr. found that probable cause existed to believe Williams 
  was a sexually violent predator as defined in the Act.Â  Thereafter, the matter 
  came to trial before Judge Thomas W. Cooper.Â  
Prior to the start of trial, the court heard Williamsâ€™ 
  summary judgment motion.Â  Williams argued the case was barred by the doctrine 
  of res judicata, relying on the April 9, 2001, probable cause determination.
The trial court denied Williamsâ€™ motion for summary 
  judgment holding that because the prior probable cause hearing was not â€œon the 
  merits,â€ the doctrine of res judicata did not apply.Â  Following this ruling, 
  the case proceeded to a jury trial, after which Williams was found to be a sexually 
  violent predator under the Act.Â  Pursuant to this jury finding, the trial court 
  committed Williams to the Department of Mental Health for long term treatment.Â  

ISSUE

Did the trial court err in holding that a determination of 
  a lack of probable cause in a prior action arising under the Act does not amount 
  to a judgment on the merits?

DISCUSSION
Williamsâ€™ sole argument 
  on appeal is that the trial court erred in not finding the second petition and 
  following action barred by the doctrine of res judicata. 
Under the doctrine of 
  res judicata, a final judgment on the merits in a prior action will act 
  to bar the parties and those in privity with them from initiating a second action 
  based on the same claim, to the extent the second claim relates to issues actually 
  litigated in the first action, or to issues which might have been litigated 
  in the first action.Â  Prince v. City of Georgetown, 297 S.C. 185, 189, 
  375 S.E.2d 335, 337 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œTo establish res judicata, the defendant 
  must prove three elements: (1) identity of the parties; (2) identity of the 
  subject matter; and (3) adjudication of the issue in the former suit.â€Â  Nelson 
  v. QHG of South Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 290, 304, 580 S.E.2d 171, 178 (Ct. 
  App. 2003) (citing Sealy v. Dodge, 289 S.C. 543, 347 S.E.2d 504 (1986) 
  (further citations omitted)).
Appellant argues the 
  prior probable cause hearing amounted to an adjudication on the merits as to 
  whether probable cause existed to believe Williams was a sexually violent predator.Â  
  Accordingly, Williams argues the second hearing should have been barred by res 
  judicata.Â  We disagree and find the trial court correctly held the action was 
  not barred.
Significantly, Appellant 
  cites no cases or other authority to support his contention that a probable 
  cause hearing amounts to a decision on the merits and we are not aware of any.Â  
  As such, we conclude a preliminary hearing for the purpose of determining probable 
  cause under section 44-48-80 of the South Carolina Code is not the equivalent 
  of an adjudication on the merits.Â  The very purpose of the probable cause hearing 
  under this section is to determine â€œwhether probable cause exists to believe 
  that the person is a sexually violent predator.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(B)(3) 
  (2002).Â  Moreover, section 44-48-90 provides that within sixty days of the hearing, 
  â€œthe court shall conduct a trial to determine whether the person is a sexually 
  violent predator.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-90 (2002).Â  Therefore, according 
  to the plain language of the Act, a probable cause hearing is by definition 
  not a hearing on the merits.Â  The purpose of the probable cause hearing is to 
  determine if sufficient evidence exists to bind the matter over for trial on 
  the merits, i.e., to adjudicate whether the person is indeed a sexually violent 
  predator under the Act. 
Williamsâ€™ argument further 
  fails to acknowledge that the present action includes additional facts concerning 
  his parole violations that occurred after the initial probable cause 
  determination.
CONCLUSION
We find the trial court correctly 
  held that this action was not barred by the doctrine of res judicata.Â  The decision 
  of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ.,Â  concur.



 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-48-10 â€“ 170 (2002 & Supp. 2003).

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The minors Williams was charged with assaulting were two eight-year-old 
    boys, both of whom were close relatives.

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Williams was accused of sexually assaulting a male roommate.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Debra Mathews and John Doe the unknown father of Letisha Mathews, and 
        Letisha Mathews DOB 4/19/93,        Defendants,
of whom Debra Mathews is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marion County
Mary E. Buchan, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-331
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 17, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mary Jaques Ryan, of Loris, for Appellant.
Timothy H. Pogue, of Marion, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  Debra Mathews appeals 
  the termination of her parental rights. [1] Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The South Carolina Department of Social 
  Services (â€œDSSâ€) commenced this action after taking emergency protective custody 
  of Letisha Mathews.Â  Letisha, a minor child born on April 19, 1993, suffers 
  from cerebral palsy.Â  Letisha has special needs, illustrated by the fact that 
  she walks with a limp, has a speech deficiency, and requires special medical 
  care.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On February 21, 2001, following a hearing 
  pursuant to section 20-7-610 of the South Carolina Code, the family court issued 
  an order granting DSS custody of Letisha.Â  The court based its ruling primarily 
  on the fact that on several occasions, no one was present to care for Letisha 
  when she returned home from school. [2] Â  The order also mentions that 
  Ms. Mathews was informed of her right to have an attorney and the procedure 
  by which she could have one appointed. 
On February 23, 2001, after a merits hearing 
  and pursuant to an agreement between the parties, the court affirmed its award 
  of custody to DSS, and ruled that a treatment plan presented to Ms. Mathews 
  by DSS was fair, equitable, and in the best interests of Letisha.Â  This order 
  reflects that prior to the hearing, Ms. Mathews was properly served with notice 
  of her right to counsel.Â  
The parties attended a permanency planning 
  hearing on January 29, 2002.Â  On February 8, 2002, the court issued an order 
  finding it would be in Letishaâ€™s best interest to remain in the custody of DSS, 
  that DSS should seek termination of Ms. Mathewsâ€™ parental rights, and that DSS 
  continue the treatment plan it presented at the merits hearing.Â  The order notes 
  that per her request, Ms. Mathews was allowed to represent herself.Â Â  
On April 3, 2002, DSS filed a complaint seeking 
  termination of Ms. Mathewsâ€™ parental rights.Â  The complaint alleged, among other 
  things, that Letisha had been removed from her home for at least six months 
  and Ms. Mathews had failed to remedy the conditions that caused her removal. 
  [3] Â  The parties met for a hearing on July 23, 2002. Â Deciding her rights 
  should be terminated, the family court relied in part on the testimony of Dr. 
  Neely, who performed psychological evaluations of Ms. Mathews.Â  In Dr. Neelyâ€™s 
  opinion, Ms. Mathews is unable to properly care for Letisha without having someone 
  present to provide assistance.Â  The court issued its order terminating Ms. Mathewsâ€™ 
  parental rights on September 4, 2002.Â  Ms. Mathews was represented by counsel 
  at the final hearing.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
ISSUES

  
    Did the family court err in ruling DSS proved by clear and convincing evidence 
  that Ms. Mathews failed to remedy the conditions leading up to the removal of 
  her child?
    
  
    Did the family court err in allowing Ms. Mathews to represent herself at all 
  hearings other than the final termination of parental rights hearing?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn a termination of parental rights 
  (TPR) case, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.â€Â  
  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 
  2003) (citing South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Smith, 343 S.C. 
  129, 133, 538 S.E.2d 285, 287 (Ct.App.2000)).Â  Before a parentâ€™s rights may 
  be terminated, the alleged grounds for termination must be proven by clear and 
  convincing evidence.Â  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Mrs. H, 346 S.C. 329, 333, 
  550 S.E.2d 898, 901 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
On appeal, this court may review the record 
  and make its own determination of whether the grounds for termination are supported 
  by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id.; see also South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 
  506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, despite this broad scope of review, this 
  court is not required to disregard the findings of the family court nor ignore 
  the fact that the trial judge was in a better position to evaluate the credibility 
  of the witnesses.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 
  324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Clear and Convincing Evidence
Ms. Mathews first argues the family court erred 
  in ordering termination of her parental rights because DSS failed to prove by 
  clear and convincing evidence that she failed to remedy the conditions leading 
  up to her childâ€™s removal.Â Â  Specifically, Ms. Mathews attacks the quality of 
  Dr. Joe Neelyâ€™s investigation and makes a concomitant allegation that certain 
  witnesses merely adopted the doctorâ€™s position.Â Â  The evidence in the record, 
  however, belies this argument.
Dr. Neely had an adequate opportunity 
  to examine Ms. Mathews and arrive at his conclusions.Â  The family court judge 
  assigned weight to Dr. Neelyâ€™s testimony, and we concur with this assessment.Â  
  In fact, Ms. Mathewsâ€™ objective living of life falls in line with his opinion 
  that she is a â€œvery impulsive woman who does not make really good decisions.â€Â  

Ms. Mathewsâ€™ lifestyle reflects 
  a pattern of placing her own interests above Letishaâ€™s interest.Â  In 1998, for 
  example, Ms. Mathews placed Letisha with some friends while she went on â€œvacationâ€ 
  with a truck driver.Â  Ms. Mathews informed her friends that she would return 
  for Letisha in a week.Â  After several weeks with no word from Ms. Mathews, these 
  friends notified DSS.Â  DSS took custody of Letisha.Â  Similarly, since Letisha 
  was first removed from Ms. Mathewsâ€™ home at the start of the current action, 
  Ms. Mathews has moved seven different times.Â  She also has had many different 
  boyfriends during this period. 
There are also Ms. Mathewsâ€™ repeated failures 
  to meet Letisha when she arrives home from school, or to make arrangements for 
  someone else to meet Letisha at the bus stop.Â  This resulted on many occasions 
  the school bus driver having to return Letisha to school.Â  In fact, the current 
  action began after the fifth such incident.Â  On another occasion, an earlier 
  investigation revealed that Donald Green, one of Ms. Mathewsâ€™ male friends and 
  the person supposedly taking care of Letisha, smelled of alcohol.Â  Although 
  the treatment plan proposed by DSS mandated that Ms. Mathews attend anger management 
  classes, she openly admitted she still has problems controlling her temper.Â Â Â  

Considering this history, there is more 
  than enough evidence in the record to support Dr. Neelyâ€™s testimony, and particularly 
  his opinion that if Letisha were returned to Ms. Mathews â€œthere should be an 
  extremely high level of supervision.â€Â  
 As for Ms. Mathewsâ€™ allegation that DSSâ€™s 
  other witnesses merely â€œrubber stampedâ€ Dr. Neelyâ€™s opinions, the record does 
  not support this contention.Â  It is clear from the record each of these witness 
  had an independent history of dealing with Ms. Mathews, and each had the opportunity 
  to arrive at their own conclusions regarding her fitness as a parent and, significantly, 
  the likelihood Ms. Mathews would remedy the conditions which necessitated removal.
For instance, Peggy Bryant testified to 
  much of the behavior outlined above.Â  She further testified to being present 
  at times when she felt Ms. Mathewsâ€™ behavior towards Letisha was inappropriate.Â  
  Finally, Ms. Bryant testified that DSS sought to terminate Ms. Mathewsâ€™ parental 
  rights based on her failure to rehabilitate.Â  According to Ms. Bryant, as of 
  January 2002, Ms. Mathews failed to complete a number of objectives outlined 
  in the treatment plan.Â  Of particular importance was Ms. Mathewsâ€™ failure to 
  understand the importance of providing appropriate supervision and stable housing 
  for Letisha.Â  Although Ms. Bryant did testify that DSS relied in part on Dr. 
  Neelyâ€™s opinion in making its determination that Ms. Mathews would be unable 
  to complete her rehabilitation, it is clear Ms. Bryant arrived at her own conclusions 
  regarding Ms. Mathewsâ€™ fitness as a parent.
Similarly, Mrs. Marley, the guardian ad 
  litem, testified about her experiences with Ms. Mathews.Â  Although Mrs. Marley 
  testified she agreed with Dr. Neelyâ€™s opinion that Ms. Mathews repeatedly makes 
  poor decisions, she provided specific examples which gave rise to her independent 
  conclusions.Â  Specifically, Mrs. Marley stated, â€œI have observed mom in many 
  different homes with different relationships.Â  And I â€“ and thatâ€™s my opinion.Â  
  It happens to be the doctorâ€™s.â€Â  As such, it is clear Mrs. Marley did not merely 
  adopt Dr. Neelyâ€™s opinion as her own.Â Â Â Â  
In an attempt to bolster her position 
  that the conditions leading up to removal of Letisha have been remedied, Ms. 
  Mathews mentions that her mother, Mrs. Robinson, agreed to move into her home 
  to provide Letisha with after-school care.Â  However, as DSS correctly points 
  out, this is not exactly a true assertion.Â  Mrs. Robinson testified that while 
  she would be willing to watch Letisha after school, she would not be able to 
  live with them because she had her â€œown home to run, too.â€Â Â Â  Mrs. Robinson 
  also testified that Ms. Mathews never asks for her help when there is a man 
  in her house.Â  The limitations Mrs. Robinson places on her ability to care for 
  Letisha are significant when one considers Ms. Mathewsâ€™ history of frequent 
  moves and her habit of dating a number of men for short periods of time.Â  
Because we find the evidence supports 
  the family courtâ€™s findings, findings with which we concur, we conclude DSS 
  established that Ms. Mathewsâ€™ parental rights should be terminated by clear 
  and convincing evidence.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Counsel
Ms. Mathews argues on appeal that the 
  family court erred in allowing her to represent herself at all hearings other 
  than the final termination of parental rights hearing.Â  As an initial matter, 
  this issue was not properly preserved for our review.Â  From the record it does 
  not appear any challenges were made to the family court raising this issue.Â  
  At the very least, there was no specific assignment of error, although the record 
  does contain testimony related to the absence of an attorney.Â  
In addition, the family courtâ€™s final order is 
  completely silent as to this issue.Â  If it were an issue as Ms. Mathews now 
  asserts, appellate preservation rules would have required a Rule 59(e), SCRCP 
  motion.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 
  731, 733 (1998) (stating that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on 
  appeal, the issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court).Â  
  In this case, such a motion was not made.Â  Therefore, technically this argument 
  is not preserved for our review.
However, because we understand the importance 
  of thoroughly reviewing matters where termination of parental rights is at stake, 
  we have examined this alleged point of error even though it was not properly 
  preserved.Â  See Joiner ex rel. Rivas v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 107, 
  536 S.E.2d 372, 374 (2000) (holding that it is not error to rule on an issue 
  raised to but not ruled on by the family court because â€œprocedural rules are 
  subservient to the courtâ€™s duty to zealously guard the rights of minorsâ€).
Ms. Mathews would have us assign weight to the 
  absence of an attorney in all hearings other than the final termination of parental 
  rights hearing.Â  This position is heightened by an effort on appeal to cast 
  herself in a more deficient light mentally than the record actually supports.Â  
  Ms. Mathews, in this court, seeks to draw an inconsistency between Dr. Neelyâ€™s 
  opinion that she possesses a â€œborderline to low average range intelligence,â€ 
  and the trial courtâ€™s determination that she was able to waive her right to 
  counsel and represent herself.Â  We find no reversible error.
While we do have concerns with Ms. Mathewsâ€™ mental 
  state, it is clear from the record she is able to function in society.Â  It may 
  be true that she does function in the low to average range of intelligence, 
  but this alone is not dispositive of the question before us.Â  Many good parents 
  fall within this category and are still able to care for their children.Â  
Our review convinces us that Ms. Mathews possesses 
  the necessary level of mental functioning to competently waive her right to 
  counsel and should she choose to, act as a fit parent.Â  However, we agree 
  with the family court and arrive at the conclusion that Ms. Mathewsâ€™ parental 
  rights were properly terminated.Â  This determination does not arise from her 
  purported deficient mental status, but from the lack of stability in her life 
  and her consistent pattern of exercising poor judgment as far as the care of 
  her daughter is concerned.Â  
As noted previously, Ms. Mathews has a history 
  of following her own interests in lieu of Letishaâ€™s.Â  In 1998, DSS exercised 
  protective custody of Letisha after Ms. Mathews failed to return from a vacation.Â Â  
  On five occasions, Ms. Mathews has failed to ensure someone was home to care 
  for Letisha after school.Â  Although she asserts her mother will move in to help 
  her take care of Letisha, her mother admits she has her own house to run and 
  Ms. Mathews does not ask for help when there is a man in her life.Â  To this 
  end, Ms. Mathews has a history of dating men, but not for significant periods 
  of time.Â  She has moved seven times since the current action began.Â  Ms. Mathews 
  has repeatedly made poor decisions and admits she does not always think before 
  she acts.Â  She also admitted to having problems controlling her temper.Â  
It is the type of behavior outlined above which 
  triggered the treatment plans promulgated by DSS.Â  It is also clear from the 
  record she had the ability to comply with the plans, as she did in part.Â  However, 
  it is the cumulative effect of this history that persuades us of the correctness 
  of the trial courtâ€™s ruling and that termination of Ms. Mathewsâ€™ parental rights 
  is in Letishaâ€™s best interest.Â  
CONCLUSION
The family courtâ€™s decision to terminate the parental rights of Ms. 
  Mathews is
 AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., 
  concur.Â  

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Although the case originally included John Doe, Letishaâ€™s 
    unknown father, only Ms. Mathews appeals from the family courtâ€™s ruling.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Specifically, the order states the complained of incident 
    was the fifth time Letisha returned home during the school year without proper 
    supervision.Â  

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(2) (Supp. 2003).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Gerald T. Hatcher and Martha Jean
Hatcher,        Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Tammy S. Hornsby Moore, and Skylar
Hatcher, a minor under the age of 
        fourteen (14) years,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Peter R. Nuessle, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-332
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 17, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas P. Murphy, of N. Augusta, for Appellants.
Amanda Frances Whittle, of Aiken, for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  In this termination of parental 
  rights case, Gerald T. Hatcher and Martha Jean Hatcher appeal from an order 
  of the family court denying their complaint to terminate the parental rights 
  of Tammy S. Hornsby Moore to her minor son, Skylar Hatcher.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Tammy Moore is the mother of Skylar Hatcher, 
  born January 13, 1997.Â  Skylar lived with his mother in Aiken County until he 
  was about one and a half years old.Â  Then, in June 1998, Moore asked the Hatchers, 
  Skylarâ€™s paternal grandparents, to care for Skylar.Â  Immediately after placing 
  Skylar with the Hatchers, Moore was arrested for failing to appear in court 
  on a matter unrelated to the instant case.Â  
After her June 1998 arrest, Mooreâ€™s contact with 
  and support for her son was limited.Â  At Mooreâ€™s request, the Hatchers retained 
  primary physical custody of Skylar.Â  Shortly after her arrest, Moore sent the 
  Hatchers a personal check for fifty dollars.Â  A few weeks later, Mike Hornsby, 
  a friend of Mooreâ€™s and the father of her other child, sent an additional check 
  for fifty dollars to the Hatchers for Skylarâ€™s support.Â  
In August 1998, Moore was involved in a serious 
  car accident in which the passenger in the car she was driving was killed.Â  
  Moore was charged with and pled guilty to involuntary manslaughter and was ultimately 
  sentenced to five years imprisonment.Â  
After the accident, Moore was admitted to a drug 
  treatment facility as mandated by a previous court order.Â  She was released 
  approximately one month later.Â  Following her release, Moore moved toÂ  Seneca, 
  South Carolina, to live with her parents.Â  Â Â 
Moore testified she would occasionally visit Skylar 
  during the following months by â€œsneaking upâ€ to see him with the help of Skylarâ€™s 
  father, Trent Hatcher.Â  Moore also claimed she left Christmas presents for Skylar 
  at the Hatchersâ€™ home in December 1998.Â  She returned to Aiken full-time in 
  July 1999 and lived with Trent in a trailer adjacent to the Hatchersâ€™ home.Â  
  Moore moved out approximately one month later.Â Â  Throughout this time, Moore 
  testified she was unemployed and unable to provide any additional financial 
  support for Skylar.Â  
Moore last saw Skylar on October 31, 1999.Â  The 
  next day she began serving her five-year prison sentence for the August 1998 
  involuntary manslaughter conviction.Â  
While she was in prison, Moore attempted to maintain 
  involvement with Skylar and the Hatchers.Â  Though she earned no money in prison, 
  she sent letters and holiday cards to Skylar along with letters to the Hatchers 
  asking how her son was doing and thanking them for their help raising Skylar 
  while she was away.Â  Moore also requested that the Hatchers bring Skylar to 
  visit her in prison.Â  They refused to do so.Â  
The Hatchers brought this action in May 2000, seeking 
  to terminate Mooreâ€™s parental rights to Skylar, alleging she had willfully failed 
  to visit or support Skylar during the time the child had been in their custody.Â  
  The family court denied the Hatchersâ€™ request, finding they failed to establish 
  sufficient grounds to terminate Mooreâ€™s parental rights. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Grounds for termination of parental rights 
  must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 
  334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999).Â  On appeal of a termination of 
  parental rights case, this court may review the entire record to make a determination 
  of the facts according to our view of the evidence.Â  Richland County Depâ€™t 
  of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1998). Our 
  broad scope of review, however, does not require us to disregard the findings 
  of the family court below or ignore the fact the trial judge was in a better 
  position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. 
  App. 2001). 
DISCUSSION
The Hatchers argue the family court erred 
  in denying their request to terminate Mooreâ€™s parental rights to Skylar, because 
  they assert the evidence clearly demonstrates Moore failed to support and visit 
  Skylar.Â  We disagree.
Termination of parental rights is governed 
  by South Carolina Code section 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2003).Â  This statute provides 
  that the family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding 
  of one or more of the enumerated grounds.Â Â  In this case, the Hatchers sought 
  to terminate Mooreâ€™s parental rights to Skylar pursuant to subsections (3) and 
  (4) of the statute, which provide for termination if:

(3) The child has lived outside 
  the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the 
  parent has wilfully failed to visit the child. The court may attach little 
  or no weight to incidental visitations, but it must be shown that the parent 
  was not prevented from visiting by the party having custody or by court order.Â  
  The distance of the childâ€™s placement from the parentâ€™s home must be taken into 
  consideration when determining the ability to visit;
(4) The child has lived outside 
  the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the 
  parent has wilfully failed to support the child.Â  Failure to support 
  means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s 
  care.Â  A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according 
  to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other 
  necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.Â  The 
  court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not 
  the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including requests for 
  support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support; 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1752(3) & (4) (Supp. 2003) 
  (emphasis added).
Whether a parentâ€™s failure to visit or 
  support a child is willful under section 20-7-1752 is a question of intent to 
  be determined by the facts and circumstances of each case. Â South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 610, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 
  (2003).Â  Our supreme court has held â€œ[c]onduct of the parent which evinces a 
  settled purpose to forego parental duties may fairly be characterized as â€˜willfulâ€™ 
  because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to 
  receive support and consortium from the parent.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of 
  Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 835, 839 (1992).Â  The 
  element of willfulness must be established by clear and convincing evidence.Â  
  Id. at 52, 413 S.E.2d at 838.
Based on our review of the record, we 
  do not find there is clear and convincing evidence to show Moore willfully failed 
  to visit or support Skylar.Â  Mooreâ€™s testimony, which we find largely credible, 
  reveals she made numerous attempts to visit Skylar prior to her incarceration, 
  doing so discreetly when she felt she would not be welcome in the Hatchersâ€™ 
  home. We also note the period of time Moore lived adjacent to the Hatchers in 
  the summer of 1999.Â  Mooreâ€™s credible testimony indicates she took advantage 
  of that opportunity to spend time with Skylar.Â  Mooreâ€™s imprisonment did not 
  end her desire to see her son.Â  The Hatchers admitted that Moore asked them, 
  on more than one occasion, to bring Skylar to the prison for a visit.Â  The Hatchers 
  refused these requests.Â  It was also admitted that Moore tried to maintain contact 
  and involvement with Skylar from prison by way of regular cards and letters 
  to Skylar and the Hatchers.
On the question of Mooreâ€™s support for 
  Skylar, we find her lack of support in this case does not rise to the level 
  warranting termination of parental rights.Â  To be sure, Moore provided very 
  little in the form of pure financial support.Â  We cannot say, however, that 
  Moore evidenced a desire to completely forgo her duty to support Skylar.Â  The 
  gifts she provided Skylar, along with the time spent with Skylar in summer 1999, 
  indicate some commitment on the part of Moore to contribute to Skylarâ€™s care.Â  

We are additionally mindful of the instruction 
  in section 20-7-1572(4) that the court must evaluate the support Moore provided 
  according to her means.Â  As noted above, Moore was unemployed in the year prior 
  to her imprisonment.Â  Though she had received some money from the sale of real 
  estate, Moore testified that a substantial portion of this money had to be used 
  to pay off an existing debt.Â  While in prison, Moore earned no money.Â  We, like 
  the family court judge, afford greater weight to the contributions Moore did 
  make to the care of Skylar in light of her very limited financial means.Â Â  
In reaching this decision, we do not intend to 
  gloss over the plain fact that Mooreâ€™s poor decisions in her life have had a 
  negative impact on her ability to meet her obligations as a parent to Skylar.Â  
  Poor decisions, however, do not necessarily signal an intent to forgo all parental 
  rights:

The fundamental liberty interest 
  of natural parents in the care, custody, and management of their child does 
  not evaporate simply because they have not been model parents or have lost temporary 
  custody of their child to the State.Â  Even when blood relationships are strained, 
  parents retain a vital interest in preventing the irretrievable destruction 
  of their family life.

Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 753 (1982) 
  (Stevens, J., dissenting).
Moore does not claim she has been a model parent.Â  
  The record reveals she has acknowledged her mistakes, and she has consistently 
  expressed appreciation for the Hatchersâ€™ important role in raising Skylar.Â  
  In our firm judgment, Mooreâ€™s efforts to maintain involvement in Skylarâ€™s life 
  before and after her incarceration, though far from ideal, warrant a finding 
  that she has not evinced a settled purpose to forgo her parental duties.Â  
Overall, we concur with the family courtâ€™s determination 
  that the Hatchers have not established by clear and convincing evidence that 
  Moore wilfully failed to visit and support Skylar under the standard of section 
  20-7-1752.Â  The order of the family court denying the Hatchersâ€™ complaint for 
  termination of Mooreâ€™s parental rights is therefore
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â  
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â
