THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Nationwide Insurance Company,       
Respondent.
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Barbara Smith, David Smith and Donald M. Brandt, Defendants,
of whom Barbara Smith and David Smith are,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Bamberg County
James D. Bailey, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-333
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 17, 
  2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
James B. Jackson, Jr., of Orangeburg, for Appellants.
Darra J. Vallini, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  David and Barbara Smith appeal 
  from the special refereeâ€™s order granting Nationwide Insurance Companyâ€™s motion 
  for summary judgment.Â  We reverse.
 FACTS
AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
   On August 25, 1999, David Smith drove 
    his employerâ€™s log truck, a 1988 Kenworth Tractor, to Georgia on company business.Â  
    While in Georgia, the truck experienced mechanical problems and Smith called 
    Donald Brandt, whom Smith then believed was his employer, for assistance.Â  
    Brandt arrived at the scene driving his personal vehicle.Â  He decided to tow 
    the log truck behind his vehicle and drive back to South Carolina.Â  Smith 
    steered the disabled log truck while it was being towed.Â  During the tow of 
    the log truck, two tires on Brandtâ€™s vehicle â€œblew out,â€ forcing both vehicles 
    off the road and down a hillside.Â  Smith was injured as a result of this accident.
  On the date of the accident, Smith believed Brandt 
    was his employer.Â  Smith subsequently learned of Brandtâ€™s purported transfer 
    of the 1988 Kenworth Tractor to his daughter, Chastity Connelly, on August 
    1, 1999, under the name Connelly Specialty Post Poles and Lumber.Â  Brandtâ€™s 
    attempted transfer to his daughter of ownership of his company assets, including 
    the log truck, was part of his apparent efforts to defraud a judgment creditor.Â  
    On July, 12, 1999, a judgment in excess of one million dollars was entered 
    in Bamberg County against Brandt. 
    [1] 
  While a bill of sale was executed transferring 
    the Kenworth Tractor to Chastity and her company, 
    [2]  Connelly Specialty Post Poles and Lumber, neither the bill of sale 
    nor the certificate of title were filed with the South Carolina Department 
    of Public Safety. [3] Â  Moreover, 
    prior to the one million dollar judgment, there had never â€œbeen any discussion 
    by [Brandt] to [Chastity] or by [Chastity] to [Brandt] that she was going 
    to get into any transportation business.â€ Â Nevertheless, Chastity claimed 
    to be Smithâ€™s employer on the day of the accident, August 25, and only 
    on that day.Â  Not knowing whether Brandt or Chastity was his true employer 
    on August 25, Smith named both Brandt and Chastity in his workerâ€™s compensation 
    claim.Â  That claim was settled, with contributions from both Brandtâ€™s and 
    Chastityâ€™s respective companies, prior to the issuance of a final decision 
    by the Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission.Â  The orders approving the settlement 
    agreements refer to Brandt as the â€œalleged employerâ€ and Chastity as the â€œemployer.â€
  Smith and his wife subsequently filed a negligence 
    action against Brandt.Â  Brandtâ€™s personal vehicle was covered by a Nationwide 
    insurance policy.Â  Nationwide filed a declaratory judgment action, seeking 
    a determination that it owed no duty to insure Brandt.Â  Specifically, Nationwide 
    argued against coverage because it claimed Smith was employed by Brandt at 
    the time of the accident, and Brandtâ€™s policy specifically excluded employees 
    from coverage.Â  The matter was referred to a special referee.Â  Nationwide 
    filed a motion for summary judgment based primarily upon depositions taken 
    in the workerâ€™s compensation action.Â  The special referee granted the motion, 
    finding Brandt was Smithâ€™s employer on August 25, 1999, as a matter of law.Â  
    The Smiths appeal.
   STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
    Summary judgment is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, 
      depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together 
      with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any 
      material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter 
      of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Tupper v. Dorchester 
      County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997); Wells v. City 
      of Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 301, 501 S.E.2d 746, 749 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
      In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies 
      the same standard which governs the circuit court: summary judgment is proper 
      when â€œthere is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving 
      party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP; 
      Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 
      537, 545 (1991).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, 
      the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence 
      must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Strother 
      v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 S.E.2d 117, 
      121 (1998).
     DISCUSSION
      The Smiths argue the special 
        referee erred in granting Nationwideâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We 
        agree.
        The relevant section of the Nationwide 
          policy on Brandtâ€™s personal vehicle excludes coverage for â€œinjury to 
          an employee of any insured while engaged in employment.â€
        We find that, based upon the pleadings, 
          exhibits, and deposition testimony in this case, the special referee 
          erred in granting Nationwideâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  In granting 
          summary judgment the special referee improperly assigned credibility 
          to Smithâ€™s initial belief that he was employed by Brandt on August 25. [4] Â  The special referee ignored 
          the appropriate summary judgment standard in â€œfind[ing] Mr. Smithâ€™s 
          testimony is more credible than that offered by Mr. Brandt and Mr. Brandtâ€™s 
          daughter, Chastity.â€Â  See Heirs v. Mullens, 310 S.C. 63, 
          68, 425 S.E.2d 57, 60 (Ct. App. 1992) (stating â€œmatters of credibility 
          should not be determined at the summary judgment stage.â€).Â  The special 
          referee further ignored the following deposition testimony of Brandt 
          and Chastity, respectively:

  
  
    
      Q:
       On the date 
          of this accident, August 25, 1999, who was Mr. Smith working for?
    
    
       A[by Brandt]:Â 
       On the day of the 
          accident?
    
    
      Q:
       Yes, sir.
    
    
      A:
       Who was he 
          working for?
    
    
      Q:
       Yes, sir.
    
    
      A:
       He was working 
          for Connelly Post Specialty.
    
    
      ...
      
    
    
      Q:
       Do you know 
          of any documents or personnel files â€¦ to a Mr. Smith?
    
    
       A[by Chastity]:
       No.Â  He only was 
          employed for one day.
    
    
      Q:
       All right.Â  
          And what day was that?
    
    
      A:
      August the 
          25th, 1999.
    
  
  

        The special referee inexplicably determined 
          that this record yielded but one conclusion, that is, Brandt was David 
          Smithâ€™s employer on August 25, 1999.Â  Viewing the facts and inferences 
          in a light most favorable to the Smiths, this record, at a minimum, 
          creates a genuine issue of material fact as to whether Brandt or Chastity 
          was David Smithâ€™s employer on August 25, rendering summary judgment 
          inappropriate.
        CONCLUSION
        The special refereeâ€™s order granting Nationwideâ€™s 
          motion for summary judgment is
         REVERSED.
        ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.
      
        

       
         
          [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Chastity understood her fatherâ€™s reason for the transfer 
          to her of his business interests: â€œ[W]ell, the end of July, we decided 
          that we were going to switch my fatherâ€™s truck into my name and I was 
          going to buy the truck from him due to a huge lawsuit against him in 
          July of â€™99â€¦actually, my father asked me about the truck due to his 
          lawsuit.Â  That was the whole reason weâ€”he wanted to get it out of his 
          nameâ€¦.â€
      
       
         
           
          [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The term â€œcompanyâ€ is used loosely, for Chastity produced 
          little in terms of business records at her deposition in response to 
          Smithâ€™s subpoena.
      
       
         
          [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The bill of sale reflected a payment of $10,500.Â  It 
          is admitted, however, that no payment was ever made or intended.Â  Brandt 
          maintained insurance on the log truck after the August 1 â€œpurchase.â€
      
       
         
           
          [4]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  As noted, Smith was initially unaware of the purported 
          transfer of the Kenworth Tractor from Brandt to Chastity.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jose and Cynthia Hernandez,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Town of Mt. Pleasant Board of Zoning Appeals & Mark Sargeant in his 
        official capacity as zoning administrator,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-334
Heard April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed May 17, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas R. Goldstein, of Charleston, for Appellants.
R. Allen Young, of Mt. Pleasant; and Frances Isaac Cantwell, 
  of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:  Â Jose Hernandez and Cynthia 
  Hernandez appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the denial of a zoning 
  variance by the Mt. Pleasant Board of Zoning Appeals and dismissing their claims 
  for violation of their rights to due process and equal protection.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The Hernandezes own a 7.7-acre lot in 
  a subdivision in Mt. Pleasant.Â  Originally, the unified lot extended from frontage 
  on Bampfield Drive to frontage on Coinbow Drive, with a lake in the middle of 
  the parcel.Â  Now, however, because the Hernandezes sold highland around the 
  perimeter of the lake to adjoining property owners, the lake bisects the Hernandezesâ€™ 
  lot, separating the highland fronting Coinbow Drive from the highland fronting 
  Bampfield Drive.Â  The Herndandezesâ€™ home is on the Coinbow Drive side of the 
  parcel of land.Â  They decided to subdivide the parcel and create a new lot on 
  the Bampfield Drive side of the lake.Â  
The new lot is a roughly triangular shaped highland 
  by the lake with a 25 feet by 172 feet corridor leading to Bampfield Drive.Â  
  Under the townâ€™s zoning ordinances, the lot is classified as a flag lot.Â  Neither 
  party disputed this classification during the hearing before the circuit court.Â  
  A flag lot is one failing to meet the minimum lot width for the applicable zoning 
  district, as measured at the front setback building line.Â  The new lot would 
  be 25 feet wide at the setback line as opposed to the required 80 feet for the 
  zoning district.Â  
The Hernandezes applied for a variance from the 
  ordinance to allow them to create the new lot.Â  At the hearing before the Board 
  of Zoning Appeals, the neighboring property owners objected to the granting 
  of the variance.Â  The Board denied the variance request, finding the proposed 
  lot to be a detriment to the surrounding property values.Â  
The Hernandezes then appealed the Boardâ€™s decision 
  to the circuit court, challenging the merits of the decision, the constitutionality 
  of the procedure for hearing variance requests, and the constitutionality of 
  the ordinance banning flag lots and asserting a takings claim.Â  The circuit 
  court held the Board of Zoning Appeals committed no error of law in hearing 
  or processing their variance application.Â  It found ample evidence in the record 
  to support the Boardâ€™s denial of the variance.Â  The court found no merit to 
  the Hernandezesâ€™ contention that they were denied procedural and substantive 
  due process.Â  The court also rejected their argument that the Town zoning regulations 
  that exclude flag lots are unconstitutional.Â  The court held the new lot was 
  not entitled to grandfathered status.Â  Finally, in its amended order, the court 
  held the Hernandezesâ€™ takings issue was premature and dismissed it without prejudice.Â  
  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in affirming 
  the decision of the Board.Â  We disagree.

  I.       Denial of variance

The South Carolina Local Government Comprehensive 
  Planning Enabling Act (Zoning Enabling Act) sets forth the standard of review 
  for appeals from local zoning boards of appeal:Â  â€œThe findings of fact by the 
  board of appeals must be treated in the same manner as a finding of fact by 
  a jury.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-840 (2004).Â  â€œIn determining the questions presented 
  by the appeal, the court must determine only whether the decision of the board 
  is correct as a matter of law.â€Â  Id.Â  Thus, the factual findings of the 
  zoning board will not be disturbed unless there is no evidence in the record 
  to support its decision.Â  Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals for the City of 
  Beaufort, 346 S.C. 401, 406, 552 S.E.2d 42, 45Â  (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
The Zoning Enabling Act empowers the Board 
  â€œto hear and decide appeals for variance from the requirements of the zoning 
  ordinance when strict application of the provisions of the ordinance would result 
  in unnecessary hardship.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-800(2) (2004).Â  The Board may 
  grant such a variance upon making and explaining in writing the following factors:

(a) there are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining 
  to the particular piece of property;
(b) these conditions do not generally apply to other property 
  in the vicinity;
(c) because of these conditions, the application of the ordinance 
  to the particular piece of property would effectively prohibit or unreasonably 
  restrict the utilization of the property; and
(d) the authorization of a variance will not be of substantial 
  detriment to adjacent property or to the public good, and the character of the 
  district will not be harmed by the granting of the variance.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-800(2) (2004).Â  
In order to grant a variance, the Board must make 
  the factual determination that each of these four elements favors granting the 
  variance. Restaurant Row Assocs. v. Horry County, 335 S.C. 209, 215, 
  516 S.E.2d 442, 445 (1999).Â  â€œGranting a variance is an exceptional power which 
  should be sparingly exercised and can be validly used only where a situation 
  falls fully within the specified conditions.â€Â  Id. at 215, 516 S.E.2d 
  at 445-46. The party seeking the variance bears the burden of demonstrating 
  all four of the above elements.Â  Id. at 216, 516 S.E.2d at 446.Â  
In the present case, the Board held that although 
  the Hernandezes had met the first three elements of a variance, they had not 
  met their burden of establishing that the variance would not be a substantial 
  detriment to adjacent property or to the public good and the character of the 
  district would not be harmed by the granting of the variance.
The Hernandezes assert the Board erred in considering 
  the objections of the neighboring property owners. 
  [1] Â  We find no error in the Boardâ€™s consideration of this testimony.Â  
  Section 6-29-800(2) requires the Board to determine whether the authorization 
  of a variance will be detrimental to adjacent property.Â  Accordingly, the neighborsâ€™ 
  testimony concerning the negative effect the granting of the variance would 
  have on their property values and the character of the district was relevant 
  to the Boardâ€™s consideration of this fourth element and was entitled to as much 
  weight as the Board deemed to accord it.Â  
Considering the entire record, we find 
  sufficient evidence to support the Boardâ€™s decision to deny the variance.Â  Testimony 
  from the adjacent property owners revealed concerns for drainage, overcrowding, 
  the loss of a substantial number of large trees, removal of yard debris, and 
  a negative effect on property values should the new lot be approved.Â  Accordingly, 
  we hold the circuit court correctly affirmed the Boardâ€™s decision as evidence 
  exists in the record supporting the Boardâ€™s decision.

  II.        Violation of rights to due process and equal protection

The Hernandezes argue the proceedings below violated 
  their rights to due process and equal protection.Â  At oral argument, the Hernandezesâ€™ 
  counsel stated the Hernandezes were abandoning their challenges to the constitutionality 
  of the Zoning Enabling Act and the municipal ordinance banning flag lots and 
  proceeding only on their arguments that their rights were violated by the application 
  of the statute and ordinance in their case.Â  
â€œThe fundamental requirement of due process is 
  the opportunity to be heard at a meaningful time and in a meaningful manner.â€ 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Beeks, 325 S.C. 243, 246, 481 
  S.E.2d 703, 705 (1997).Â  â€œDue process is flexible and calls for such procedural 
  protections as the particular situation demands.â€Â  Stono River Envtl. Protection 
  Assâ€™n v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 305 S.C. 90, 
  94, 406 S.E.2d 340, 342 (1991).Â  The requirements of due process include notice, 
  an opportunity to be heard in a meaningful way, and judicial review.Â  German 
  Evangelical Lutheran Church of Charleston v. City of Charleston, 352 S.C. 
  600, 608, 576 S.E.2d 150, 154 (2003).
The Zoning Enabling Act sets forth the procedure 
  for a hearing before theÂ  Zoning Board of Appeals on a zoning variance request.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 6-29-800 (2004).Â  An appeal from the Boardâ€™s decision is to 
  the circuit court, which has appellate jurisdiction only.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 
  6-29-820 and 6-29-840 (2004).Â  The circuit court may not take additional evidence.Â  
  Â§ 6-29-840.Â  
The Hernandezes contend the hearing before the 
  Board was unfair.Â  We disagree.Â  
The Hernandezes were provided with an opportunity 
  to be heard in a meaningful manner.Â  They were allowed to present their position 
  to the Board.Â  Furthermore, as found above, the Board did not err in allowing 
  the neighboring property owners to voice their objections to the variance request 
  as their concerns were relevant to the Boardâ€™s determination of whether the 
  request met all of the statutory factors necessary for the granting of a variance.Â  
  The Hernandezes were also afforded judicial review by their appeal to the circuit 
  court.Â  We hold the Hernandezes received all of the procedural protections afforded 
  them under the Zoning Enabling Act.
The Hernandezes also raise another due process 
  issue by asserting that as the Hobcaw subdivision plat was approved prior to 
  the enactment of the flag lot ordinance, the ordinance should not be allowed 
  to deprive them of all economic use of the land. 
  [2] 
A landowner only acquires a vested right to continue 
  a nonconforming use if that use is already in existence at the time his property 
  is zoned.Â  Friarsgate, Inc. v. Town of Irmo, 290 S.C. 266, 269-70, 349 
  S.E.2d 891, 893 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  â€œ[A] contemplated use of property by a landowner 
  on the date a zoning ordinance becomes effective to preclude such a use is not 
  protected as a nonconforming use.â€Â  Id. Â at 269, 349 S.E.2d at 893. 
At the time the Town of Mt. Pleasant enacted the 
  ordinance prohibiting flag lots, the Hernandezesâ€™ property was considered one 
  lot and was in conformance with the ordinance.Â  The Hernandezes made no attempt 
  to subdivide their lot to create the nonconforming flag lot until after the 
  enactment of the ordinance.Â  Accordingly, as their use of the property as a 
  separate lot was at the most merely contemplated at the time of the enactment 
  of the ordinance, they are not entitled to any protection from enforcement of 
  the ordinance.Â  
The Hernandezes next assert 
  their rights to equal protection were violated by enforcement of the ordinance 
  prohibiting flag lots because although they are not being permitted to create 
  a flag lot, there are five flag lots in the immediate vicinity of their property.Â  
  The record reveals, however, that these lots were all created either prior to 
  the area being annexed into the Town of Mt. Pleasant or prior to the enactment 
  of the ordinance prohibiting flag lots.Â  As such, this is not a case of disparate 
  treatment of similarly situated individuals.
Finally, the Hernandezes 
  suggest they were denied the variance because Mr. Hernandez is Hispanic.Â  As 
  this issue was neither raised to nor ruled on by the circuit court, it is not 
  preserved for our review.Â  See Beaufort County v. Butler, 316 
  S.C. 465, 468, 451 S.E.2d 386, 388 (1994) (stating constitutional claims must 
  be raised and ruled upon below to be preserved for appeal).Â  
Accordingly, the 
  decision of the circuit court affirming the Boardâ€™s decision to deny the Hernandezesâ€™ 
  request for a variance is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and
CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
     
    [1] Â  The Hernandezes cite to Boulevard Dev. and St. Johnâ€™s Inn v. 
    City of Myrtle Beach, Op. No. 2001-UP-091 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Feb. 13, 
    2001).Â  Rule 239(d)(2), SCACR provides, â€œMemorandum opinions and unpublished 
    orders have no precedential value and should not be cited except in proceedings 
    in which they are directly involved.â€Â  

 
   
     
    [2]    As the parties have agreed to reserve the Hernandezesâ€™ takings claim 
    until after the resolution of their variance appeal, we will treat this argument 
    as an assertion that their lot should be grandfathered under the ordinance, 
    as it was addressed by the circuit court.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL
VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
John Doe, individually, and as Guardian for his minor child, James Doe 
        and Jason Doe, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Merle Batson,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-335
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  17, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gregg E. Meyers, of Charleston and J. David Flowers, of Greenville, 
  for Appellants.Â  
Edward R. Cole, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John Doe, individually, and 
  as guardian for his minor sons, James and Jason Doe (the Does), and on behalf 
  of all others similarly situated, brought this action against Merle Batson alleging 
  she breached her duty to warn the Does of her sonâ€™s deviancy after several boys, 
  including James and Jason, reported that Batsonâ€™s son molested them in Batsonâ€™s 
  house. [1] Â  The circuit court 
  granted Batsonâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  The Does appeal.Â  We affirm. 
  [2] 
FACTS
Batsonâ€™s son served as a youth minister 
  at the church James and Jason attended with their family.Â  He befriended a number 
  of teenage boys in the congregation and spent time with them outside of church-related 
  activities.Â  Eventually, he invited some of the boys, including James and Jason, 
  to visit and spend the night with him in his bedroom located in the basement 
  of Batsonâ€™s house.Â  It was during these visits that Batsonâ€™s son molested James 
  and Jason.Â  
The Does concede that Batson had no actual knowledge 
  of her sonâ€™s sexual deviancy until the charges became publicly known.Â  James 
  and Jason both testified their interaction with Batson was limited to some breakfasts 
  following overnight visits in her home.Â  Both boys testified they did not believe 
  she was suspicious of any sexual activity between them and her son.Â  Jason testified 
  he and Batsonâ€™s son sneaked into Batsonâ€™s sonâ€™s bedroom through an adjacent 
  storage room in the basement.Â  In another instance, Jason admitted to hiding 
  from Batson in her sonâ€™s bedroom and stated he did not believe she knew he was 
  in her house.Â  Eventually, the boys admitted the clandestine activities to their 
  parents.Â  
The Does brought this premises liability 
  action alleging Batson either expressly knew or should have known of her sonâ€™s 
  â€œdangerous propensities.â€Â  As such, they contend she breached her duty to appropriately 
  warn the Does.Â  The circuit court granted Batsonâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  
  On appeal, this court reversed the circuit court and remanded, finding the Does 
  were denied a full and fair opportunity to complete discovery.Â  Doe v. Batson, 
  338 S.C. 291, 525 S.E.2d 909 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The supreme court, after granting 
  certiorari, affirmed our decision to reverse and remand while vacating other 
  portions of the opinion.Â  Doe ex rel. Doe v. Batson, 345 S.C. 316, 548 
  S.E.2d 854 (2001).Â  On remand, the circuit court again granted Batsonâ€™s motion 
  for summary judgment.Â  The Does appeal.Â  We affirm.
DISCUSSION
The Does contend the circuit court erred by ruling 
  Batson did not owe a duty of care to warn James or Jason of her sonâ€™s deviant 
  behavior.Â  They also assert the court erred in concluding that even if a duty 
  of care existed, they failed to prove Batson breached it as a matter of law.Â  
  Finally, the Does contend summary judgment was improper because genuine issues 
  of material fact exist.Â  We disagree.Â  
When this court reviews the grant of a 
  motion for summary judgment, it applies the same standard of review that governs 
  the circuit court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Summary judgment is proper when, 
  viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party, there 
  is no genuine issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment 
  as a matter of law.Â  Baril v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 279-80, 
  573 S.E.2d 830, 835 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
A landownerâ€™s duty toward a person depends 
  upon the personâ€™s status.Â  F. Patrick Hubbard & Robert L. Felix, The 
  South Carolina Law of Torts 76 (1990).Â  The Does conceded James and Jason 
  were licensees for purposes of their premises liability claim against Batson.Â  
  Accordingly, Batson owed James and Jason a duty to warn of any concealed dangerous 
  conditions or activities known to her, or of any change in the condition of 
  the premises that might have been dangerous to them, and which she may reasonably 
  have been expected to discover.Â  Neil v. Bynum, 288 S.C. 472, 473, 343 
  S.E.2d 615, 616 (1986).Â  
The Does do not allege Batson had direct 
  knowledge that the boys were being molested.Â  Rather, they attempt to create 
  genuine issues of material fact regarding whether she knew the boys were spending 
  the night with her son on a regular basis by citing instances when Batson saw 
  the boys in or around her home.Â  The Does note Batson saw the boys with their 
  sleeping bags on one visit and during a few breakfasts following overnight stays. 
  Â Jason testified that on one occasion Batson gave him a package of pop-tarts.Â  
  James testified Batson saw him eating breakfast on several occasions.Â  However, 
  there was no evidence that Batsonâ€™s son was present during any of these encounters.Â  
  Batson testified she had seen James and Jason in her house on two occasions 
  and, although she saw them with their sleeping bags, she had â€œno earthly idea 
  what their sleeping arrangements were.â€Â  
The Does also claim Batson once saw Jason and her 
  son sitting in her sonâ€™s car in her driveway at night.Â  Jason testified that 
  after Batson saw him and her son in the driveway, they drove away, only to return 
  later and sneak into Batsonâ€™s house through a basement entrance. Â These casual 
  encounters suggest only that Batson knew of the boysâ€™ presence in or around 
  her house.Â  They do not suggest any unusual activity that would have alerted 
  Batson to any deviant behavior by her son.Â  
More significantly, both James and Jason testified 
  they did not believe Batson knew about her sonâ€™s sexual activities with them, 
  and there is evidence suggesting they actively prevented her from discovering 
  them.Â  The boys sneaked into the sonâ€™s room through an adjacent storage room 
  in the basement.Â  Jason admitted hiding from Batson in another instance, and 
  stated he did not believe she knew he was in her house.Â  
Batson had no duty to warn the boys of a danger 
  of which she was unaware.Â  Under these facts, we conclude Batson had neither 
  actual nor constructive notice her son posed a danger to James or Jason.Â  Without 
  notice, she could not have been reasonably expected to discover the deviant 
  activity clandestinely occurring in her sonâ€™s basement room.Â  As such, we find 
  no duty was created and no genuine issues of material fact were left in dispute.Â  
  In light of our determination Batson had no duty to James or Jason, we need 
  not address the Doesâ€™ claim of breach of duty.Â  
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., CURETON, A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The circuit court noted the Does filed but did not pursue 
    a motion to certify this action as a class action.Â  Further, the Doesâ€™ deposition 
    testimony revealed there were no other participants in the putative class.Â  
    We agree with the circuit court this is not a class action. In any event, 
    the Does have abandoned their attempt to obtain class certification. Â 

 
    [2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this 
    case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Janette Clayton,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Lands Inn, Inc., d/b/a Lands Inn and
Comfort Inn,        Defendants,
of whom Lands Inn, Inc. d/b/a Lands Inn is the       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-336
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 17, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert E. Lee, Amy Anderson Wise and Samuel F. Arthur, III, all of Florence, 
  for Appellant,
Ervin Lindsay Blanks, of N. Charleston and James Edward Bell, III, of Sumter, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal arises from a jury 
  verdict for actual and punitive damages in favor of Respondent Janet Clayton.Â  
  The circuit court denied Appellant Lands Innsâ€™ motions for a judgment 
  notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV), new trial absolute, and new trial nisi 
  remittitur.Â Â  Lands Inn appeals on the basis that the verdict was the 
  result of passion, caprice and prejudice. 
  [1] Â  We affirm.
Clayton worked as a resident hotel manager for 
  Lands Inn from 1992 until she was fired in 1996.Â  Robert Bowen, the executive 
  housekeeper at the hotel, believed that his job was in jeopardy.Â  Bowen, in 
  an effort to ingratiate himself with Richard Johnston, a Lands Inn supervisor, 
  informed Johnston that Clayton had been underreporting the number of rooms rented 
  and keeping money from those rooms. 
Pursuant to information supplied by Bowen, Johnston 
  compared the record of rooms cleaned each day to the information submitted by 
  Clayton reporting how many rooms were rented each day.Â  Undiscovered by Johnston 
  was the fact that Bowen dated rooms cleaned on the day prior to the actual cleaning.Â  
  This caused the comparison of records to show inconsistencies that, in fact, 
  did not exist.Â  Lands Inn, through Johnston, acted on this false information 
  and caused Clayton to be arrested for theft in July 1996.
Clayton hired an attorney in connection with the 
  criminal charge. She was denied unemployment benefits after Lands Inn reported 
  that she had been terminated for theft.Â  Clayton was unable to find a job until 
  seven months later when she took a lesser paying job as a hotel telephone operator.Â  
  During this time, Clayton had to borrow money from family and had two cars repossessed.Â  
  Also, at least two friends who called the hotel and asked for Clayton were told 
  that she had been terminated for theft.Â  The criminal charge was dismissed in 
  March 1997.Â  
Clayton brought an action against Lands 
  Inn for negligence, slander, and malicious prosecution.Â  At trial, Lands Inn 
  admitted its error and conceded there existed no basis for the theft charge 
  against Clayton.Â  Linda Jones, an accountant for Lands Inn, acknowledged that 
  Lands Inn made a â€œterrible mistake.â€
Prior to reaching a verdict, the jurors requested 
  and were given written instructions on the difference between actual and punitive 
  damages.Â  A second note inquired if Lands Inn could delay payment of its award 
  pending appeal:

  
  
    
      THE
        COURT:
       The jury has sent out a note:Â  If we award 
  actual and punitive damages, can the defendant delay payment on both awards 
  pending appeal?Â  Signed by foreperson.
        I have shared this with counsel.Â  And the response that is 
  going to be written on the note by consent is, this is not an issue that is 
  proper for your consideration.Â  Is that acceptable to everyone?
    
    
      All counsel responded, 
       â€œYes.â€
    
  
  

The court then, with the consent of the parties, 
  responded with a note that instructed the jury that this was not a proper issue 
  for their consideration.
After a verdict for actual damages of $500,000 
  and punitive damages of $750,000 was returned, Lands Inn moved for judgment 
  notwithstanding the verdict, new trial absolute, and alternatively, a new trial 
  nisi remittitur.Â  The motions were denied, as was Lands Innsâ€™ motion 
  for reconsideration.Â  Lands Inn appeals, arguing that the circuit court abused 
  its discretion by denying the motion for a new trial absolute because the jury 
  exceeded its authority by inquiring if payment of a potential verdict might 
  be delayed upon appeal.Â  This issue, however, was not raised in the trial court.
In its post-trial motions, Lands Inn claimed the 
  damage awards were grossly excessive, and moved â€œfor a new trial absolute on 
  the basis that the jury was clearly motivated by passion, caprice, prejudice, 
  whatsoever, as the court knows all the terminology there.â€Â  Lands Inn raised 
  no challenge in connection with the purportedly prejudicial jury note.Â  Thus, 
  the sole ground asserted on appeal was neither raised to nor ruled upon by the 
  trial court.Â  This issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  Holy Loch 
  Distribs., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 S.E.2d 282 (2000) (â€œIn 
  order to preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue must have been raised 
  to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€).Â  Lands Innâ€™s generic motion simply 
  cannot be construed to encompass the precise ground asserted on appeal.Â  See 
  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (stating 
  â€œan objection must be sufficiently specific to inform the trial court of the 
  point being urged by the objector.â€).
Moreover, considering the challenge to the verdict 
  as grossly excessive, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s denial 
  of Lands Innâ€™s motion for a new trial absolute.Â  The record reveals that Clayton 
  sustained substantial harm from Lands Innâ€™s egregious conduct.Â  We conclude, 
  as did the trial court, that the juryâ€™s verdict was not the result of passion, 
  caprice, prejudice or other improper factors.Â  
Accordingly, the judgment of the circuit court 
  is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. 
  

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Lands Innâ€™s appellate counsel did not represent Lands 
    Inn at trial.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Mary Ann Brinson,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Lexington Medical Center Extended Care,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
L. Casey Manning, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-337
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 17, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas J. Hummel, of Columbia, for Appellant.
F. Earl Ellis, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Mary Ann Brinson appeals an 
  order of the circuit court affirming the decision of an appellate panel of the 
  Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission denying her claim for compensation.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Brinson was employed as a housekeeper 
  by Lexington Medical Center from July 1994 to August 2000.Â  For the last year 
  and half of her employment, she experienced increasing degrees of pain in her 
  hands and fingers.Â  She consequently terminated her employment with the hospital.Â  
  She was subsequently diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome in both hands.Â  It 
  was Brinsonâ€™s opinion that this injury was a direct result of her employment 
  with Lexington Medical Center.Â  
Brinson filed a claim for workersâ€™
compensation with her former employer, which was denied.  She appealed this
denial to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission and was granted a hearing before 
  a single commissioner.Â  Brinson claimed that her duties at Lexington Medical 
  Center, namely the multiple tasks she performed with her hands in cleaning approximately 
  twenty-three rooms on a daily basis, had caused her injury. 
  [1] Â  It was revealed at the hearing, however, that Brinson had a long time 
  hobby of cross-stitching and needlepoint, which she had enjoyed for over twenty 
  years.Â  While Brinson at one point in the hearing claimed that she had ceased 
  this activity years prior to 1994, the record also reflects Brinsonâ€™s contradictory 
  admission that she continued needlepoint during her employment with Lexington 
  Medical Center.Â  In her deposition, Brinson claimed that she did not stop her 
  needlework until well after gaining employment with Lexington Medical Center, 
  when pain made it impossible to enjoy the hobby.Â  
Although treated by two specialists 
  in the area of carpal tunnel syndrome, Brinson presented only the testimony 
  of her chiropractor at the hearing to support the view that her injury was caused 
  by her employment.Â  The chiropractor acknowledged, however, that the carpal 
  tunnel syndrome could have been brought about by her years of needlework.Â  Â Â 
The single commissioner concluded Brinsonâ€™s 
  carpal tunnel syndrome was not the result of an injury by accident arising out 
  of and in the course of her employment pursuant to South Carolina Code section 
  42-1-160 (Supp. 2003).Â  Brinsonâ€™s request for compensation was denied.Â  An appellate 
  panel of the Commission upheld the denial of Brinsonâ€™s claim, and the circuit 
  court affirmed.Â  The circuit court determined there was substantial evidence 
  to support the decision of the Commission.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures 
  Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (Supp. 2003), establishes the standard 
  of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission 
  as the â€œsubstantial evidenceâ€ standard.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 
  130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  The factual findings of the agency are 
  presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  
  Kearse v. State Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 198, 
  200, 456 S.E.2d 892, 893 (1995).Â  Substantial evidence is evidence that, when 
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the 
  conclusion the Commission reached.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 
  S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999); McGuffin v. Schlumberger-Sangamo, 
  307 S.C. 184, 186, 414 S.E.2d 162, 163 (1992).Â  â€œThe possibility of drawing 
  two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent the commissionâ€™s 
  findings from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Oâ€™Banner v. Westinghouse 
  Elec. Corp., 319 S.C. 24, 30, 459 S.E.2d 324, 327-28 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
Pursuant to this standard, 
  the reviewing court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission 
  as to questions of fact (so long as such judgment is supported by substantial 
  evidence), and may only reverse if the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (A)(6) (Supp. 2003); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 
  324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App 1996).Â  The issue of whether there 
  is a causal connection between the claimantâ€™s employment and their injury is 
  a question of fact.Â  Sharpe, 336 S.C. at 159, 519 S.E.2d at 105; see 
  also Rhodes v. Guignard Brick Works, 245 S.C. 304, 311, 140 S.E.2d 
  487, 490 (1965).
DISCUSSION
Brinson contends the decision 
  of the Commission was based on an error of law.Â  We disagree.
Brinson cites Pee v. 
  AVM, Inc., 352 S.C. 167, 573 S.E.2d 785 (2002), for the proposition that 
  an injury caused by repetitive trauma may constitute â€œinjury by accidentâ€ under 
  the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 
  2003).Â  Pursuant to this holding, she asserts legal error by the Commission 
  in excluding â€œmultiple task repetitive traumaâ€ from the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act.Â  We agree with Brinson that it is undecided in this state whether such 
  varying activities, as she performed at Lexington Medical Center, may constitute 
  â€œrepetitive traumaâ€ under the Pee v. AVM holding.Â  Brinson, however, 
  misconstrues the basis of the Commissionâ€™s denial of her claim, for the Commissionâ€™s 
  decision is fact-based.Â  
The Commission affirmed 
  the decision of the single commissioner by adopting her complete order by reference.Â  
  The single commissioner based her decision to deny Brinson compensation on the 
  factual finding that the injury was not caused by Brinsonâ€™s employment. The 
  commissioner found the testimony of Brinsonâ€™s chiropractor lacking in credibility.Â  
  The commissioner also noted that Brinsonâ€™s needlework hobby of over twenty years 
  did involve such motions.Â  The commissioner did not exclude as a matter of law 
  activities like those required by Brinsonâ€™s employment from the possible legal 
  causes of carpal tunnel syndrome, for she merely found, as a factual determination, 
  that in this particular case a much more likely cause was Brinsonâ€™s twenty year 
  needlework hobby.Â Â  This was solely a factual determination of whether there 
  was any causal connection between Brinsonâ€™s employment and her injury.Â  See 
  Sharpe, 336 S.C. at 159-160, 519 S.E.2d at 105.Â  
Since the decision to deny 
  Brinson compensation was determined exclusively on the factual issue of causation, 
  we have only to determine whether substantial evidence supports the ruling.Â  
  We find substantial evidence exists on record to find Brinsonâ€™s carpal tunnel 
  syndrome is not the result of an injury by accident arising out of and in the 
  course of her employment.Â  As discussed above, the commissioner heard evidence 
  of two possible causes of Brinsonâ€™s injury, her employment and her needlepoint.Â  
  â€œWhen evidence is in conflict, someone has to determine the true facts [and] 
  [t]hat chore is assigned to the Workerâ€™s Compensation Commission.â€Â  Fair 
  v. Fluor Daniel, 309 S.C. 520, 521, 424 S.E.2d 541, 542 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  
  Given the testimony of the chiropractor that either activity could have caused 
  Brinsonâ€™s injury, Brinsonâ€™s testimony as to her needlework, and the non-specific 
  descriptions of her work-related activities, there was substantial evidence 
  to deny Brinson compensation.
Brinson also points out 
  on appeal that, even if her injuries were caused by the needlepoint, an accident 
  that accelerates or aggravates a preexisting condition is still compensable.Â  
  Brown v. R.L. Jordan Oil Co., 291 S.C. 272, 275, 353 S.E.2d 280, 282 
  (1987).Â Â  While this is a correct assertion, one must also note â€œa condition 
  due solely to natural progression of a preexisting [injury] is not compensable.â€Â  
  Id.Â  Brinson did not raise the issue of aggravated injury at any level 
  below and offered no evidence on record as to the degree of possible aggravation 
  as opposed to natural progression.Â  She instead sought to gain full compensation 
  by arguing her injury was wholly caused by her employment with Lexington Medical 
  Center.Â  As such, the issue of aggravation is not preserved for our review.Â  
  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 
  543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the 
  first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial 
  court to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
In a claim for compensation brought under the Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Act, â€œ[t]he burden is on the claimant to prove such facts as will 
  render the injury compensable, and such an award must not be based on surmise, 
  conjecture or speculation.â€Â  Crosby v. Wal-Mart Store, Inc., 330 S.C. 
  489, 496, 499 S.E.2d 253, 257 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Here, substantial evidence supports 
  the Commissionâ€™s determination that Brinson failed to meet this burden.
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the 
  circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â  
  

 
   
    [1]  These duties included wiping off tables, dusting lamps, refilling 
    paper towels and soap dispensers, emptying trash, mopping floors, and cleaning 
    sinks and toilets.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2),
SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lynn Whitsett Corporation,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Norbord South Carolina, Inc., and Callidus Technologies, Inc., Defendants, 
        Of Which Callidus Technologies, Inc., is,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-338
Submitted March 8, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  18, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Joseph W. Hudgens, of Newberry, and Warner R. Wilson, Jr., 
  of Atlanta, for Appellant.Â  
Boyd B. Nicholson, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lynn Whitsett Corporation brought 
  this action against Norbord South Carolina, Inc. and Callidus Technologies, 
  Inc. for breach of contract, foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien, and quantum meruit.Â  
  Callidus counterclaimed for breach of contract and breach of warranties.Â  The 
  trial court found for Lynn Whitsett on its breach of contract claim, but concluded 
  Callidus was entitled to an offset for delays and recovery on its breach of 
  warranties claims.Â  The resulting net judgment was in favor of Callidus.Â  Lynn 
  Whitsett appeals.Â  We affirm. [1] 
  
FACTS
Norbord hired Callidus as its 
  general contractor to build a pressboard plant.Â  Callidus subcontracted with 
  Lynn Whitsett to install ceramic refractory materials to the walls of Norbordâ€™s 
  kilns.Â  Lynn Whitsettâ€™s contract contained a fixed price for the installation 
  project.Â  However, in the event of a change in the scope of the work, the contract 
  converted to one based on time and materials.Â  It also stated Callidus would 
  provide a particular type of refractory material to be used in the installation.Â  
  Instead, Callidus supplied a slightly different product.Â  Lynn Whitsett applied 
  the ceramics using a gunning crew to spray them onto the kiln walls and a casting 
  crew to pour the material into prepared forms.Â  Delays arose when the refractory 
  material did not set up properly with the result that the entire application 
  process took fifteen weeks instead of the eight weeks stated in the contract.Â  

Lynn Whitsett claimed it was owed $84,472.20 under 
  the contract because the application required significant extra labor.Â  When 
  Callidus refused to pay, Lynn Whitsett brought this action.Â  Callidus filed 
  a bond to discharge the mechanicâ€™s lien and agreed to indemnify Norbord for 
  any amounts due Lynn Whitsett.  
Lynn Whitsett amended its complaint to 
  argue the scope of its work had been increased because Callidus supplied a different 
  refractory material than had been proposed in the contract.Â  Lynn Whitsett claimed 
  this change converted the contract from one with a fixed price to one based 
  on time and materials.Â  Callidus counterclaimed alleging breach of express and 
  implied warranties based on faulty workmanship.Â  
The trial court agreed with Lynn Whitsett 
  that the contract was converted from a lump sum payment to one based on time 
  and materials with a balance due of $272,498.60.Â  However, the court determined 
  Lynn Whitsett was responsible for four weeks of delays and gave Callidus a substantial 
  setoff of $179,307.12.Â  The court also found Lynn Whitsett breached implied 
  and express warranties and set damages at $114,342.79, finally awarding judgment 
  for Callidus in the amount of $21,151.31.Â  Based on these findings, the court 
  concluded Callidus prevailed in the mechanicâ€™s lien action and awarded attorneyâ€™s 
  fees in the amount of $71,714.41.Â  
DISCUSSION
An action for breach of contract seeking 
  money damages is an action at law.Â  Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 
  S.C. 237, 240, 421 S.E.2d 402, 404 (1992).Â  An action to foreclose a mechanicâ€™s 
  lien is also an action at law.Â  Adams v. B & D, Inc., 297 S.C. 416, 
  420, 377 S.E.2d 315, 317 (1989).Â  In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried 
  without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon 
  appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports those findings.Â  
  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 
  775 (1976).Â  
I.Â  Four-Week Delay
Lynn Whitsett contends 
  the trial court erred by granting Callidus a set-off after determining Lynn 
  Whitsett was responsible for a four-week delay in completing its work.Â  Lynn 
  Whitsett claims there is no evidence in the record to support the trial courtâ€™s 
  conclusion, and maintains Callidus caused the delays by supplying substitute 
  refractory materials and by failing to properly prepare and install items prior 
  to the application of the ceramics.Â  We disagree.Â  
On appeal, this court cannot 
  weigh conflicting evidence in a law case.Â  Only if there is no conflicting evidence 
  may we find error as a matter of law.Â  Hibernian Socâ€™y v. Thomas, 282 
  S.C. 465, 469, 319 S.E.2d 339, 342 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Although the record contains 
  evidence that Callidus may have been responsible for some delays, it also contains 
  evidence that Lynn Whitsett caused the four-week delay.Â  In a letter to Callidus 
  with the heading â€œSubject:Â  Explanation for extra work invoice,â€ beneath a subsection 
  marked â€œOther problems that caused delays or additional work:â€ a Lynn Whitsett 
  representative wrote: 

It was never Lynn Whitsettâ€™s intention 
  to cast the SCC in any other method but to pump them.Â  This was an oversight 
  on my part when I read the SK-1 sheet that you sent me before starting of 
  this job that stated that Kricon 28 would be used.Â  I assumed after other conversations 
  that I had with you and Elton, that pumping of the SCC was the only cost effective 
  way of installation.Â  This will require an additional four weeks of work 
  to do this in the manner that you want it, one bucket at a time.Â  Again, this 
  was not quoted that way.Â  

(Emphasis added.)
When questioned about the letter 
  during cross examination, the representative admitted his oversight caused the 
  delay.Â  Accordingly, we conclude there was evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s 
  finding that Lynn Whitsett was responsible for four weeks of the delay and the 
  corresponding award of a set-off in favor of Callidus.  
II.Â  Calculating 
  the Set-off Amount
Lynn Whitsett further contends 
  the amount of the set-off is unsupported by the evidence.Â  We disagree.Â  
The evidence supporting a damages 
  award should be such that the court can determine the amount with reasonable 
  certainty or accuracy.Â  See Gray v. Southern Facilities, Inc., 256 S.C. 
  558, 570, 183 S.E.2d 438, 444 (1971).Â  However, proof to a mathematical certainty 
  of the amount of loss or damage is not required.Â  Whisenant v. James Island 
  Corp., 277 S.C. 10, 13, 281 S.E.2d 794, 796 (1981).Â  
In making the set-off award of 
  $179,307.12, the trial court relied on Lynn Whitsettâ€™s own exhibit detailing 
  three weeks of estimated labor costs for one of its crews.Â  The total cost came 
  to $138,938.16 or, by extrapolation, as much as $185,250.88 for four weeks.Â  
  Lynn Whitsett contends this reliance was misplaced because the exhibit details 
  costs for a gunning crew and not a casting crew of the sort used during the 
  four-week delay.Â  This distinction is insignificant.Â  Both crews were engaged 
  in the same tasks and employed nearly the same number of men, with a gunning 
  crew employing eight and a casting crew eight or nine.Â  As such, we find the 
  trial court properly considered Lynn Whitsettâ€™s exhibit as evidence in determining 
  the amount of the set-off.Â  
Additionally, we note Lynn Whitsett 
  estimated its total cost for the full 15 to 16 weeks at $670,112.60.Â  A four-week 
  delay would then equate to between $167,528.16 and $178,696.68.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find the evidence presented amply supports the set-off amount of $179,307.12.Â  

III.Â  Breach of 
  Express Warranty
Lynn Whitsett contends the trial 
  court erred by awarding Callidus damages on its counterclaim for breach of express 
  warranty.Â  It insists the contractâ€™s warranty provision applied exclusively 
  to goods purchased through the purchase order and did not cover the installation 
  of the ceramic refractory material.Â  We disagree.Â  
An express warranty is created when a seller makes 
  an affirmation or promise to the buyer which relates to the goods and becomes 
  part of the basis for the bargain that those goods will conform to the affirmation 
  or promise.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-102 (2003) (stating the UCC applies 
  to transactions in goods); see also Fields v. Melrose Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 
  312 S.C. 102, 105, 439 S.E.2d 283, 284 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œA warranty is created 
  when the seller makes an affirmation with respect to the thing to be sold with 
  the intention that the buyer shall rely on it in making the purchase.â€) (citation 
  omitted).Â  
The contractâ€™s warranty provision defined 
  â€œgoodsâ€ to mean â€œthe goods described in this Purchase Order or any amendment 
  hereto . . . and also include[d] any work or services performed under the 
  Contract by Supplier or any of its subcontractors in connection with or incidental 
  to Goods.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  We read this language to extend the coverage 
  of the express warranty beyond the raw materials to include the installation 
  of the refractory material.Â  
An engineer testified the ceramic refractory 
  material installed by Lynn Whitsett should last at least one year if not two 
  or three.Â  One month after the kilns began operating, the refractory material 
  began to separate from the kiln walls.Â  Norbord immediately began testing to 
  determine the cause.Â  Within five months, enough refractory material had dislodged 
  that Lynn Whitsett, at Callidusâ€™ request, returned to perform repairs.Â  However, 
  refractory material continued to come out of the kilns.Â  Callidus again asked 
  for repairs in January and May of 2001.Â  Lynn Whitsett refused, and another 
  company ultimately completed the work.Â  
Based on our reading of the warranty provision, 
  we find Lynn Whitsett expressly warranted any work or services performed under 
  the contract including the installation of the refractory material.Â  As such, 
  Lynn Whitsett breached its express warranty when it refused to correct defective 
  installation and make repairs on Norbordâ€™s kilns in January and May of 2001. [2] 
IV.Â  Calculation of Damages
Lynn Whitsett also argues 
  that even if we determine it breached warranties to Callidus, there was no competent 
  evidence to support the amount of the damages award.Â  Lynn Whitsett contends 
  the repair invoices the court relied on to calculate damages were not properly 
  identified by either the service provider or the recipient payor.Â  As such, 
  Lynn Whitsett asserts they were inadmissible hearsay.Â  This issue is not preserved 
  for our review.Â  
 Callidus produced two invoices from Larkin Furnace, 
  the company that ultimately completed the kiln repairs, as evidence to support 
  its claim for damages arising from Lynn Whitsettâ€™s breach of express and implied 
  warranties.Â  Norbord paid the invoices, but was fully reimbursed by Callidus.Â  
  At trial, Dick Liniger, an engineer for Callidus, explained the invoices.Â  
When the invoices were offered into evidence, 
  Lynn Whitsett objected on the ground there was no causal link established between 
  the work it performed and the need for repairs.Â  After additional testimony 
  from Liniger, the court admitted the invoices into evidence.Â  Lynn Whitsett 
  did not object to the invoices as hearsay.Â  Neither was there an objection that 
  Liniger was not the appropriate person to testify to the content of the invoices 
  or the necessity of the repairs.Â  Lynn Whitsett raised this objection for the 
  first time in its motion to alter or amend.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not 
  preserved for our review.Â  Patterson v. Reid, 318 S.C. 183, 185, 456 
  S.E.2d 436, 437 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding a party cannot raise an issue by way 
  of a Rule 59(e) motion which may have been raised at trial).Â  
V.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Finally, Lynn Whitsett contends that 
  but for the errors in the trial courtâ€™s order, it would be the prevailing party 
  and, consequently, the attorneyâ€™s fees award should be reversed in its favor.Â  
  We disagree.
Lynn Whitsettâ€™s argument is dependent 
  on a determination it prevailed on its remaining causes of action.Â  Under our 
  analysis, Callidus remains the prevailing party and is, therefore, entitled 
  to attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â 

 
   
     
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
     
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Lynn Whitsett also appeals the trial courtâ€™s conclusion 
    that it breached an implied warranty.Â  However, we need not address this issue 
    in light of our determination that Lynn Whitsett breached an express warranty 
    created by the contract.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  In this legal malpractice action, 
  Dale Shaffer appeals the order of the trial court granting Adam Bacotâ€™s motion 
  to strike portions of Shafferâ€™s complaint.Â  Shaffer argues the court erred in 
  granting the motion to strike and that the process of litigating legal malpractice 
  claims violates constitutional guarantees of equal protection and due process.Â  
  We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities:Â  
  Totaro v. Turner, 273 S.C. 134, 135, 254 S.E.2d 800, 801 (1979) (stating 
  aÂ motion to strike is addressed 
  to the sound discretion of the trial court; the trial courtâ€™s decision will 
  not be reversed absent a showing of abuse of discretion); Rule 12(f), SCRCP 
  (stating the trial court may order stricken from any pleading â€œredundant, immaterial, 
  impertinent or scandalous matterâ€); Beaufort County v. Butler, 316 S.C. 
  465, 468, 451 S.E.2d 386, 388 (1994) (stating constitutional claims must be 
  raised and ruled upon below to be preserved for appeal).
 AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, 
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â
