THIS OPINION HAS NOT PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
George A. Sowell,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Mayme Gust Sowell,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
H. T. Abbott, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-340
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 18, 
  2004 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert Lucas Lumpkin, Jr., of Georgetown; Thomas M. Neal, 
  III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Deborah Harrison Sheffield, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  George A. Sowell (Husband) 
  appeals from the family court judgeâ€™s modification of a spousal support award 
  to Mayme Gust Sowell (Wife).Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
BACKGROUND


Husband
and Wife were divorced in September 1983, after 27 years of marriage. 
At the time of the divorce,
Husband was 53 years old and employed as a physician, while Wife was 48 years
old and unemployed.  After
considering the various appropriate factors, the court ordered Husband to pay
alimony to Wife in the amount of $3,000 per month. 
 


Ten
years later, in December 1993, Husband brought an action to reduce Wifeâ€™s
alimony award.  On January 20, 1994,
the parties entered into a consent order in which Wifeâ€™s alimony award would
be reduced and the amount of the reduction held in abeyance pending her
remarriage.  The amount held in
abeyance was then to be paid to Wife when she remarried, at which time
Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation would end.  Wifeâ€™s
remarriage, however, did not occur.  Thereafter,
in May 1994, Husband filed an amended complaint seeking a reduction, suspension
or termination of the alimony payments based upon an alleged substantial change
in the partiesâ€™ financial conditions.  A
hearing was held on the matter in August 1996. 
At that time, Husband alleged he had diluted his income due to his
advancing age and his inability to continue to work the number of hours he
previously worked in his medical practice. 
He further alleged he had â€œreduced and plan[ned] to eliminate his
obstetrical practice.â€  On October
10, 1996, the family court judge issued an order maintaining the monthly $3000
alimony award.  The judge found
Husbandâ€™s reduction in income was insufficient to warrant a reduction in
alimony.  Specifically, he found the
reduction in Husbandâ€™s income was contemplated by him inasmuch as Husband
testified he anticipated reducing his hours as he approached retirement. 
The judge further found Husband anticipated use of his retirement funds
to supplement his reduced income.  The
family court judge found Husbandâ€™s reduction in income should have been
anticipated by the parties at the time of the alimony award in 1983. 
  In August 2001, Husband filed another 
    action seeking a reduction in the $3,000 alimony award.Â  Husband sought this 
    change in his support obligation based on both his reduction of income and 
    Wifeâ€™s improved financial condition.Â  After a hearing, the family court judge 
    issued an order reducing the alimony award from $3000 per month to $2000 per 
    month.Â  The judge noted Husbandâ€™s net worth had decreased from $1,076,000 
    in 1996 to $925,000 in 2002, as he withdrew his retirement to supplement his 
    income, while Wifeâ€™s net worth increased from $492,000 in 1996 to $865,000 
    in 2002. [1] Â  However, he determined 
    Husbandâ€™s retirement was foreseeable and within the purview of the parties.Â  
    On the other hand, he found fluctuations in the stock market were not anticipated, 
    and Wifeâ€™s substantially changed financial condition resulting from fortuitous 
    investments warranted a modification in alimony.Â  The judge found both parties 
    were well represented and both had positions of merit.Â  He therefore denied 
    attorneyâ€™s fees for either party.Â  The family court judge subsequently denied 
    Husbandâ€™s motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  
  Husband appeals, arguing the family court judge 
    erred in making certain findings concerning his financial condition, and in 
    failing to further reduce or eliminate his alimony obligation.Â  He further 
    asserts error in the denial of attorneyâ€™s fees.
  STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
    In appeals from the family court, 
      this court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own 
      view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 
      307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review 
      does not, however, require this court to disregard the findings of the family 
      court.Â  Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 283, 569 S.E.2d 367, 
      369 (2002).Â  Rather, because the family court is in a superior position 
      to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given 
      broad discretion.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 
      620, 623 (2003).Â Â  

  LAW/ANALYSIS

I.         
Modification of Alimony Award
         Husband argues that, in determining 
          the amount to reduce the alimony award, the family court judge committed 
          reversible error in including the valuation of a life insurance policy 
          as well as Husbandâ€™s current wifeâ€™s interest in their marital home in 
          the value of Husbandâ€™s assets.Â  Husband also argues the family court 
          judge erred in failing to either further reduce or terminate the alimony 
          award.Â  We disagree.
        Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  A.Â Â Â Â Â  Life insurance policy
        Husband argues the family court judge erred 
          in including the value of a life insurance policy in determining his 
          assets.Â  Specifically, Husband argues the policy should not have been 
          considered because it is the subject of an irrevocable trust and he 
          has no access to the funds.
        It is undisputed that in 1985, 
          Husband placed certain life insurance policies in a trust for the benefit 
          of his children.Â  In determining Husbandâ€™s net worth to have decreased 
          from $1,076,000 in 1996 to $925,000 in 2002, the family court judge 
          stated he included $80,000 for the cash value of life insurance in the 
          $925,000 figure.Â  The judge recognized Husband testified â€œthis money 
          was placed into an Irrevocable Unfunded Life Insurance Trust for his 
          children prior to the 1996 hearing to which he has no access to withdraw 
          funds.â€Â  However, the judge stated his inclusion of this policy was 
          merely for comparison purposes, as Husband had included the value of 
          this policy on his 1996 financial declaration.Â  
        We find the family court judge 
          properly considered the $80,000 cash value of the life insurance policy 
          when determining Husbandâ€™s 2002 net worth inasmuch as Husband had included 
          this figure on his 1996 financial declaration, even though he had transferred 
          this policy to the trust prior to 1996.Â  Therefore, as stated by the 
          judge in the final order, the inclusion of the cash value of the policy 
          in the instant case was merely to compare Husbandâ€™s current financial 
          situation with his 1996 finances.Â  The family court judge could not 
          properly compare the change in Husbandâ€™s financial condition without 
          including this same asset as listed on his 1996 financial declaration.Â  
        

          B.   Â Â Â Â  Interest in marital home

        Husband argues the family court judge erred 
          in including the full value of his home, including his current wifeâ€™s 
          one-half interest in the home, in determining his assets.Â  
        In determining Husbandâ€™s current 
          net worth, the family court judge considered Husbandâ€™s interest in his 
          marital home to be 100 percent.Â  Akin to the situation with the life 
          insurance policy, however, the judge stated the inclusion of the marital 
          home in the calculation of Husbandâ€™s net worth was â€œsolely for the purpose 
          of comparison.â€Â  
        The record shows that in May 
          2001, Husband transferred a one-half interest in his home to his current 
          wife.Â  Husband testified his wife did not pay him anything for this 
          transfer of interest.Â  Similar to our findings regarding the inclusion 
          of the life insurance policy when determining Husbandâ€™s current net 
          worth, we find the family court judge properly considered the full value 
          of Husbandâ€™s current marital home.Â  The full value of his home was listed 
          on Husbandâ€™s 1996 financial declaration; thus the family court was within 
          its discretion in taking into account the full value of the home in 
          determining whether there was a change in circumstances.Â  This is especially 
          true as the family court judge noted he included the home â€œsolely for 
          the purpose of comparison.â€ [2] 
        Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  C.Â Â Â Â Â  Further reduction 
          or termination of alimony
        Husband also argues the family 
          court judge erred in failing to further reduce or terminate Wifeâ€™s alimony 
          award.Â  He contends Wife no longer has a need, or at least not a significant 
          need, for alimony, and he is no longer in a position to pay it. 
          [3] 
        An award of periodic alimony may be modified 
          based on a change of circumstances pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-170 
          (1985). In order to justify modification or termination of an alimony 
          award, the changes in circumstances must be substantial or material.Â  
          Eubank v. Eubank, 347 S.C. 367, 372, 555 S.E.2d 413, 416 (Ct. 
          App. 2001) (citing Thornton v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 111, 492 
          S.E.2d 86, 94 (1997)).Â  Further, the change in circumstances must be 
          unanticipated.Â  Kelley v. Kelley, 324 S.C. 481, 486, 477 S.E.2d 
          727, 729 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Several considerations relevant to the initial 
          setting of an alimony award may be applied in the modification context 
          as well, including the partiesâ€™ standard of living during the marriage, 
          each partyâ€™s earning capacity, and the supporting spouseâ€™s ability to 
          continue to support the other spouse.Â  Id.Â  The modification 
          of alimony is within the sound discretion of the family court and will 
          not be overturned absent an abuse of that discretion.Â  Riggs v. Riggs, 
          353 S.C. 230, 236, 578 S.E.2d 3, 6 (2003). 
        We find a further reduction or 
          outright termination of Husbandâ€™s alimony obligation is not warranted 
          in this case.Â  Though Husband argues his circumstances have changed 
          and his net worth has decreased since his retirement, we note the 1996 
          order clearly found Husband anticipated use of his retirement funds 
          to supplement his reduced income, and Husbandâ€™s reduction in income 
          should have been anticipated by the parties at the time of the alimony 
          award in 1983.Â  Further, Husband testified that at the time of the 1996 
          action he anticipated a reduction in hours he worked as he approached 
          retirement and he planned to eliminate his obstetrical practice, at 
          which time he would have to use his retirement funds to supplement his 
          income. He further admitted that at the 1996 hearing, as well as the 
          1983 hearing, he knew he would have to invade his retirement funds at 
          some point and that his â€œgame planâ€ all along was to use these funds 
          upon retirement.Â  Thus, the record supports the family court judgeâ€™s 
          finding in this matter that Husbandâ€™s retirement was contemplated by 
          the parties.Â  
        Further, we find the family court judgeâ€™s 
          modification of the alimony award from $3000 to $2000 in the instant 
          case was more than reasonable.Â  Wifeâ€™s 2002 financial declaration showed 
          a monthly income, including the $3,000 in alimony, of $3,251 after taxes.Â  
          She listed total monthly expenses of $2,914.Â  Thus, with a $1,000 reduction 
          in alimony Wife should have a net income somewhat less or almost in 
          line with her expenses.Â  Husband, on the other hand showed a net monthly 
          income of $5,735 in 2002, and expenses of $6,764, including his $3,000 
          monthly alimony payments to Wife.Â  With a decrease by $1,000 in his 
          monthly alimony payments, Husband likewise should be able to meet his 
          monthly expenses.Â Â  This court is not unmindful of Husbandâ€™s complaint 
          that he is having to withdraw from his retirement to achieve his income 
          stream, however, the modification as ordered by the family court judge 
          will not require Wife to deplete her assets so Husband will not have 
          to reduce his own, a measure clearly contemplated by the parties and 
          the court.Â  We find the reduction in alimony as ordered by the court 
          provides Husband some relief, without serving as a disincentive to Wife 
          from saving and investing her money.Â  Accordingly, we find no error 
          in the family court judgeâ€™s determination to reduce Husbandâ€™s monthly 
          alimony obligation from $3000 to $2000.
         II.        
        Attorneyâ€™s Fees
           Husband argues the family court 
            judge erred in failing to award him attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We disagree.
          In
          determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court
          should consider the following factors: (1) the partyâ€™s ability to
          pay his or her own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by the
          attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and (4)
          the effect of the attorneyâ€™s fee on each partyâ€™s standard of
          living. 
          E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d 812,
          816 (1992). 
          The decision of whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees is in the
          discretion of the trial court, which will not be overturned absent an
          abuse of that discretion. 
          Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d
          901, 903 (1988).
          The fact that Husbandâ€™s attorney 
            obtained a beneficial result in the form of a reduction in monthly 
            alimony payments does not require an award of attorneyâ€™s fees in this 
            case.Â  Wife was also benefited by the representation from her attorney 
            in that she did not suffer the extent of a decrease in alimony sought 
            by Husband.Â  Further, as the family court judge found Husbandâ€™s net 
            worth was $925,000, Husband still has the ability to pay his own fees.Â  
            Finally, there is no evidence his financial condition has deteriorated 
            to the point that paying his attorneyâ€™s fees would be a hardship or 
            that it would detrimentally impact his standard of living. 
            [4] Â  We find the judge acted within his discretion in deciding 
            not to award attorneyâ€™s fees because â€œboth parties were well represented 
            and the relative positions both [had] merit.â€Â  Accordingly, we find 
            the family court judge did not err in declining to award attorneyâ€™s 
            fees to Husband.
           AFFIRMED.
          ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

       
         
          [1] The parties agreed at the outset of the hearing in this matter 
          that Husband was alleging a change of circumstances since the 1996 order, 
          and therefore the court would consider events occurring after the 1996 
          order in determining whether there was a substantial change in circumstances 
          warranting modification.Â  
      
       
         
          [2]  Furthermore, we consider Husbandâ€™s argument that the court 
          should not have included in Husbandâ€™s assets the transferred one-half 
          interest in the marital home to his current wife, which occurred only 
          four months prior to the institution of this action, to be without merit.Â  
          Husband testified he gratuitously transferred the interest to his current 
          wife for no consideration.Â  While Husband was clearly entitled to make 
          such a transfer, the family court judge properly considered this voluntary 
          transfer in determining Husbandâ€™s net assets.
      
       
         [3] 
          We note Husband only sought a reduction of alimony in his complaint, 
          not a termination of alimony.Â  Further, there is no indication in the 
          record before us that Husband argued to the family court that he was 
          entitled to a termination of this support obligation. 
      
       
         
          [4] Husband has provided no evidence of the amount of his attorneyâ€™s 
          fees.

title: Dunham v. Coffey
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Kimberly F. Dunham, Respondent,
        v.
        
Michael David Coffey, Appellant.
      
    
  



Appeal From Greenville County
  Timothy L. Brown, Family Court Judge 



Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-344
  Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 25, 2004Â 



AFFIRMED



  
    
      
Michael D. Coffey, of Greer, for Appellant.
Kimberly Fisher Dunham, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Michael David Coffey appeals 
  the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motion for relief from an order requiring him 
  to pay attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
In January of 1998, Lisa A. Webb commenced an action 
  against Coffey seeking a modification of custody, visitation, child support, 
  unrecovered medical expenses, attorneyâ€™s fees, and other related relief.Â  Coffey, 
  who represented himself in the matter, filed an answer and counterclaim, but 
  did not list his address as required by Rule 11(a), SCRCP.Â  Three days prior 
  to the final hearing, Kimberly Dunham, Webbâ€™s attorney, mailed notice of the 
  final hearing to Coffey by certified mail, return receipt requested, to his 
  last known address of 204 Roe Road. Unbeknownst to the court or Dunham, Coffey 
  had moved from the Roe Road location.Â  The notice was forwarded to Coffeyâ€™s 
  new address, and Coffey received the notice the day after the hearing.Â  Thus, 
  Coffey was not present at the final hearing on April 16, 1999.Â  In the trial 
  courtâ€™s final order issued on May 27, 1999, Coffey was ordered to pay $3,531.05 
  in attorneyâ€™s fees to Dunham within sixty days of the entry of the final order.Â  

Coffey failed to pay the attorneyâ€™s fees; therefore, 
  in July of 2002, Dunham filed this action seeking enforcement of the portion 
  of the final order pertaining to the payment of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  On October 
  11, 2002, Coffey filed a motion for relief from judgment under Rule 60, SCRCP, 
  claiming he did not receive proper notice of the final hearing.Â  The trial court 
  denied Coffeyâ€™s motion.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS

Coffey essentially argues the May 1999 order is void because 
  he was not properly served with notice of the final hearing.Â  Therefore, he 
  claims the trial court erred in denying his motion for relief from judgment.Â  
  We disagree.
Rule 60(b), SCRCP, provides that a motion for relief from 
  a final judgment must be made within one year of the entry of judgment.Â  Coffey 
  waited until October of 2002 to file his motion, well over one year after the 
  trial court issued its order.Â  Therefore, Coffey is bound by the one-year time 
  frame unless the evidence shows he was not given proper notice of the final 
  hearing.Â  See Rule 60(b), SCRCP.
Coffey argues Dunham failed to properly notify him of the 
  final hearing because she sent the notice to his old address a mere three days 
  prior to the final hearing.Â  Rule 17(a), SCRFC, states that, when a defendant 
  is not represented by counsel and does not file an answer, notice is sufficient 
  when mailed to the defendant at his last known address, by certified mail, return 
  receipt requested.Â  In the present case, Coffey filed an answer with the court.Â  
  Therefore, Rule 17(a) did not apply, and Dunham actually did more than was required 
  when she mailed notice to Coffey.Â  
When a defendant files an answer pro se, 
  Rule 11(a), SCRCP, requires him to sign the answer and state his address so 
  that the clerk of court can notify him of the hearing.Â  In this case, Coffey 
  failed to state his address when he filed his answer.Â  Although Coffey claims 
  his address of 204 Roe Road was on file with the court because of the return 
  address on a letter he sent to the judge prior to the merits hearing, Coffey 
  admitted in his testimony that he moved from this address prior to the hearing 
  and did not notify the court that his address had changed. As a pro se 
  litigant, Coffey is held to the same standard as an attorney, and it was Coffeyâ€™s 
  duty to keep the court informed of his address. State v. Hollman, 232 
  S.C. 489, 498, 102 S.E.2d 873, 877 (1958) (â€œ[E]stablished rules of procedure 
  are not to be discarded, either in the trial court or on appeal, merely because 
  the defendant has been his own lawyer.â€), overruled on other grounds by 
  Stevenson v. State, 335 S.C. 193, 516 S.E.2d. 434 (1999).Â  
Based on the above, we find it was Coffeyâ€™s own error in 
  not providing the court with his address that caused him to fail to receive 
  notice of the final hearing.Â  Therefore, Coffeyâ€™s motion for relief is barred 
  by the one-year time limit under Rule 60(b), SCRCP. [2] Â  
AFFIRMED.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, AJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Because we find Coffeyâ€™s motion for relief is barred by Rule 60(b), 
    we need not address his other issues on appeal.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Jean Huggins and David Lindsay, as Personal Representative of the Estate 
        of John C. Lindsay, Jr., deceased, Appellant,
v.
Bruce A. Ericson and South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Marlboro County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-345
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 25, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Arthur K. Aiken and Howard Hammer, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Louis D. Nettles, of Florence and T. Eugene Allen, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  John C. Lindsay, Jr. 
  died as a result of an accident that occurred when his motorcycle collided with 
  a truck driven by Bruce A. Ericson. Lindsayâ€™s estate sought to stack the additional 
  underinsured motorist coverage from Lindsayâ€™s Farm Bureau insurance policies 
  covering two other vehicles he owned.Â  Each of the Farm Bureau policies provided 
  $250,000 in underinsured motorist coverage.Â  Farm Bureau paid Lindsayâ€™s estate 
  $100,000 under each policy, totaling $200,000.Â  The personal representative 
  of Lindsayâ€™s estate brought a declaratory judgment seeking a determination that 
  Farm Bureau was liable for the full amount of the underinsured motorist coverage 
  on each policy, totaling $500,000.Â  The circuit court granted summary judgment 
  in favor of Farm Bureau, finding the available underinsured motorist coverage 
  on each policy was limited to the amount of coverage Lindsay carried on the 
  vehicle involved in the accident, in this case $100,000. 
Lindsayâ€™s estate appeals arguing that the 
  available underinsured motorist coverage was not so limited because of ambiguities 
  in the Farm Bureau policy or, alternatively, because Lindsay bargained for additional 
  coverage.Â  We affirm [1]  pursuant 
  to Rule 220, SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 
  (2002 and Supp. 2003); Lanham v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of South Carolina, 
  349 S.C. 356, 361, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002) (finding that a grant of summary 
  judgment will be affirmed on appeal when there is no genuine issue as to any 
  material fact and the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of 
  law); South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Mooneyham, 304 S.C. 
  442, 446, 405 S.E.2d 396, 398 (1991) (â€œ[W]e interpret the pertinent language 
  of the statute as setting a cap on the amount which can be stacked; the amount 
  of coverage which may be stacked from policies on vehicles not involved in an 
  accident is limited to an amount no greater than the coverage on the vehicle 
  involved in the accident.â€); Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Howard, 288 
  S.C. 5, 12, 339 S.E.2d 501, 504 (1985) (â€œPertinent provisions of the uninsured 
  motorist statutes which are absent from the policy language prevail as much 
  as if expressly incorporated in the policy.â€); State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. 
  Co. v. Gunning, 340 S.C. 526, 529, 532 S.E.2d 16, 17 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œ[Section 
  38-77-160] applies to every policy as if embodied therein, and inconsistent 
  policy provisions are void.â€).
 AFFIRMED
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, 
  AJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We affirm this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Brinson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
John Brinson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-346
Heard February 11, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  25, 2004

AFFIRMED IN PART AND VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
Alysoun Meree Eversole, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan 
  McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney 
  General Charles H. Richardson, Sr., Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, 
  all of Columbia;Â  and Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:  John 
  Brinson appeals his convictions for first-degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC), 
  first-degree burglary, and kidnapping.Â  He asserts the circuit court erred in 
  denying his motion for a mistrial.Â  He further contends the court lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction because the State improperly amended the indictments for 
  first-degree burglary and first-degree CSC.  [1] Â  We affirm in part and vacate 
  in part.
FACTS
On December 2, 1999, the victim went 
  to bed around midnight only to be awoken sometime later by someone jumping on 
  her bed and on top of her.Â  Despite her attempts to fight him off, the assailant 
  pinned her to the bed, choked her, threatened to kill her, and forced her to 
  perform and receive oral sex. Â This assault lasted several hours.Â  At some point, 
  the assailant took a brief break to drink a beer from the victimâ€™s refrigerator.Â  
  He also attempted to force her to drink a beer.Â  After this pause, the assault 
  continued in much the same manner as it had before.Â  As sunrise approached, 
  the assailant threatened to kill the victim if she told anything to the police 
  about what had happened and left. Soon thereafter, the victim phoned 9-1-1 and 
  the police were dispatched to her home.Â  
Throughout this prolonged assault, the house was 
  very dark and the victimâ€™s eyes were covered with blankets and pillows.Â  At 
  no time did she get a good look at the perpetrator, but offered the police a 
  very limited physical description.Â  She informed police that the assailant had 
  a terrible speech impediment. Â The victim had a few minor injuries and was taken 
  to a local hospital, where a rape kit was performed. 
Fingerprints were lifted from the two beer bottles 
  and the headboard of the victimâ€™s bed. Â According to an investigating police 
  officer, a suspect had been determined from the victimâ€™s description and a fingerprint 
  match was quickly made with a fingerprint card of the suspect available in the 
  sex offender registry. Â Brinson was subsequently arrested and indicted for first-degree 
  burglary, first-degree CSC, and kidnapping. 
At the outset of trial, the State moved to amend 
  the indictments for first-degree burglary and first-degree CSC.Â  The State requested 
  that the word â€œintercourseâ€ be struck from the first-degree CSC indictment and 
  the words â€œand the victim was the victim of kidnapping or burglaryâ€ be added.Â  
  The State also requested that the words â€œor another participant in the crime 
  was armed with a deadly weapon or explosiveâ€ in the first-degree burglary indictment 
  be replaced with, â€œentered or remained in the nighttime.â€ Â The court allowed 
  these handwritten amendments after Brinsonâ€™s attorney stated that he had no 
  objections to the changes. 
The State presented a great deal of 
  evidence at trial incriminating Brinson.Â  The jury heard testimony concerning 
  Brinsonâ€™s speech impediment, the palm and fingerprint matches, and a DNA sample 
  taken from saliva found in the victimâ€™s underwear that matched the DNA of Brinson. 
  Â 
An investigating officer testified to the initial 
  evidence that led to the arrest of Brinson as follows: 

[ASSISTANT SOLICITOR:] What did you do with the hinge lift 
  after you - - after you did that?
[OFFICER:] I kept it in my possession. A suspect had been 
  developed through description.Â  I examined a fingerprint card that was in the 
  sexual offender registry of that certain suspect.

Brinsonâ€™s counsel promptly moved for 
  a mistrial based on the reference to the sex offender registry and the possible 
  inference of a prior record. Â Counsel further contended the error could not 
  be cured with an instruction to the jury.Â  After a stern warning to the solicitor 
  not to introduce any other references to any prior record of Brinson, the court 
  denied the motion. Â Brinson renewed his motion for a mistrial at the close of 
  the Stateâ€™s case.Â  Again denying the motion, the court stated:

[M]y recollection of the testimony was that the detective 
  said he went to check the sex offender registry.Â  He never testified that the 
  defendant was on the sex offender registry and . . . I felt it was proper for 
  a law enforcement officer, where a sex crime had occurred, to check the sex 
  offender registry.Â  I did not feel that any prejudice from that testimony had 
  occurred to the defendant, tying the defendantâ€™s prior record to that testimony, 
  although I felt it was dangerous ground and warned the witness to be careful 
  as to his testimony . . .

The jury convicted Brinson of all three 
  charges.Â  Due to his prior record, the court sentenced Brinson under section 
  17-25-45 to three concurrent terms of life imprisonment without the possibility 
  of parole.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (2003 & Supp. 2003) (outlining South 
  Carolinaâ€™s two/three strikes law).Â  Brinson appeals. 
DISCUSSION
I. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  DENIAL OF MOTION FOR 
  MISTRIAL
Brinson argues the circuit court erred 
  in denying his motion for a mistrial.Â  He contends the officerâ€™s testimony concerning 
  the fingerprint match obtained from the sex offender registry card of â€œthat 
  certain suspectâ€ was prejudicial to the degree of tainting the trial on all 
  charges. [2] Â  We disagree.
The decision to grant or deny a mistrial 
  is within the sound discretion of the trial judge; hence, we must only determine 
  if this discretion was abused.Â  State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 63, 530 
  S.E.2d 626, 627-28 (2000); State v. Dawkins, 297 S.C. 386, 392, 377 S.E.2d 
  298, 301 (1989).Â  The grant of a mistrial is an extreme measure that should 
  only be used when absolutely necessary.Â  Harris, 340 S.C. at 63, 530 
  S.E.2d at 628; State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 13, 515 S.E.2d 508, 514 
  (1999), cert. denied, 528 U.S. 1050 (1999); State v. Beckham, 
  334 S.C. 302, 310, 513 S.E.2d 606, 610 (1999).Â  In order to receive a mistrial, 
  a defendant must show error and prejudice. Harris, 340 S.C. at 63, 530 
  S.E.2d at 628.
Here, the officerâ€™s testimony strongly 
  implies prior crimes committed by Brinson.Â  Evidence of a personâ€™s character 
  or trait of character is not admissible for the purpose of proving action in 
  conformity therewith unless offered as rebuttal evidence.Â  See Rule 404(a), 
  SCRE (Generally, â€œ[e]vidence of a personâ€™s character or a trait of character 
  is not admissible for the purpose of proving action in conformity therewith 
  on a particular occasion.â€).Â  Furthermore, evidence of other crimes, wrongs, 
  or acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show 
  that the charged crime is in conformity with past behavior.Â  See Rule 
  404(b), SCRE (â€œEvidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts is not admissible to 
  prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith.Â  
  It may, however, be admissible to show motive, identity, the existence of a 
  common scheme or plan, the absence of mistake or accident, or intent.â€).Â  Based 
  on these rules, our appellate courts have held that the admittance of evidence 
  merely implying the existence of prior crimes is error.Â  See State 
  v. Tate, 288 S.C. 104, 105, 341 S.E.2d 380, 381 (1986) (holding admission 
  of photographic lineup which included a â€œmug shotâ€ of defendant constituted 
  reversible error).Â  
Brinson contends the officerâ€™s testimony concerning 
  his fingerprint file in the sex offenderâ€™s registry so strongly implied a prior 
  criminal record that a mistrial should have been granted.Â  We agree with Brinson 
  that the admittance of the officerâ€™s testimony without a curative instruction 
  to the jury in this case was legal error.Â  We find, however, that this error 
  was harmless.
No definite rule of law governs the 
  finding that an error was harmless; rather the materiality and prejudicial character 
  of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  State 
  v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 193-94, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990).Â  The decision 
  whether or not to grant a mistrial for testimony that merely implies the existence 
  of prior crimes often hinges on the degree of that implication.Â  Compare 
  Council, 335 S.C. at 13, 515 S.E.2d at 514 (holding that a reference 
  to a fingerprint card on file at the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division 
  was too vague to constitute prejudice); State v. George, 323 S.C. 496, 
  511, 476 S.E.2d 903, 912 (1996), cert. denied, 520 U.S. 1123 (1997) (finding 
  testimony of prior drug dealing to be merely suggestive and not prejudicial); 
  State v. Thompson, 352 S.C. 552, 561, 575 S.E.2d 77, 82 (Ct. App. 2003) 
  (finding an isolated reference to arrest warrants too vague to constitute reversible 
  error); with Tate, 288 S.C. at 105, 341 S.E.2d at 381 (finding 
  the admittance of mug shots of defendant to be a strong enough implication of 
  a prior criminal record to constitute reversible error). 
In our view, the trial court recognized that the 
  implication of the officerâ€™s testimony was fairly clear and these comments dangerously 
  approached the threshold of reversible error.Â  We are also troubled by the similarity 
  of the referenced prior bad acts to the charge of first-degree CSC. See 
  State v. Brooks, 341 S.C. 57, 62, 533 S.E.2d 325, 328 (2000) (â€œWhen the 
  prior bad acts are similar to the one for which the appellant is being tried, 
  the danger of prejudice is enhanced.â€).Â  When viewing this error from its relationship 
  to the entire case, however, we find this implication harmless.Â  This determination 
  is not due to the statementâ€™s vagueness, but rather, in light of its probable 
  weight when compared to the strength of the Stateâ€™s case as a whole.Â  
An error is harmless when it could not have reasonably 
  affected the result of the trial. State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 
  336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985).Â  In cases where the evidence of guilt presented 
  against an appellant, separate and apart from the evidence or testimony alleged 
  to have been admitted in error, constitutes overwhelming and un-contradicted 
  proof of guilt, a reviewing court may deem the error harmless if it believes 
  beyond a reasonable doubt that the error did not contribute to the verdict.Â  
  Chapman v. California, 386 U.S. 18 (1967); Mitchell, 286 S.C. 
  at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151; State v. Watts, 321 S.C. 158, 165-66, 467 
  S.E.2d 272, 277 (Ct. App. 1996).
Â  Here, there is overwhelming evidence in the record 
  from which the jury could have found Brinson guilty, notwithstanding the implication 
  of a prior record.Â  Evidence was presented to the jury regarding a positive 
  DNA match between Brinson and saliva found in the victimâ€™s underwear.Â  Positive 
  matches were made between Brinsonâ€™s finger and palm prints and multiple prints 
  lifted from the victimâ€™s home.Â  In light of these and other facts appearing 
  in the record, we believe beyond a reasonable doubt that the testimony of the 
  investigating officer concerning Brinsonâ€™s sex offender registry file did not 
  contribute to the verdict. State v. Parker, 315 S.C. 230, 235, 433 S.E.2d 
  831, 833 (1993); Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151.Â  Thus, 
  we find the denial of Brinsonâ€™s motion for a mistrial constituted harmless error.
II.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  SUBJECT MATTER JURISDICTION
Brinson argues the circuit court erred 
  in permitting the State to amend the indictments for first-degree burglary and 
  first-degree CSC.Â  He asserts the amendments were improper and, thus, deprived 
  the court of subject matter jurisdiction as to those two charges.Â  We agree.
â€œA circuit court has subject matter 
  jurisdiction if:Â  (1) there has been an indictment which sufficiently states 
  the offense; (2) there has been a waiver of indictment; or (3) the charge is 
  a lesser included charge of the crime charged in the indictment.â€Â  State 
  v. Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 639, 545 S.E.2d 511, 513 (2001).Â  An indictment 
  is sufficient if it contains the necessary elements of the offense intended 
  to be charged and sufficiently apprises the defendant of what he or she must 
  be prepared to meet.Â  Browning v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 
  358, 359 (1995); State v. Gill, 355 S.C. 234, 238, 584 S.E.2d 432, 434 
  (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Amendments to an indictment are allowed and do not deprive 
  the court of subject matter jurisdiction if:Â  (1) they do not change the nature 
  of the offense; (2) the charge is a lesser-included offense of the crime charged 
  on the indictment; or (3) the defendant waives presentment to the grand jury 
  and pleads guilty.Â  State v. Myers, 313 S.C. 391, 393, 438 S.E.2d 236, 
  237 (1993); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-100 (2003) (stating an amendment 
  to an indictment is permissible if the amendment does not change the nature 
  of the offense charged).Â  
Because issues related to subject matter jurisdiction 
  may be raised at any time, even for the first time on appeal, we must now decide 
  whether or not the amendments to both the burglary and criminal sexual conduct 
  charges changed the nature of each offense.Â  Browning, 320 S.C. at 368, 
  465 S.E.2d at 359 (stating issues relating to subject matter jurisdiction may 
  be raised at any time).
A. First-Degree Burglary
At the outset of trial, the State altered 
  the first-degree burglary indictment by removing the phrase â€œarmed with a deadly 
  weapon or explosiveâ€ and replacing it with â€œentered or remained in the nighttime.â€Â  
  First-degree burglary is established by proving a burglary occurred with any 
  one of several different enumerated aggravating circumstances.Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 16-11-311 (2003). [3] Â  The 
  amendment in question removed one such aggravating circumstance and replaced 
  it with another.
We find the Supreme Court decision of 
  State v. Lynch, 344 S.C. 635, 545 S.E.2d 511 (2001), conclusive precedent 
  on this issue.Â  In Lynch, a first-degree burglary indictment was amended 
  in the same manner as the case before us.Â  The State moved to amend the indictment 
  for first-degree burglary, requesting the words â€œin the hours during darknessâ€ 
  be replaced with â€œcaused physical injury.â€Â  The Court found that by changing 
  the aggravating circumstances, the amendment to the indictment â€œsubstituted 
  an entirely different offense for the one charged.â€ Id. at 640-41, 545 
  S.E.2d at 514.Â  The Court reasoned that the aggravating circumstance is the 
  â€œessenceâ€ of first-degree burglary. Id. at 640, 545 S.E.2d at 614.Â  Furthermore, 
  each aggravating circumstance is distinct from the others and requires proof 
  that is materially different.Â  Id.
The Supreme Court further explained that a defendant 
  charged with first-degree burglary by way of one aggravating circumstance is 
  not prepared to meet and defend the same charge brought via a different aggravating 
  circumstance.Â  Lynch, 344 S.C. at 641, 545 S.E.2d at 514.Â  The Court 
  recognized the fact that the penalty for both is the same does not mean an amendment 
  does not change the nature of the offense. Id. at 639, 545 S.E.2d at 
  514.Â  Based on this analysis, the Court vacated the conviction for first-degree 
  burglary, finding the amendment deprived the circuit court of subject matter 
  jurisdiction.Â  Id. at 639-41, 545 S.E.2d at 514.Â  
Here, Brinson was indicted for first-degree burglary 
  under section 16-11-311(A)(1)(a), the aggravating circumstance involving a deadly 
  weapon.Â  The amendment to the indictment deleted this aggravating circumstance 
  and replaced it with an entirely different offense and code section, section 
  16-11-311(3), providing the defendant entered or remained in the nighttime.Â  
  In light of our Supreme Courtâ€™s decision in Lynch, we find the circuit 
  court was deprived of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  As such, Brinsonâ€™s conviction 
  for first-degree burglary is vacated.Â  See Brown v. State, 343 
  S.C. 342, 346, 540 S.E.2d 846, 849 (2001) (stating acts of a court with respect 
  to a matter to which it has no subject matter jurisdiction are void).
B.Â  First-Degree Criminal Sexual 
  Conduct
The amendment of the first-degree CSC 
  charge was slightly different than that of the burglary charge.Â  Like first-degree 
  burglary, first-degree CSC is defined as a base charge (criminal sexual battery) 
  proven with any one or more of several aggravating circumstances. See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-652 (2003). [4] Â  Prior to trial, the State amended this indictment 
  by adding the words â€œand the victim was the victim of kidnapping and burglaryâ€ 
  to the indictment. Rather than substituting one aggravating circumstance for 
  another, this amendment added another aggravating circumstance to a charge made 
  a first-degree offense by the â€œuse of aggravated force,â€ which was alleged in 
  the indictment before and after the amendment.
For many of the same reasons set forth 
  in the burglary analysis, we hold this amendment changed the nature of the offense 
  and deprived the circuit court of subject matter jurisdiction over this charge.Â  
  We find that the aggravating circumstances of first-degree CSC, like first-degree 
  burglary, are â€œthe essenceâ€ of that crime. Lynch, 344 S.C. at 640, 545 
  S.E.2d at 514.Â  Each is distinct from the others and requires proof that is 
  materially different.Â  
Our decision is based on Lynch and this 
  Courtâ€™s recent holding in State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 572 S.E.2d 
  309 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In Guthrie, the defendant was indicted for first-degree 
  burglary based on the aggravating circumstance of unlawfully entering a dwelling 
  during the nighttime hours.Â  Prior to trial, the State moved to amend the indictment 
  to include as an additional aggravating factor the defendantâ€™s prior convictions 
  for two or more burglaries.Â  Over the defendantâ€™s objection, the court granted 
  the amendment.Â  On appeal, the defendant argued the circuit court lacked subject 
  matter jurisdiction because the amendment added an additional element of aggravation 
  that was not presented to the grand jury.Â  This Court held the amendment deprived 
  the circuit court of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Id. at 111, 572 S.E.2d 
  at 314.Â  We determined the amendment changed the nature of the offense charged, 
  stating â€œ[t]he two aggravating circumstances in the case sub judice 
  are distinct from one another, and thus, the proof required for each aggravating 
  circumstance is materially different from the other.â€Â  Id.
At oral argument, the State asserted this case was 
  distinguishable from Guthrie in that the statutes for first-degree CSC 
  and first-degree burglary are decidedly different.Â  The State explained the 
  amendment in this case only added another method of proof and did not provide 
  for additional elements, whereas the amendment in Guthrie added another 
  offense.Â  Because Brinsonâ€™s indictments for kidnapping and first-degree burglary 
  had been presented to the grand jury, the State argued the addition of these 
  offenses to the first-degree CSC indictment did not create a separate and entirely 
  different offense.Â  As such, the State claimed the amendment to first-degree 
  CSC did not divest the court of subject matter jurisdiction. [5] Â Â  
We reject the Stateâ€™s argument on several 
  grounds.Â  First, this case is factually similar to Guthrie.Â  As in Guthrie, 
  the original indictment in this case was correct in that the base offense and 
  one aggravating circumstance were properly alleged and remained intact after 
  the amendments.Â  Thus, applying the holding in Guthrie, we believe the 
  amendment in the instant case divested the court of subject matter jurisdiction 
  even though the original indictment properly conferred subject matter jurisdiction. [6] Â Â  Secondly, we fail to discern 
  the distinction made between the statutes for first-degree burglary and first-degree 
  CSC.Â  A review of both charges indicates there is a base offense and proof of 
  each offense requires the existence of one or more aggravating circumstances.Â  
  Thirdly, once added to the indictment, it is possible for the jury to ignore 
  the initially charged circumstance and convict the defendant of a first-degree 
  crime based solely on the added, non-indicted aggravating circumstance.Â  Although 
  the amendment did not alter the general offense of first-degree CSC, it did 
  affect the nature of the charge.Â  In this case, the nature of the charged offense 
  was substantively changed and Brinson was not apprised of what he had to be 
  prepared to answer.Â  Finally, the fact that Brinson was also indicted for kidnapping 
  and burglary, and was thus not â€œsurprisedâ€ by the amendment, is irrelevant.Â  
  As stated by our Supreme Court in Lynch: 

[I]n testing the sufficiency of an indictment and the propriety 
  of amending an indictment, it is improper to look to other indictments, even 
  if those indictments relate to the same course of conduct.Â  A subject matter 
  jurisdiction analysis is performed on individual charges, not the charges in 
  the aggregate.Â  The appropriate analysis is whether the amendment to the indictment 
  changed the nature of the offense charged, not whether the amendment in any 
  way surprised or prejudiced appellant.

Lynch, 344 S.C. at 641, 545 S.E.2d at 514; 
  see State v. Bryson, 357 S.C. 106, 114 n.6, 591 S.E.2d 637, 641 
  n.6 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œ[A]n amendment is substantive and thus not permitted unless 
  the â€˜same defense is available to the defendant both before and after the amendment 
  and upon the same evidence.â€™â€ (quoting 41 Am. Jur. 2d Indictments and Informations 
  Â§ 168 (1995))).Â Â 
By permitting the improper amendment, the circuit court 
  was divested of subject matter jurisdiction as to the charge of first-degree 
  CSC.Â  As such, the conviction on this charge is vacated.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons set forth above, we 
  find that Brinsonâ€™s kidnapping conviction and sentence of life imprisonment 
  stand. The convictions for first-degree burglary and first-degree CSC, however, 
  are vacated. [7]  Accordingly, 
  Brinsonâ€™s convictions areÂ  
AFFIRMED IN PART AND VACATED IN PART.
HUFF, J., concurs and STILWELL, J., concurs in part 
  and dissents in part in a separate opinion.
  STILWELL, J. (concurring in part and dissenting 
  in part): I concur in the majority opinion concerning the denial of a motion 
  for mistrial and the subject matter jurisdiction relating to first degree burglary.Â  
  However, I disagree and therefore dissent from the majorityâ€™s opinion on subject 
  matter jurisdiction on the criminal sexual conduct (CSC) charge.Â  The amendment 
  relating to the CSC charge did not delete from the indictment the aggravating 
  circumstance originally submitted to the grand jury, but only added an additional 
  aggravating circumstance.Â  As noted, this is the identical factual situation 
  presented in State v. Guthrie, 352 S.C. 103, 572 S.E.2d 309 (Ct. App. 
  2002).Â  I dissented in Guthrie and, in this case, adhere to the opinion 
  expressed in that dissent.

 
   
    [1] Â  Appellate counsel for Brinson originally filed a brief pursuant 
    to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  Brinson filed a separate 
    pro se response.Â  After completing our Anders review, 
    we ordered re-briefing on the mistrial issue and the two jurisdictional issues.Â  
    These issues are now the only remaining issues for appellate consideration.

 
   
    [2] Â Â  Although Brinson raises several grounds in support of this contention, 
    we confine our analysis to those arguments that were specifically raised during 
    trial.Â  See State v. Silver, 314 S.C. 483, 486, 431 S.E.2d 250, 
    251 (1993) (stating ground asserted on appeal must be supported by objection 
    raised at trial); State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5-6, 377 S.E.2d 581, 
    584 (1989) (holding a party cannot argue one ground below then argue another 
    on appeal).

 
   [3] Â  First-degree burglary is properly charged pursuant 
    to section 16-11-311, which provides in part:Â  
  
  (A) A person is guilty of burglary in the first degree 
    if the person enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit 
    a crime in the dwelling, and either:
    
  (1) when, in effecting entry or while in the dwelling 
    or in immediate flight, he or another participant in the crime:
      
   (a) is armed 
    with a deadly weapon or explosive; or
  (b) causes physical injury to a person who is not a 
    participant in the crime; or
  (c) uses or threatens 
    the use of a dangerous instrument; or
  (d) displays what is or appears to be a knife, pistol, 
    revolver, rifle, shotgun, machine gun, or other firearm; or
      
  (2) the burglary is committed by a person with a prior 
    record of two or more convictions for burglary or housebreaking or a combination 
    of both; or
   (3) the entering or remaining 
    occurs in the nighttime.
    
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (2003)(emphasis added).
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

 
   [4] Â  Section 16-3-652 provides in relevant part:
  
  (1) A person is guilty of 
    criminal sexual conduct in the first degree if the actor engages in sexual 
    battery with the victim and if any one or more of the following circumstances 
    are proven:
    
  (a) The actor uses aggravated force to accomplish sexual battery.
  (b) The victim submits to 
    sexual battery by the actor under circumstances where the victim is also the 
    victim of forcible confinement, kidnapping, robbery, extortion, burglary, 
    housebreaking, or any other similar offense or act.
    
  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-652 (1)(a),(b) (2003) (emphasis 
    added).
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

 
   
    [5] Â  The State appeared to argue that an amendment only divests a court 
    of subject matter jurisdiction if the amendment creates an offense that is 
    separate and entirely different from the one originally indicted.Â  See 
    Cutner v. State, 354 S.C. 151, 155-56, 580 S.E.2d 120, 123 (2003) (reversing 
    conviction for possession with intent to distribute (PWID) marijuana within 
    proximity of a school due to improper amendment where defendant was originally 
    indicted with the offense of PWID within proximity of a church).Â Â Â  

 
   [6] Â  While we recognize a divided Court decided Guthrie, 
    we are, nevertheless, bound by the decision.Â  

 
   
    [7] Â  Of course, in the event a conviction is vacated, the defendant may 
    be retried if he is reindicted or waives presentment. See Lynch, 
    344 S.C. at 641 n.4, 545 S.E.2d at 515 n.4 (holding appellant could be retried 
    for first-degree burglary conviction that was vacated for lack of subject 
    matter jurisdiction if he was re-indicted or waived presentment).

      Leo Gefre and Ellen Gefre, Appellants,
v.
Donald Skelton and Robert Skelton d/b/a Creative Candles,
Defendants/Third Party Plaintiffs,
v.
Travelers Property and Casualty Insurance Company and Charter Oak Fire 
        Insurance Company, Third Party Defendants,
Of Whom Donald Skelton and Robert Skelton d/b/a/ Creative Candles are 
        the, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-347
Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed May 
  25, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas J. Rubillo, of Georgetown, for Appellants.
Gene McCain Connell, Jr., of Surfside Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Leo and Ellen Gefre brought 
  this action against Donald Skelton and Robert Skelton asserting causes of action 
  for negligence, assault, battery, intentional infliction of emotional distress, 
  wrongful discharge, and negligent supervision. [1] Â  The circuit court granted summary 
  judgment in favor of Robert Skelton as to all of the claims brought against 
  him.Â  The Gefres appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Both Leo and Ellen Gefre, husband and wife, were 
  employed at Creative Candles, a candle-making shop owned and operated by Robert 
  Skelton in Pawleyâ€™s Island, South Carolina.Â  The claims raised by the Gefres 
  in this case stem from an alleged altercation at the candle shop between Leo 
  Gefre and Robert Skeltonâ€™s son, Donald Skelton. 
While working at the shop in May 1999, Leo Gefre 
  claims he was beaten and choked by Donald Skelton.Â  Following the assault, the 
  Gefres sought assurances from Robert Skelton that his son would not be allowed 
  to return to Creative Candles in order to prevent further threat of physical 
  violence.Â  Receiving no satisfactory assurances, the Gefres did not return to 
  work at the candle shop. 
The Gefres subsequently brought suit against Donald 
  Skelton alleging common-law assault and battery as well as intentional infliction 
  of emotional distress.Â  Robert Skelton d/b/a Creative Candles was also included 
  in the suit under additional causes of action for negligence, negligent supervision, 
  and wrongful discharge.
On Donald and Robert Skeltonâ€™s motion for summary 
  judgment, the circuit court dismissed the causes of action against Robert Skelton 
  as owner of Creative Candles on the ground that the claims were precluded by 
  the exclusive remedy provision of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act (Act). S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-540 (1985).Â  Specifically, the court found that these claims 
  fell within the purview of the Act because Donald Skelton was a fellow â€œemployeeâ€ 
  with the Gefres at the Creative Candles shop. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court should grant a motion for summary 
  judgment when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions 
  on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine 
  issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment 
  as a matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see Fleming v. Rose, 350 
  S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002) (â€œSummary judgment is appropriate 
  when there is no genuine issue of material fact such that the moving party must 
  prevail as a matter of law.â€).Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issues of 
  fact exist, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from 
  the evidence must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€ 
  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 61, 504 
  S.E.2d 117, 121 (1998).Â  If triable issues of fact exist, those issues must 
  go to the jury. Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 
  717, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).
DISCUSSION
I.
The Gefres claim the circuit court erred 
  in finding their claims against Robert Skelton as the owner and manager of Creative 
  Candles for injuries resulting from Donald Skeltonâ€™s alleged attack were barred 
  by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  The Gefres argue they were not limited to 
  the remedies allowed under the Act because Donald Skelton was not an employee 
  of Creative Candles.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Section 42-1-540 provides:

  
The rights and remedies granted 
  by this Title to an employee when he and his employer have accepted the provisions 
  of this Title, respectively, to pay and accept compensation on account of personal 
  injury or death by accident, shall exclude all other rights and remedies of 
  such employee, his personal representative, parents, dependents or next of kin 
  as against his employer, at common law or otherwise, on account of such injury, 
  loss of service or death.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-540 (1985).
As this case was decided by the circuit 
  court on the narrow question of whether Donald Skelton was an employee, our 
  review of the facts is confined to determining whether that employer-employee 
  relationship existed between Donald Skelton and his father. [2] Â  â€œWhether or not an employer-employee relationship 
  exists is a jurisdictional question.â€Â  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 
  S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2002).Â  Because the issue involves determining 
  proper jurisdiction, this Court must take its own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence in our analysis of whether Donald Skelton was employed at the 
  candle shop.Â  Id.Â  â€œIt is South Carolinaâ€™s policy to resolve jurisdictional 
  doubts in favor of the inclusion of employers and employees under the Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Act.â€Â  Id.Â  
The Act defines â€œemployeeâ€ as those 
  persons â€œengaged in an employment under any appointment, contract of hire, or 
  apprenticeship, expressed or implied, oral or written . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 42-1-130 (Supp. 2003).Â  In applying the definition of employee provided under 
  the Act, this Court has previously opined: â€œThe employment relationship is contractual 
  in character; however, no formality is required.Â  The contract may be oral or 
  written, and also may be implied from conduct of the parties.Â  It is enough 
  if the circumstances show unequivocally that the parties recognize the relationship.â€Â  
  Spivey v. D.G. Const. Co., 321 S.C. 19, 22, 467 S.E.2d 117, 119 (Ct. 
  App. 1996).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In determining whether an employer-employee relationship 
  exists for purposes of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, our courts have examined 
  the employerâ€™s right to control.Â  That is, the determination of employee status 
  depends on whether the putative employer has a right to control and direct the 
  particular details of the putative employeeâ€™s work.Â  Nelson, 349 S.C. 
  at 594, 564 S.E.2d at 113; see Young v. Warr, 252 S.C. 179, 189, 
  165 S.E.2d 797, 802 (1969) (â€œThe general test applied is that of control by 
  the employer.Â  It is not the actual control then exercised, but whether there 
  exists the right and authority to control and direct the particular work or 
  undertaking, as to the manner or means of its accomplishment.â€); 82 Am. Jur. 
  2d Workersâ€™ Compensation Â§ 123 (2003) (commenting that â€œ[i]t has been 
  said that in a workersâ€™ compensation case, the ultimate question in finding 
  an employment relationship is whether the employer assumes the right to control 
  the times, manner and method of executing the work of the employeeâ€).Â  
Though these determinations depend on the specific 
  facts of each case, our courts generally look to four factors in examining an 
  employerâ€™s degree of control: (1) direct evidence of the right or exercise of 
  control; (2) payment and method of payment; (3) furnishing major items of equipment; 
  and (4) the right to terminate the employment relationship at will and without 
  liability.Â  Dawkins v. Jordan, 341 S.C. 434, 439, 534 S.E.2d 700, 703 
  (2000).
Our review of the factual circumstances 
  concerning Robert Skeltonâ€™s right to control the method and manner which Donald 
  Skelton worked at the candle shop leads us to agree with the circuit courtâ€™s 
  conclusion that there is no material dispute of the facts concerning whether 
  Donald Skelton was an employee.Â  There was direct evidence presented of Robert 
  Skeltonâ€™s right and exercise of control of his sonâ€™s activities at work.Â  Both 
  Robert Skelton and Ellen Gefre testified that Donald would take instructions 
  relating to his work duties directly from his father.Â  Donald worked approximately 
  twenty hours per week and was paid $1,000 to $1,300 per month.Â  Donald worked 
  primarily in the candle-making factory portion of the business where all of 
  the equipment required to make candles was provided for him.Â  There is no evidence 
  that Donaldâ€™s employment was on any terms other than strictly at-will employment.Â  
  Furthermore, Leo and Ellen Gefre both testified in their depositions that Donald 
  Skelton was an employee.Â  They also stated in their responses to the defendantsâ€™ 
  discovery requests that Robert Skelton was Donaldâ€™s employer.
A consideration of these facts supports the conclusion 
  that each of the four indicia of control identified by our courts is present 
  in the circumstances of Donald Skeltonâ€™s work for his father.Â  We conclude therefore 
  that there is no genuine issue of material fact regarding whether Donald Skelton 
  was an â€œemployeeâ€ under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  As such, the Gefresâ€™ 
  claims against Robert Skelton are precluded by the exclusive remedy provision 
  of the Act as a matter of law.
II.
The Gefres argue the circuit court improperly 
  dismissed their claim for wrongful discharge.Â Â  The court, however, did not 
  specifically address this issue in its order granting partial summary judgment.Â  
  Despite this omission, the Gefres did not petition the court for a ruling by 
  way of a motion to alter or amend judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  As 
  such, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. 
  v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (holding that â€œ[i]t 
  is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but 
  must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for 
  appellate reviewâ€); see also Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 
  56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (finding issue was not preserved where the 
  trial judge did not explicitly rule on the appellantâ€™s argument and the appellant 
  did not raise the issue in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the 
  judgment).
CONCLUSION
We find no error with the circuit courtâ€™s ruling 
  that the Gefresâ€™ claims stemming from injuries caused by Donald Skeltonâ€™s alleged 
  assault and battery were barred by the exclusive remedy provision of the Workersâ€™ 
  Compensation Act.Â  The Gefresâ€™ claim for wrongful discharge was not preserved 
  for appellate review.Â  The courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Robert 
  Skelton is therefore
 AFFIRMED. 
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â  Ellen Gefre also alleged causes of action for loss of consortium 
    and negligent infliction of emotional distress. 

 
   
    [2] Â Â  The parties do not appear to dispute that the causes of action 
    against Robert Skelton, with the exception of wrongful discharge, come within 
    the purview of the Act if an employee-employer relationship exists.Â  See 
    Loges v. Mack Trucks, Inc., 308 S.C. 134, 136, 417 S.E.2d 538, 540 
    (1992) (â€œRecovery under the Act is the exclusive means of settling personal 
    injury claims which come under the Act.â€).

title: Centura Bank v. Cox
text:
THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Centura Bank, Respondent,
v.
Norma J. Cox, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-348
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed May 25, 
  2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bradford P. Simpson, B. Randall Dong, and Michael J. 
  Cone, all of Columbia, for Appellant. 
Ray Coit Yarborough, Jr., of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Centura Bank brought this action 
  against Norma J. Cox for judgment on a note secured by real property.Â  Cox appeals 
  the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Centura on Coxâ€™s counterclaims 
  (1) that the bank failed to timely obtain her attorney preference as required 
  by statute and (2) that the contract was unconscionable.Â  We affirm. [1] 
BACKGROUND
Cox had an outstanding loan with Centura 
  which was secured by a second mortgage on real estate and, in addition, had 
  several unsecured loans in favor of the bank.Â  The unsecured loans came due 
  and Cox planned to pay all her debts to Centura from the sale of her real property, 
  which was at that time listed for sale.Â  Centura offered to renew Coxâ€™s unsecured 
  loans if she consolidated all her debt into a loan secured by the real property 
  and payable in six months.Â  Cox agreed and because she was temporarily physically 
  disabled from a minor auto accident, a Centura employee took the documents to 
  Coxâ€™s home for her to sign.Â  
Cox failed to make the payment on the 
  new note on its maturity date.Â  When Centura commenced this action more than 
  a year after the note matured, Cox responded alleging the contract was unconscionable 
  and obtained in violation South Carolinaâ€™s attorney and insurance agent preference 
  statute.Â  Her real property, valued at $490,000 in the personal financial statement 
  she submitted with her application, was no longer on the market when Cox was 
  deposed.Â  It remained unlisted throughout the litigation.Â  Cox explained in 
  her deposition testimony she still intended to sell the property and pay off 
  the note, but wanted to wait until the market would generate a price suitable 
  to her financial needs.Â  
After a hearing, the trial court granted 
  Centuraâ€™s motion for summary judgment on Coxâ€™s counterclaims.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the 
  disposition of cases that do not require the services of a fact finder.Â  Dawkins 
  v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003).Â  When reviewing 
  the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard 
  that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper 
  when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party 
  is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 
  488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  
In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, 
  the evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be viewed in a light 
  most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sauner v. Public Serv. Auth., 
  354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003).Â  Even if there is no dispute 
  as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions to be drawn from them, 
  summary judgment should be denied.Â  Pye v. Aycock, 325 S.C. 426, 431, 
  480 S.E.2d 455, 457 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Summary judgment is not appropriate when 
  further inquiry into the facts is desirable to clarify the application of law.Â  
  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).
DISCUSSION
I.Â  The Preference Statute
Cox argues the trial court erred in ruling 
  she failed to establish the attorney and insurance agent preference statute 
  applied and in its alternative finding that Centura satisfied the statute.Â  
  We disagree with both contentions.

South Carolina Code section 37-10-102 provides:
Whenever the primary purpose of a loan that is secured 
  in whole or in part by a lien on real estate is for a personal, family or 
  household purpose â€“ 
(a)Â Â Â Â  The creditor must ascertain prior to closing 
  the preference of the borrower as to the legal counsel that is employed to represent 
  the debtor in all matters of the transaction relating to the closing of the 
  transaction . . .
The creditor may comply with this section by:
  
(1)Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  including the preference information on 
  or with the credit application . . . or
(2)Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  providing written notice to the borrower 
  of the preference information with the notice being delivered or mailed no 
  later than three business days after the application is received or prepared.Â  

  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-10-102(a) (2002) (emphasis added).Â  

Cox argues the court erroneously found she 
  presented no evidence the loaned funds were used for a personal, family, or 
  household purpose and thus erred in concluding the statute was not triggered.Â  
  Although Cox lived on part of the property she mortgaged, her testimony did 
  not indicate the purpose of the unsecured debt that was restructured. Â However, 
  as did the trial court, we assume for the purpose of our analysis that the preference 
  statute applied to this loan and conclude Centura complied with its requirements.
On July 23, 1999, a Centura employee visited 
  Cox at home to prepare her application.Â  During this visit, the date the application 
  was â€œreceived or prepared,â€ Cox signed several documents, including the credit 
  application and the attorney and insurance agent preference form. Â This evidence 
  establishes Centura ascertained Coxâ€™s preference regarding a closing attorney 
  simultaneously with the receipt and preparation of the credit application.Â  

However, Cox contends a material factual 
  dispute exists regarding the date the application was received and summary judgment 
  was thus inappropriate. Â Although she does not dispute signing all of the relevant 
  documents on July 23, Cox asserts this does not prove the date she applied for 
  the loan.Â  Noting the personal financial statement was dated July 17, Cox argues 
  this indicates Centura provided her with the application before July 23.Â  
  Relying on this premise, Cox argues there is a factual question whether Centura 
  failed to provide her with preference information within three days of the application.
We doubt the preference statute requires 
  anything more of a creditor than ascertaining a borrowerâ€™s attorney preference 
  prior to closing.Â  The specific portion of the section Cox references merely 
  describes one way a lender may comply with the statute.Â  Â§ 37-10-102(a)(2); 
  see Edge v. State Farm Ins. Co., 345 S.C. 136, 139, 546 S.E.2d 
  647, 648-49 (2001) (concluding when the term â€œmayâ€ is used, it is meant to be 
  merely permissive and not a requirement).Â  However, even if Coxâ€™s interpretation 
  of the statute is correct, the evidence and factual inferences create no genuine 
  triable issue regarding whether Centura failed to satisfy the statuteâ€™s requirements.Â  
  On the contrary, the evidence shows she signed the attorney preference form 
  and the credit application on the same day.
II.Â  Unconscionability
Cox further argues the trial court erred in failing 
  to fully consider the elements of her unconscionability counterclaim.Â  She claims 
  the contract was one of adhesion, that she was unsophisticated and naÃ¯vely believed 
  she could sell the property for $490,000 within six months, and that the sophisticated 
  Centura took advantage of her limited physical mobility knowing she was in no 
  position to negotiate.Â  Again, we find summary judgment was properly granted.
A trial court may refuse to enforce or limit 
  enforcement of a consumer credit agreement that was unconscionable when it was 
  made.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-5-108(1) (2002).Â  When making this determination, 
  a trial judge is to consider several factors outlined in section 37-5-108(4). [2] Â  Here, the court specifically referenced these statutory factors 
  before making extensive findings of fact relating to the question.Â  The court 
  found, among other things, Cox owns real and personal property that could be 
  sold to reduce the debt, Centura reasonably relied on Coxâ€™s assurances she was 
  going to sell the property, the credit contract contains no extraordinary terms, 
  Cox could have easily gone elsewhere to obtain the loan, and Cox specifically 
  noted her auto accident â€œwas not a big thing.â€Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 
  37-5-108(1)(b) (â€œany term or part of the agreement or transaction [was] unconscionable 
  at the time it was madeâ€); Â§ 37-5-108(4)(a) (â€œbelief by the . . . lender at 
  the time a transaction is entered into that there is no reasonable probability 
  of paymentâ€); Â§ 37-5-108(4)(e) (â€œthe fact that the . . . lender has knowingly 
  taken advantage of the inability of the consumer or debtor reasonably to protect 
  his interests by reason of physical or mental infirmitiesâ€).Â  
Unconscionability is the absence of meaningful choice 
  on the part of one party caused by one-sided contract provisions together with 
  terms so oppressive that no reasonable person would make them and no fair and 
  honest person would accept them.Â  Munoz v. Green Tree Fin. Corp., 343 
  S.C. 531, 541, 542 S.E.2d 360, 365 (2001).Â  The trial court, correctly citing 
  the statutory factors and several specific facts related to them, determined 
  the credit contract was neither one-sided nor oppressive.Â  We conclude the trial 
  court properly considered all relevant elements of Coxâ€™s counterclaim and correctly 
  concluded the credit contract was not unconscionable as a matter of law.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Subsection 4 has been amended since the trial court issued 
    the order on appeal.
